Although the president is the commander-in-chief of the armed forces (Article II, Section 2), only Congress can formally declare war (Article I, Section 8); therefore, eliminate (D).

content: The line-item veto was ruled unconstitutional because it

answers.A: <label>A. violated the legislative process by which bills become laws</label>
answers.B: <label>B. allowed Congress to eliminate sections of legislation without a two-thirds majority</label>
answers.C: <label>C. gave states the ability to override federal legislation</label>
answers.D: <label>D. empowered Congress to nullify executive actions</label>
answers.E: <label>E. allowed the president to pass legislation without congressional approval</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A The Line Item Veto Act of 1996 gave the president the power to veto individual sections of a bill without vetoing the entire bill. Shortly thereafter, the Supreme Court ruled the line-item veto unconstitutional because it violated the Presentment Clause (Article I, Section 7) of the Constitution by providing the president too much legislative authority. Choice (B) is incorrect because Congress generally requires only a simple majority to pass legislation. Choice (C) is incorrect because it describes the theory of nullification. Choice (D) is incorrect because it describes the legislative veto (which was determined by the Supreme Court in 1983 to be unconstitutional). Choice (E) is incorrect because only Congress may pass legislation according to Article I, Section 1 of the Constitution.

content: Which of the following best states an argument made by James Madison in The Federalist number 10?

answers.A: <label>A. Honest politicians can prevent factions from developing.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Factions are more likely to occur in large republics than in small ones.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The negative effects of factionalism can be reduced by a republican government.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Free elections are the people's best defense against factionalism.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Factions cannot emerge in a republic when decisions are made by the majority.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C In The Federalist Papers, Alexander Hamilton, James Madison, and John Jay argued in favor of states' ratification of the Constitution. Choice (B) would be an argument against the Constitution, so eliminate it. In The Federalist number 10, James Madison addresses the concerns of those who fear that the Constitution grants too much power to the federal government: Madison argues that the federal government would protect individual liberties better than states and that a republican system of government would prevent a majority from oppressing a minority. While the founders felt that free elections were beneficial, (D) is incorrect because it is not the argument made in The Federalist number 10. Eliminate (A) and (E) because factions can emerge even when politicians are honest and the majority makes decisions.

content: An "unfunded mandate" is created when the federal government requires state and municipal governments to

answers.A: <label>A. collect a sales tax in their areas without instructions on how to spend the revenues</label>
answers.B: <label>B. comply with federal laws, even if those laws conflict with state and municipal laws</label>
answers.C: <label>C. issue short-term bonds without specifying the interest rate for those bonds</label>
answers.D: <label>D. fulfill a particular duty but does not provide the finances for doing so</label>
answers.E: <label>E. attract new businesses to their areas by lowering tax rates</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D A mandate is issued when the federal government orders state or municipal governments to provide a particular service to their citizens. A mandate is unfunded when the federal government has not provided the money necessary for the state or municipal governments to provide those services. Therefore, (D) is the best answer. Choice (A) is incorrect because sales taxes are determined by state and local governments. Choice (B) is incorrect because it describes the supremacy clause of the Constitution. Choice (C) is incorrect because the issuance of municipal bonds is a decision made by state and local governments. Choice (E) is incorrect because states and municipal governments can lower the state and local tax rates (not federal tax rates) without federal involvement.

content: Which of the following is an example of "horse-race journalism"?

answers.A: <label>A. A news story focuses on a politician's scandals rather than achievements.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. A television news anchor reports an event before the station's rivals.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A reporter announces which candidate leads in a public opinion poll.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A newspaper editor prints stories about long-term political developments.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. A radio broadcaster interviews a senator about recent policy decisions.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C "Horse-race journalism" refers to the media practice of focusing its reports on how candidates fare relative to each other in public opinion polls rather than on substantive issues in the campaigns. This makes (C) the best answer. The other choices are incorrect because they are not about campaigns. Even if these other choices took place during a campaign, they would still be incorrect because they do not draw attention to the relative positions of the candidates in the polls.

content: Federal election laws require that, in

answers.A: <label>A. an area that has a substantial community of non-English speakers, voters be provided with ballots in their native language</label>
answers.B: <label>B. an electoral district that has historically low voter turnout, polling places be open for longer than the typical work day</label>
answers.C: <label>C. a state with a budget deficit, a tax be collected from each voter to pay for the cost of the election</label>
answers.D: <label>D. a region with racial diversity, congressional district lines be drawn to guarantee that at least one elected congressperson be of a racial minority</label>
answers.E: <label>E. an area that lacks adequate public transportation, all voters with drivers licenses be automatically registered to vote</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A Subsequent amendments to the Voting Rights Act of 1965 have aimed to protect "language minority groups." To protect minority groups from being denied the right to vote based solely on language, federal election laws require that, in areas where more than 5% of the voting population belongs to a single language minority, election materials be provided in that minority's preferred language. The other answer choices are not true and, in some cases, as with the poll tax suggested by (C), are specifically illegal based on federal election laws.

content: Which of the following is the largest source of "automatic spending" for the federal government?

answers.A: <label>A. Salaries to employees of the U.S. Post Office</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Interest payments made to U.S. bondholders</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Entitlement programs</label>
answers.D: <label>D. National defense</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Infrastructure investments in roads and bridges</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The federal government's discretionary spending is determined each year by Congress through its regular budgeting process. These expenditures include (D) and (E). Non-discretionary spending is sometimes referred to as "automatic" or "uncontrollable" because those expenditures are required by law, outside of the usual budgeting process. Congress enacts laws to set the eligibility requirements for entitlement programs, such as Social Security and Medicare, and unless Congress changes the eligibility requirements, each year's expenditures are usually the result of how many people participate in these programs. Choice (B) is another form of automatic, or uncontrollable spending, but (C) makes up a greater amount of spending. In (A), the post office is a generally self-sufficient entity, so its employees' salaries are paid by the post office, not Congress.

content: Which of the following best describes the Supreme Court's doctrine of incorporation?

answers.A: <label>A. Although the Constitution empowers the federal government to regulate international trade, states may establish boycotts of goods imported from countries that use child labor.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. While the Congress creates laws, and the executive branch enacts and enforces those laws, only the Supreme Court may decide which laws and executive actions are unconstitutional.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The Fifth Amendment guarantees that an individual may not be deprived of life, liberty, or property without due process, and this protection provides a legal justification for those who do not wish to serve on a jury.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Although the Securities and Exchange Commission has the power to establish regulations for the financial markets, it does not have the authority to levy fines against or otherwise punish those who do not comply.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The Bill of Rights articulates certain rights in order to protect individuals from the federal government, and the Fourteenth Amendment extends most of those rights to protect individuals from the state governments as well.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E Choice (E) best describes the doctrine of incorporation. Choice (A) is incorrect because states may not regulate international trade. Choice (B) is incorrect because it describes judicial review. Choices (C) and (D) begin correctly but end with incorrect conclusions: the Fifth Amendment does not allow people to avoid jury duty, and the SEC can levy fines and bring lawsuits against those who violate its regulations.

content: Which of the following plays the most significant role in forming a child's political views?

answers.A: <label>A. The geographical area in which the child grows up</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The child's family</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The media to which the child is exposed</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The child's religion</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The child's teacher</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Political socialization is the process by which children and adolescents learn about politics, and it affects their political views for the rest of their lives. A child's family plays the greatest role in shaping his or her understanding of politics, so (B) is the best. Although (A), (C), (D), and (E) influence a child's political views, they do not play the most significant role in doing so; therefore, those choices are incorrect.

content: Which of the following was the legal basis for the 1973 Roe v. Wade majority opinion, in which the Supreme Court struck down a state ban on abortion?

answers.A: <label>A. The Nineteenth Amendment secures for women the right to vote.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The Civil Rights Act of 1964 prohibits discrimination based on gender.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The Bill of Rights implies a right to privacy.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The Ninth Amendment reserves powers to the people.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The First Amendment guarantees freedom of religion.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C In the Roe v. Wade decision, the Supreme Court found that the Bill of Rights implies a right to privacy, and the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment extends that right to the state level. Therefore, states cannot invade women's privacy by banning abortions, and (C) is the best. The other choices correctly connect laws with their effects, but these choices were not used in crafting the Roe decision.

content: When the Founders met in 1787 to write the Constitution, their primary objective was to

answers.A: <label>A. establish a bill of rights that would protect citizens from the government</label>
answers.B: <label>B. create a national court system for hearing disputes between citizens of different states</label>
answers.C: <label>C. return to the states those powers that the Articles of Confederation had given to the central government</label>
answers.D: <label>D. create a government in which small states had equal influence as large states</label>
answers.E: <label>E. replace the weak central government created by the Articles of Confederation with a stronger one</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E The founders met in 1787 to write the Constitution in response to the failures of the Articles of Confederation. The primary failure of the government created by the Articles of Confederation was that it was too weak to deal with the problems faced by the young country; therefore, (E) is the best. Although the Bill of Rights was eventually added to the Constitution, it was in reaction to the stronger federal government that the Constitution created; therefore, you should eliminate (A). Choice (B) describes the Supreme Court, which was created by the Constitution but was not the primary objective of the Founders. Choice (C) is incorrect because states had more power under the Articles of Confederation than under the Constitution. Choice (D) is incorrect because states were equally represented in Congress under the Articles of Confederation.

content: Which of the following best articulates the doctrine of original intent?

answers.A: <label>A. When a law is unclear, the Supreme Court may consider the intent of a law or the letter of the law, but not both.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Copyright laws exist to protect the rights of those who create original works.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Appellate judges should respect the original decisions of trial judges.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The Constitution should be interpreted in light of the intent of those who wrote it.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The Supreme Court should not hear a case unless the court intends to issue an original decision that is different from past decisions.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D The doctrine of original intent holds that the Constitution should be understood to mean only what the Framers who wrote it intended for it to mean. This doctrine is at odds with those who see a "living Constitution" whose meaning changes as the times change. Therefore, (D) is the best. Choices (A) and (E) are incorrect because they do not accurately describe how the Supreme Court hears cases. Choice (B) is true but does not describe the doctrine of original intent. Choice (C) is incorrect because, although judges respect others' opinions, appellate judges are not bound to the decisions of trial judges.

content: Which of the following is a significant difference between the Senate and the House of Representatives?

answers.A: <label>A. Only the House has the power to issue subpoenas.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Only the Senate may introduce revenue bills.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. States are equally represented in the House, while representation in the Senate is proportional to population.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The Senate allows unlimited debate, while the House does not.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The House has the power to confirm presidential appointments, while the Senate does not.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D The filibuster allows senators to engage in unlimited debate; no such rule exists in the House. Therefore, the best choice is (D). Choice (A) is incorrect because both houses can issue subpoenas. Choice (B) is incorrect because the Constitution dictates that revenue (tax) bills originate in the House. Choice (C) gets it backward: each state has two senators, and representation in the House is proportional to population. Choice (E) is incorrect because only the Senate may confirm presidential appointments.

content:
Appointments to which of the following positions must be confirmed by the Senate before taking effect?

I. Director of Homeland Security

II. Secretary of the Treasury

III. National Security Advisor

IV. U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations

answers.A: <label>A. II only</label>
answers.B: <label>B. I and III only</label>
answers.C: <label>C. II and IV only</label>
answers.D: <label>D. I, II, and IV only</label>
answers.E: <label>E. I, II, III, and IV</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Start with the positions you know the most about. Maybe you recall that the secretary of the treasury is a member of the cabinet, and therefore requires Senate confirmation. Eliminate (B) because it does not include II. All U.S. Ambassadors must be confirmed by the Senate; therefore, you may eliminate (A) because it does not include IV. The Director of Homeland Security is also a member of the cabinet, so eliminate (C) because it does not include I. The National Security Advisor is a member of the White House staff, not the cabinet, and is not subject to Senate confirmation. Eliminate (E) because it includes III, and choose (D).

content: Which of the following CANNOT limit the influence of the federal courts?

answers.A: <label>A. A constitutional amendment to the contrary of a court decision</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The impeachment of a federal judge</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A governor's failure to enforce a court decision</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A national election recalling an unpopular judge</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Appointment of new judges</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Choice (D) is the best answer because federal judges are appointed and therefore not subject to recall elections. The other choices are valid recourses for those who disagree with a court's ruling. Constitutional amendments are not subject to judicial review, so eliminate (A). Judges can be impeached for their crimes, so eliminate (B). If a governor (or any government executive, such as the president or a mayor) disagrees with a ruling, he or she might choose not to enforce the court's decision. This is not a long-term solution, as the issue would likely be taken up by the court again, but the executive would be able to limit the reach of the courts for a while, so eliminate (C). The appointment of new judges sympathetic to Congress and/or the president would make it more likely that laws would be upheld, thus reducing the courts' checks on congressional and presidential power; therefore, you may eliminate (E).

content: Which of the following is true of the House Committee on Ways and Means?

answers.A: <label>A. Its primary role is to appropriate spending for infrastructure projects.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It is the primary author of congressional banking reform legislation.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It allocates funding for canals and waterways.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It serves the same function as the Senate Committee on Appropriations.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Its jurisdiction includes the tax system.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E The primary role of the House Committee on Ways and Means is to write laws dealing with revenue (taxes), so (E) is the best. It does not oversee infrastructure, banking, or canals and waterways, so eliminate (A), (B), and (C). Choice (D) is incorrect because the Senate Committee on Appropriations is the analog of the House Committee on Ways and Means; even so, the two committees are not exactly the same. The Constitution states that all revenue bills must begin in the House, not the Senate.

content: Of the following interest groups, which has created the largest number of political action committees (PACs) since the 1970s?

answers.A: <label>A. Environmental activists</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Labor unions</label>
answers.C: <label>C. For-profit business</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Religious institutions</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Senior citizens</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Of the interest groups in the answer choices, business and labor unions make the most use of PACs, so eliminate (A), (D), and (E). More PACs have been created to support business interests than labor unions, so the best choice is (C).

content: Which of the following is NOT true of executive orders?

answers.A: <label>A. Presidents avoid using executive orders for controversial actions.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Executive orders have the same effect as laws passed by Congress.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Presidents have made increased use of executive orders since the 1970s.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Executive orders bypass congressional approval.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The courts have jurisdiction over executive orders.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A Choices (B), (C), (D), and (E) correctly describe executive orders, while (A) does not. Presidents have made increased use of executive orders (C) in large part because they are not subject to congressional approval (D). This allows presidents to take unilateral action, especially on controversial issues, so (A) is best. Because executive orders have the same effect as laws passed by Congress (B), they too are subject to judicial review (E).

content: All of the following are core values of American political culture EXCEPT

answers.A: <label>A. income equality</label>
answers.B: <label>B. democracy</label>
answers.C: <label>C. individual liberty</label>
answers.D: <label>D. due process</label>
answers.E: <label>E. equality before the law</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A Choices (B), (C), (D), and (E) correctly identify core values of American political culture; therefore, (A) is the best. Americans generally agree on the concept of equal opportunity but generally oppose the idea of equality of outcome. Equal opportunity means that everyone is given the same chance to achieve: some will succeed, and some will fail. Equality of outcome means that the government guarantees that everyone receives the same results: no matter how hard someone works or how talented someone is, no one receives more than anyone else. Equality before the law is an example of equal opportunity. Income equality, in which everyone receives the same amount of money, is an example of equality of outcome.

content: Why do political scientists identify the presidential elections of Franklin Roosevelt in 1932 and Richard Nixon in 1968 as well as the midterm election of 1994 as "critical elections"?

answers.A: <label>A. The issues at stake in those elections were more important than in most elections.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Those elections saw major shifts in party alignment that would last for decades.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Minority voters played a key role in deciding the winners of those elections.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Those elections took place during wartime.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The personalities of the candidates were more important to voters than issues in those elections.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B "Critical elections" mark dramatic party realignments, as happened in the 1932, 1968, and 1994 elections; therefore, (B) is the best. The issues discussed during the elections of 1932, 1968, and 1994 were important, so eliminate (E). However, (A) is incorrect because it is highly subjective and would not be a point of agreement among political scientists. Many minority voters were disenfranchised during the 1930s, so eliminate (C). Choice (D) is incorrect because the U.S. was not at war in 1932 or 1994.

content: Which of the following conclusions can be drawn from the data above?

answers.A: <label>A. Republican presidents appointed a higher percentage of minorities to the judiciary than Democratic presidents.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Democratic presidents appointed a higher percentage of males to the judiciary than Republican presidents.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. President Clinton made more judicial appointments than President Reagan.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. President Obama appointed the highest percentage of women to the judiciary.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. President Reagan appointed the highest percentage of African Americans to the judiciary.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D In assessing (A) and (B), recall that the Republicans presidents are Ronald Reagan, George H.W. Bush, and George W. Bush; the Democratic presidents are James Carter, William Clinton, and Barack Obama. Choice (A) is incorrect because white judges comprised 93.9%, 89.1%, and 82.2% of the Republican presidents' appointments, respectively; this means that minorities constituted 6.1%, 10.9%, and 17.8% of their appointments, respectively. On the other hand, white judges comprised 78.2%, 75.3%, and 64.2% of the Democratic presidents' appointments, respectively; this means that minorities constituted 21.8%, 24.7%, and 35.8% of their appointments, respectively. Choice (B) is incorrect because 84.3%, 70.6%, and 59.0% of Democratic appointments were male judges, compared with 91.6%, 81.3%, and 78.2% of Republican appointments. Choice (C) is incorrect because President Clinton made 378 appointments, and President Reagan made 383 appointments. Choice (D) is correct because 41.0% of President Obama's appointments were women, the highest of any other president shown. Choice (E) is incorrect because 1.8% of President Reagan's appointments were African Americans, the lowest of any president shown.

content: Which of the following accurately describes individual entitlements?

answers.A: <label>A. Congress provides funds to the states, and the states decide how best to spend the money.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Congress is allowed to fund these programs only when the federal government has a budget surplus.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Congress must pay benefits to anyone who qualifies to receive them.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Congress grants money to states, provided that certain criteria are met.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Congress must pass a law each year to determine how to allocate these funds.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Choice (C) accurately defines an entitlement program, such as Social Security or Medicare. Choice (A) is incorrect because it describes a block grant. Choice (B) is incorrect because entitlement programs pay benefits regardless of whether the federal government has a budget surplus or deficit. Choice (D) is incorrect because it describes a categorical grant. Choice (E) is incorrect because individual entitlement revenues are collected and benefits are paid outside the normal budgeting process: this means that, once created, entitlement programs continue, year in and year out, until Congress changes them by law.

content: While ratifying the Constitution, the primary point of disagreement between Federalists and Anti-Federalists was over

answers.A: <label>A. whether representation in Congress should be equal among states or proportional to population</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the strength of the federal government relative to the states</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the future of the slave trade</label>
answers.D: <label>D. whether people had inalienable rights</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the future location of the nation's capital</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Federalists favored a strong central government, as opposed to the weak Congress created by the Articles of Confederation. Anti-Federalists preferred that power remain with the states. While (A) and (C) were issues raised during the Constitutional Convention, they were not the subject of the primary debates between Federalists and Anti-Federalists as states considered ratifying the Constitution.

content: All of the following statements about gerrymandering are true EXCEPT that it

answers.A: <label>A. favors incumbent candidates over challengers</label>
answers.B: <label>B. can divide like-minded voters into several districts to reduce their influence</label>
answers.C: <label>C. has been allowed by the Supreme Court in some instances</label>
answers.D: <label>D. increases the control voters have over their elected officials</label>
answers.E: <label>E. can group members of a racial minority into a single district</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Gerrymandering is the drawing of voting district boundaries to achieve an electoral result that benefits the drawer. One common gerrymandering tactic is to "pack" members of a racial minority into a single district to minimize their effect on other districts; so eliminate (E). Another tactic is to "crack" members of a demographic group: in this case, a political party that draws its support from suburban voters may divide the region's urban voters into several districts where they will be outnumbered by suburban voters, thus eliminating the electoral influence of the urban voters; so eliminate (B). Districts are usually drawn to protect incumbents and make their seats "safe" from challengers, so eliminate (A). While the Supreme Court has placed restrictions on the use of gerrymandering (e.g., districts must be contiguous and must not be racially biased) it has allowed bipartisan gerrymandering; eliminate (C). All of these methods of gerrymandering have the effect of reducing voters' influence on their representatives, which is why (D) is the best answer.

content: Federalism is a principle of government in which

answers.A: <label>A. power is shared between the national government and state governments</label>
answers.B: <label>B. states have equal representation in the national government</label>
answers.C: <label>C. individual liberties are guaranteed by a Bill of Rights</label>
answers.D: <label>D. legislative, executive, and judicial powers are separated</label>
answers.E: <label>E. states give their law-making powers over to the national government</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A This is the definition of the constitutional principle of federalism. Choice (B) describes how states are represented in the U.S. Senate. Choice (C) is true of the Constitution, but does not define federalism. Choice (D) describes the separation of powers included in the Constitution. Choice (E) is incorrect because while states share powers with the national government, in a federal system they do not give up all power.

content: Which of the following is the best illustration of "pork barrel" legislation?

answers.A: <label>A. A federal agency is created to ensure the safety of food and animal products.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. A bill can be passed only if a majority of congresspersons from rural districts approve of it.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A senator refuses to vote for a tax increase without a corresponding decrease in spending.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A federal program provides free lunches to schoolchildren of low-income families.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. A member of Congress inserts a provision into a bill to secure funding for a project in his or her district.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E "Pork barrel" legislation refers to a law that establishes funding for a project in the member's home district in order to benefit his or her constituents. The name "pork barrel" does not refer to farming, so eliminate (A) and (B). Nor does it refer to food, so eliminate (D).

content: An appointment to which of the following offices is NOT subject to confirmation by the U.S. Senate?

answers.A: <label>A. Securities and Exchange commissioner</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Secretary of the Interior</label>
answers.C: <label>C. White House Chief of Staff</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Chair of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The White House Chief of Staff is appointed by the president to manage White House affairs and advise the president, but is not subject to Senate approval. A president's nominee for any of the other positions must be approved by the Senate before the appointment takes effect.

content: The opposition of the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), the National Association of Women Lawyers (NAWL), and the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations (AFL-CIO) to Samuel Alito's 2006 nomination to the Supreme Court is an example of

answers.A: <label>A. realignment</label>
answers.B: <label>B. coalition building</label>
answers.C: <label>C. impeachment</label>
answers.D: <label>D. a recall election</label>
answers.E: <label>E. a voter drive</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Coalition building is the cooperation of distinct groups with their own interests toward a common purpose. Choice (B) is the best because the ACLU, NAWL, and AFL-CIO believed Samuel Alito was too conservative to be allowed on the Supreme Court and worked together to oppose his nomination. Choice (A) is incorrect because realignment deals with voters switching political parties. Choice (C) is incorrect because impeachment means to remove someone from office. Choice (D) is incorrect because federal judges and justices are not elected; therefore, they are not subject to recall elections. Choice (E) is incorrect because a voter drive registers people to vote.

content: Which of the following does the Supreme Court NOT have the power to override?

answers.A: <label>A. Constitutional amendments</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Presidential executive orders</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Laws passed by Congress</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Laws passed by state legislatures</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Decisions of state courts</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A Through its power of judicial review, the Supreme Court has the power to interpret the Constitution but not to override the Constitution or its Amendments; therefore, the best answer is (A). The court's power of judicial review allows it to overturn laws passed by Congress and presidential actions, so eliminate (B) and (C). The supremacy clause of the Constitution gives the Supreme Court the power to overturn actions of state governments as well, so eliminate (D) and (E).

content: Which of the following does NOT appear in the Constitution?

answers.A: <label>A. The electoral college</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Political parties</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Separation of powers</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The term length for members of Congress</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Supremacy of the federal law over state law</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Political parties were not anticipated by the Framers of the Constitution and are not mentioned in it, so the best answer is (B). Choice (A) is incorrect because the electoral college is mentioned in Article II, which explains how the president is elected. Choice (C) is incorrect because the Constitution laid out three branches of government and checks and balances among them. Choice (D) is incorrect because Article I, which addresses Congress, specifies the two-year and six-year terms for representatives and senators, respectively. Choice (E) is incorrect because Article VI, Clause 2 specifies that the Constitution and federal law are "the supreme law of the land"; this is often referred to as the "supremacy clause."

content: Which of the following best describes the balance the Supreme Court has struck between the establishment clause and the free-exercise clause?

answers.A: <label>A. Freedom of speech is protected except in certain situations, such as yelling "fire" in a crowded theater.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Once a church has been recognized by the federal government, its tax-exempt status can never be revoked.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Once Congress has created an administrative agency, that agency can be dissolved only by a constitutional amendment.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. State-sponsored prayer during school hours is prohibited, but voluntary prayer by student groups before school is allowed.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Religious freedom allows people to avoid paying taxes.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D The First Amendment begins with "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereofâ€¦." The Supreme Court has interpreted this to mean that federal, state, and local governments cannot take actions that favor one religion over another or none at all (the establishment clause), and that government cannot interfere with the practice of religion (the free-exercise clause). Choice (D) is the best answer because it accurately describes the precedent established by the decisions in Engel v. Vitale (1962) and Abington School District v. Schempp (1963). Choice (A) is incorrect because it summarizes the decision in Schenck v. United States (1919), which addressed a free-speech issue. Choice (B) inaccurately describes the tax-exempt status of religious organizations. Choice (C) is incorrect because Congress can pass a law to dissolve an administrative agency. Choice (E) inaccurately describes religious freedom.

content: Which principle was established by the Supreme Court's decision in Marbury v. Madison?

answers.A: <label>A. One man, one vote</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Separate but equal</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Judicial review</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Right to privacy</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Freedom of expression</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The Supreme Court's decision in Marbury v. Madison was the first to overturn an act of Congress, establishing the precedent of judicial review. Thus, the best answer is (C). Choice (A) is incorrect because "one man, one vote" was established by the court's 1964 decision in Reynolds v. Sims. Choice (B) is incorrect because "separate but equal" was established by the court's 1896 decision in Plessy v. Ferguson; it was later overturned by the court's 1954 decision in Brown v. Board of Education. Choice (D) is incorrect because a right to privacy was established in the court's 1965 decision in Griswold v. Connecticut. Choice (E) is incorrect because a freedom of expression in based on the First Amendment's freedom of speech and has been hotly debated for the last century.

content: Divided government frequently results in

answers.A: <label>A. reapportionment of voting districts</label>
answers.B: <label>B. amendments to the Constitution</label>
answers.C: <label>C. conflict between states and the federal government</label>
answers.D: <label>D. an expansion of executive power</label>
answers.E: <label>E. delays in the confirmation of those nominated to be ambassadors</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E Divided government occurs when the president's political party does not hold a majority in both houses of Congress, creating more friction and less cooperation between the two branches. Because ambassadors are nominated by the president and must be confirmed by the Senate in order to serve, (E) is a frequent result when the president and the Senate are of different parties. Choice (A) is incorrect because reapportionment occurs on the state level. Choice (B) is incorrect because the passage of a constitutional amendment requires a two-thirds majority in each house of Congress, which is not significantly more likely in times of divided government. Choice (C) is incorrect because divided government creates conflict between branches of the federal government (or even bodies of Congress) but not between states and the federal government. Choice (D) is incorrect because during times of divided government, the opposition party in Congress limits the power of the president more than the president's party would.

content: In which of the following cases did the Supreme Court decision establish the "separate but equal" doctrine of state-sponsored racial segregation?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A Choice (A) is the best answer because the decision in Plessy v. Ferguson (1896) upheld a state law mandating racial segregation. Choice (B) is incorrect because McCulloch v. Maryland (1819) established that the Bank of the United States could not be taxed by the State of Maryland because of the supremacy clause in the Constitution. Choice (C) is incorrect because Gibbons v. Ogden (1824) reinforced the federal government's power to regulate interstate trade, citing the Constitution's commerce clause and supremacy clause. Choice (D) is incorrect because Brown v. Board of Education (1954) overturned the Plessy v. Ferguson decision. Choice (E) is incorrect because Gideon v. Wainwright (1963) mandated that states must provide an attorney for a defendant who cannot afford one.

content: Which of the following describes a core principle of the Constitution as it was written in 1787?

answers.A: <label>A. Direct democracy</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Checks and balances</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Equal representation</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Unitary government</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Universal suffrage</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B The Constitution divides power among the legislative, executive, and judicial branches. Each branch can restrict, or "check," the actions of the others, establishing a "balance" that prevents tyranny. This makes (B) the best. Choice (A) is incorrect because the Constitution creates a republic, or representative democracy, in which decisions are made by elected representatives. Direct democracy empowers voters to make legislative decisions, such as ballot initiatives, referendums, and recall elections. This occurs in some states but not in the federal government. Choice (C) is incorrect because each state has equal representation in the Senate but representation in the House is proportional to population. The president is elected by the electoral college, in which each state has a number of votes equal to its number of senators and representatives. Choice (D) is incorrect because only a central government exercises power in a unitary system: the Constitution establishes a system of federalism, in which power is shared between the federal government and the states. Choice (E) is incorrect because suffrage is the right to vote, and many people were not permitted to vote in 1787. Since then, the Fifteenth Amendment has extended suffrage to African American men, the Nineteenth Amendment has extended suffrage to women, and the Twenty-sixth Amendment has lowered the voting age to 18.

content: The legal principle that instructs judges to follow established precedent when deciding cases is commonly referred to as
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Precedent is the tradition of deciding cases in a matter consistent with the decisions of past courts. Stare decisis, Latin for "the decision stands," is the phrase associated with legal precedent, making (D) the best. Choice (A) is incorrect because a writ of certiorari is a request from the Supreme Court to a lower court for a case transcript; this writ is issued when the court is considering hearing a case. Choices (B) and (E) are incorrect because de jure means "by law" and de facto means "in practice." This distinction has become important in cases dealing with segregation, which may not exist legally (de jure) but exist in reality (de facto). Choice (C) is incorrect because ex post facto ("after the fact") describes a law that criminalizes an action after it has already occurred; the Constitution prohibits Congress from passing such laws.

content: Federal election laws are designed to achieve all of the following EXCEPT

answers.A: <label>A. require disclosure of campaign donations</label>
answers.B: <label>B. prevent campaigns from issuing "attack" ads</label>
answers.C: <label>C. limit campaign contributions</label>
answers.D: <label>D. require disclosure of campaign expenditures</label>
answers.E: <label>E. provide public financing of presidential campaigns</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B The Federal Election Campaign Acts of 1971 and 1974 created the Federal Election Commission (FEC). The FEC and subsequent laws have placed limits on how much money may be given to candidates and political parties, so eliminate (C). The FEC also requires campaigns to disclose information about their donations and expenditures, so eliminate (A) and (D). Presidential candidates who receive more than 10% of the vote in primary elections and agree to follow certain spending limits are eligible to receive matching funds for donations under $250; therefore, you should eliminate (E). There are no laws or FEC regulations barring "attack" ads, so the best answer is (B).

content: Which of the following statements about the House of Representatives is true?

answers.A: <label>A. All revenue bills must originate in the Senate before moving to the House.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Representation in the House is allocated equally among the states, while representation in the Senate is allocated proportional to population.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The House allows for unlimited debate, while the Senate does not.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The House has a Committee on Ways and Means, while the Senate does not.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E Choice (A) is incorrect because all revenue (tax) bills must originate in the House. Choice (B) is incorrect because representation is proportional to population in the House and equal among states in the Senate. Choice (C) is incorrect because the president pro tempore of the Senate is a ceremonial role, while the speaker of the House is a leadership role. Choice (D) is incorrect because the House places strict time limits on debates, while the Senate allows for unlimited debate, as seen with the filibuster. Choice (E) is the best because the Senate Finance Committee is the equivalent of the House Ways and Means Committee.

content: According to the Constitution, who determines voter eligibility requirements?

answers.A: <label>A. The president</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Congress</label>
answers.C: <label>C. State legislatures</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Federal administrative agencies</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The Supreme Court</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Article I, Section 4 grants the power to determine the "times, places, and manner of holding elections for senators and representatives" to the state legislatures; this makes (C) the best answer. The federal government may take corrective action when state election practices violate voters' rights (such as gerrymandering to reduce the influence of minority voters and literacy tests), but the primary responsibility falls on the states, so eliminate (A), (B), (D), and (E).

content: Which of the following is NOT part of the "iron triangles" that influence public policy-making?

answers.A: <label>A. House committees</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Senate committees</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The courts</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Bureaucratic agencies</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Interest groups</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C "Iron triangles" are informal alliances that form as rules are developed by bureaucratic agencies. The three parties in an "iron triangle" are 1) the bureaucratic agency that writes the rules, so eliminate (D); 2) the congressional committees that oversee the agency, so eliminate (A) and (B); and 3) the affected industry and its interest groups, so eliminate (E). Choice (C) is the answer because the courts are not involved in making public policy.

content: Which of the following is the most direct result of an electoral system with single-member districts?

answers.A: <label>A. Proliferation of many small parties</label>
answers.B: <label>B. A balance of power that favors the president over Congress</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A persistent third-party presence</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Development of a two-party system</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Elected officials who are more responsive to voter demands</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Congressional districts are single-member districts: the candidate who wins the most votes is elected to office and the losing parties receive no representation. This is in contrast to party-proportional representation, in which, for example, a party that receives 10% of the vote takes 10% of the seats in parliament. In this "winner take all" situation, minor parties receive no representation, so eliminate (A) and (C). Instead, groups of voters congeal into two major parties in an effort to win a majority, making (D) the best answer. Because voters generally have only two choices in an election and the margin of victory doesn't matter, representatives are less responsive to voter demands; therefore, you can eliminate (E). Choice (B) is incorrect because single-member districts affect how representatives are elected but not the power they exercise in office.

content: Which of the following court decisions did NOT deal with the First Amendment?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A The First Amendment guarantees five freedoms: speech, religion, petition, press, and assembly. Choice (A) is the best answer because Roe v. Wade addressed a woman's right to an abortion. New York Times v. United States, as one would imagine from the name, deals with freedom of the press, so eliminate (B). Choice (C) is incorrect because DeJonge v. Oregon addresses freedom of assembly. Choice (D) is incorrect because Dennis v. United States addresses freedom of speech. Choice (E) is incorrect because Engel v. Vitale prohibited state-sponsored prayer in school.

content: Which of the following statements about political action committees (PACs) is most accurate?

answers.A: <label>A. They may only campaign for issues, not for individual candidates</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Their activities are not regulated by the Federal Election Commission (FEC)</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Their activities are limited to national presidential elections</label>
answers.D: <label>D. They raise money to influence federal, state, and local elections</label>
answers.E: <label>E. They may not be formed by corporations, unions, or other special interest groups</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D PACs are organized in order to campaign for individual candidates, pieces of legislation, or ballot measures. While PACs may campaign for issues, choice (A) is incorrect as they can do more than just campaign for issues. Choice (B) is incorrect as the FEC does regulate PAC activities. Choice (C) is incorrect as PACs may also campaign for state and local elections as well. Choice (E) is incorrect as corporations and unions are permitted to form PACs.

content: Which of the following is NOT a way in which the powers of the executive branch are balanced by the legislative branch?

answers.A: <label>A. The Senate may use the filibuster to block an executive order.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Congress may impeach and convict a president for "high crime and misdemeanors."</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The Senate can decline to ratify a treaty.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The Senate can decline to approve a president's nominee for the Supreme Court.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Congress may refuse the president's request to declare war.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A The Senate uses the filibuster to block a vote on a bill; it does not affect executive orders. Choices (B), (C), and (D) are incorrect as Article II of the U.S. Constitution grants Congress the power to impeach and convict a president, the Senate the power to ratify treaties, and the Senate the power to refuse to approve a president's appointees. Choice (E) is incorrect as Article I of the U.S. Constitution grants the Senate the power to decline a president's request to declare war.

content: The attorney general is the head of which of the following entities?

answers.A: <label>A. The Senate Judiciary Committee</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The Department of Justice</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The Department of State</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The Judge Advocate General's Corps</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The Central Intelligence Agency</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B The attorney general is appointed by the president and approved by the Senate to serve as the chief executive officer of the Department of Justice. Choice (A) is incorrect as the head of the Senate Judiciary Committee is a chairman or chairwoman. Choice (C) is incorrect as the Secretary of State heads up the State Department. Choice (D) is incorrect as the head of the Judge Advocate General's Corps is the Judge Advocate General. Choice (E) is incorrect as the head of the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) is the Director of the CIA.

content: Which of the following is an example of an implied power of the Congress?

answers.A: <label>A. regulation of interstate commerce</label>
answers.B: <label>B. borrowing money on the credit of the United States</label>
answers.C: <label>C. oversight of executive branch agencies</label>
answers.D: <label>D. declarations of war</label>
answers.E: <label>E. establishment of a post office</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Though Article II of the U.S. Constitution never enumerates oversight as a congressional power, such oversight is implicit in its power to pass laws and to appropriate funds. Choices (A), (B), (D), and (E) are all enumerated powers in Article II.

content: If no presidential candidate receives a majority of the electoral college vote, then who becomes the president?

answers.A: <label>A. The candidate who wins the popular national vote</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The incumbent vice president of the United States</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Whomever is selected by the United States Supreme Court</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The candidate who wins the majority of votes in the House</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E Amendment XII of the U.S. Constitution states that if no candidate wins the majority of the vote in the electoral college, the top three candidates are presented to the House, and whoever wins a majority becomes president. Choice (A) is incorrect as the popular vote has no official weight. Choices (B) and (D) are incorrect, as they are first and third, respectively, in line of succession if the president dies or is removed from office; their position does not affect the outcome of elections. Choice (C) is incorrect as the U.S. Supreme Court plays no direct role in selecting the president.

content: The No Child Left Behind Act, which established educational standards that states must meet to receive federal educational funding, is an example of which of the following?

answers.A: <label>A. A federal mandate</label>
answers.B: <label>B. A constitutional amendment</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Affirmative action</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Tort reform</label>
answers.E: <label>E. A government-sponsored enterprise</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A No Child Left Behind (NCLB) set requirements for states by the federal government and, therefore, is a federal mandate. Choice (B) is incorrect because NCLB did not change the constitution. Choice (C) is incorrect because affirmative action relates to efforts to remedy the effects of discrimination through admissions or hiring preferences. Choice (D) is incorrect because tort reform refers to proposed changes in the civil justice system. Choice (E) is incorrect because a government-sponsored enterprise is a type of corporation created by the federal government.

content: Unlike in a closed primary election, in an open primary election

answers.A: <label>A. voters select the winner by caucus instead of by individual ballots</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the election results are not binding</label>
answers.C: <label>C. any registered voter may participate, regardless of party affiliation</label>
answers.D: <label>D. voters may register to vote on the day of the election</label>
answers.E: <label>E. voters may vote for more than one candidate</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C In an open primary, any registered voter can participate. For example, in an open Republican primary, Republicans, Democrats, and Independents can vote. However, in a closed Republican primary, only voters who are registered Republicans can vote. Choice (A) is incorrect as a caucus is not a type of primary. Choice (B) is incorrect as results of open primaries are binding. Choice (D) is incorrect because there is no difference in the registration deadlines of closed and open primaries. (Most states do not allow for same-day voter registration.) Choice (E) is incorrect as open primaries allow voters to select only one candidate.

content: Political efficacy refers to the idea that

answers.A: <label>A. political parties can provide a check to the political influence wielded by corporations</label>
answers.B: <label>B. individuals believe that they can influence the government through participation in the democratic process</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the system of checks and balances ensures that the government is both efficient and productive</label>
answers.D: <label>D. politicians have a duty to inform their constituents about the democratic process</label>
answers.E: <label>E. government is most effective when the same party controls all three branches of government</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Political efficacy refers to the idea that private citizens can influence the government by voting and otherwise participating in the political process. Choices (A), (C), and (E) are incorrect because political efficacy refers to private citizens, not parties or branches of government. Choice (D) is incorrect because political efficacy does not assume that politicians must educate voters.

content: An inherent power of the president is the power to

answers.A: <label>A. appoint a nominee for the U.S. Supreme Court</label>
answers.B: <label>B. negotiate a treaty with another country</label>
answers.C: <label>C. declare a state of emergency following a natural disaster</label>
answers.D: <label>D. veto a bill passed by the U.S. Congress</label>
answers.E: <label>E. appoint ambassadors while Congress is in recess</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Article II does not explicitly allow the president to declare a state of emergency. Rather, the power to declare a state of emergency is inferred from Article II, Section 3's "take care" clause: the president "shall take care that the laws be faithfully executed." Article II, Section 2 explicitly gives the president the power to appoint Supreme Court nominees, enter into treaties, and make recess appointments; thus, (A), (B), and (E) are incorrect. Choice (D) is incorrect because the presidential veto power is explicitly mentioned in the Presentment Clause (Article I, Section 7's description of the law-making process).

content: Which of the following is the most accurate statement about writs of certiorari?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A Those who want the Supreme Court to hear their appeal must file a petition for a writ of certiorari with the court. If four justices choose to hear a case, the court will issue a writ of certiorari: the court's official request for the transcript of a lower court case. The Supreme Court rarely grants writs of certiorari; for example, in 2009, the court granted only 1.1% of petitions. Choice (B) is incorrect as the court may grant a writ whenever it has jurisdiction and four justices decide to grant it. In general, if the court denies a petition, the lower court's ruling stands; eliminate (C). Choice (D) is incorrect as any citizen may petition the court. Choice (E) is incorrect as the attorney general would petition the court just as any other individual would.

content: Which of the following statements best characterizes cooperative federalism?

answers.A: <label>A. The executive and legislative branches working on legislation together</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The federal government granting power over a policy area to the states</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Governments working with businesses to address an issue</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Many states working together to address a regional issue</label>
answers.E: <label>E. State and federal governments working on the same issue</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E Cooperative federalism occurs when more than one level of government works together on a policy area. Choices (A), (C), and (D) are incorrect as federalism refers to the relationship between the federal and state governments. Choice (B) is incorrect as it describes "devolution."

content: Which of the following constitutional principles might be violated if the Environmental Protection Agency issued, enforced, and adjudicated all disputes regarding a new regulation?

answers.A: <label>A. Vertical federalism</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Due process of law</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Comity</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Equal protection of the laws</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Separation of powers</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E Separation of powers refers to the division of responsibility among the branches of government: the legislative branch creates laws, the executive branch enforces laws, and the judicial branch interprets laws. If the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), which is an executive branch agency, performed all three functions, it would risk violating the separation of powers. Choice (A) is incorrect as federalism refers to the sharing of powers between levels of government. Choice (B) is incorrect as due process refers to the process required to deprive someone of his or her rights. Choice (C) is incorrect as comity refers to legal reciprocity: the principle that different jurisdictions respect each other's legislative, executive, and judicial actions. Choice (D) is incorrect as equal protection requires that all citizens be treated the same under the law.

content: Which of the following is LEAST likely to explain low voter turnout for an election?

answers.A: <label>A. The preclearance provision of the Voting Rights Act</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Low levels of political efficacy among registered voters</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Regulations that require voters to show identification</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The frequency with which state and local elections occur</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The fact that elections are held on weekdays</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A The preclearance provision of the Voting Rights Act (VRA) requires that jurisdictions with a history of voter disenfranchisement gain approval from the Department of Justice before making any changes to their voting procedures; this has the effect of increasing, not decreasing, voter turnout. In 2013, the Supreme Court's ruling in Shelby County v. Holder put the future of the VRA in doubt. The court struck down Section 4(b) of the VRA, which determines which states are subject to the preclearance requirement. Until Congress revises Section 4(b), no states are subject to the preclearance requirement. Since the preclearance provision, effective or not, would not reduce voter turnout, (A) is the best. Choices (B) is incorrect because "low levels of political efficacy" means voters don't believe they can affect the outcome of an election; therefore, low levels of political efficacy would decrease voter turnout. Because some voters don't have photo identification, laws that require voters to show identification prevent voters from casting their ballots; therefore, (C) should be eliminated. Choice (D) is incorrect because voters are less likely to vote when there are frequent elections. Voters are less likely to participate in weekday elections than in weekend elections since they must take time off work to vote on a weekday; therefore, (E) should be eliminated.

content: A "motion for cloture" is used to

answers.A: <label>A. send a bill back to the House</label>
answers.B: <label>B. override a presidential veto in the House</label>
answers.C: <label>C. amend an appropriations bill in the House</label>
answers.D: <label>D. end a filibuster and force a vote on a bill in the Senate</label>
answers.E: <label>E. block a vote on a presidential appointee in the Senate</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D A senator enacts a "motion for cloture" to end a filibuster and force a vote on a bill. Choices (A), (B), and (C) are incorrect as a motion for cloture occurs only in the Senate. Choice (E) is incorrect as it refers to a potential goal of a filibuster.

content: Which of the following statements about presidential elections since 1972 is most accurate?

answers.A: <label>A. Voters increasingly get their information from newspapers.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Voters have become more focused on individual candidates.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Elections have become dominated by special interest groups.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Voters increasingly vote based on a party's platform.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. No candidate has won a majority of the popular vote.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Since 1972, voters have begun to vote more for the candidate than for the party. Choice (A) is incorrect as newspaper readership is on the decline. Choice (C) is incorrect as special interest groups have long played an important role in elections. Choice (D) is incorrect as this is the opposite of what has occurred. Choice (E) is incorrect as multiple presidents have won the majority of the popular vote.

content: The idea that the Bill of Rights applies to both federal and state governments by means of the Fourteenth Amendment is called

answers.C: <label>C. strict constructionism</label>
answers.D: <label>D. comity</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the doctrine of incorporation</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E The doctrine of incorporation holds that the protections granted by the Bill of Rights apply to both state and federal government actions. Choices (A) and (B) are incorrect as mandamus and habeas corpus are judicial actions called "prerogative writs"; orders issued by one branch of government to another. Choice (C) is incorrect because this refers to the philosophy that the Constitution should be interpreted closely to the intent of the Framers. Choice (D) is incorrect as comity refers to the idea that one court will recognize the decision of a court in a different jurisdiction.

content: Which of the following is the primary purpose of "motor voter" laws?

answers.A: <label>A. To increase turnout on election days</label>
answers.B: <label>B. To make it easier for citizens to register to vote</label>
answers.C: <label>C. To require that all voters know how to drive</label>
answers.D: <label>D. To establish voter identification laws</label>
answers.E: <label>E. To automatically register all licensed drivers to vote</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Motor voter laws allow individuals to register to vote when applying for a driver's license, thus making voter registration easier. Choice (A) is incorrect as "motor voter" laws are not directly related to voter turnout. Choice (C) is incorrect as there is no requirement that voters must drive. Choice (D) is incorrect as voter identification laws are separate from motor voter laws. Choice (E) is incorrect as both non-citizen residents and citizens under 18 can be licensed to drive but not eligible to vote.

content: Why has network news coverage become less diverse in recent years?

answers.A: <label>A. Decreasing liberal bias in the news media</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Increasing visibility for individual candidates on TV</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Increasing concentration of ownership in the news media</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Decreasing cost of political ads on TV</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Decreasing cost of newspapers</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Choice (C) is the best answer because less diversity of media ownership leads directly to less diversity of news coverage. For example, a newspaper, radio station, and television channel may choose to cover three different events or provide three different perspectives on an issue. However, if they share the same owner, they're more likely to cover the same events and express the same ideas. The cost of political ads on TV is increasing, as is the cost of newspapers, so you can eliminate (D) and (E) right away. An increased presence of individual candidates giving individual viewpoints contributes to diversity in news coverage, so eliminate (B) too. Choice (A) is controversialâ€”conservative media critics tend to see increasing liberal bias in news media, because most reporters hold liberal views. However, liberal critics point to the ownership of media outlets by large corporations and see a resulting conservative bias. Therefore, (A) is not the best choice and you can eliminate it.

content: Which of the following is true of appellate courts?

answers.B: <label>B. Appellate trials are usually jury trials.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Appellate judges usually decide the facts of a case.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. About 90 percent of appellate cases involve criminal law.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Appellate judges review decisions of lower courts.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E The use of the word "never" in (A) is too strong and should make you very suspicious of that choice. Appellate judges usually try to keep their decisions consistent with the decisions of past judges, a principle known as stare decisis, so eliminate (A). Appellate trials are decided by judges, not juries, and the judges decide issues of law, not the facts of the case, so (B) and (C) can go. While appellate cases are split between criminal law and civil law, the split is not as lopsided as 90%/10%, so cross out (D). You should be left with (E), the correct answer, since a party who wants to appeal the decision of a lower court can bring the case to a higher appellate court.

content: The preceding table most clearly shows a large difference of opinion based on

answers.A: <label>A. gender</label>
answers.B: <label>B. region</label>
answers.C: <label>C. age</label>
answers.D: <label>D. income</label>
answers.E: <label>E. race</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B The chart measures opinions on support for congressional gun control measures as broken down by gender and region, so get rid of (C), (D), and (E). There isn't much gender difference within the regions: men's and women's results are within 1â€“2% of each other. The chart shows large differences among the regions (high support for gun control in the Northeast and West, low support in the Midwest and South), so go with choice (B).

content: Which of the following has the Supreme Court held about the death penalty?

answers.A: <label>A. The death penalty may only be imposed upon citizens.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Under some circumstances, the death penalty may not violate the Eighth Amendment.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Under some circumstances, the death penalty may violate the Third Amendment.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. States may execute any adult regardless of intellectual disability.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The death penalty may only be imposed upon men.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B The Supreme Court has held that while the death penalty might constitute "cruel and unusual punishment" under some circumstances and thus violate the Eighth Amendment, in many cases it does not. Choices (A) and (E) are incorrect as the Supreme Court has held that noncitizens and women may be executed. Choice (C) is incorrect as the Third Amendment has to do with billeting troops and thus has nothing to do with the death penalty. Choice (D) is incorrect as the Supreme Court has held that the intellectually disabled may not be executed.

content: Which of the following is an example of devolution?

answers.A: <label>A. Allowing states to decide how to meet federally mandated greenhouse gas emissions targets</label>
answers.B: <label>B. A "race to the bottom" in which states compete with one another to have the fewest environmental regulations</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A state that legalizes marijuana possession in conflict with federal law</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A state being prevented from implementing a fuel efficiency standard that is more stringent than that set by the federal government</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The federal government establishing a requirement that a state increase its drinking age to 21 in order to receive federal highway funding</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A Devolution is the process by which the federal government allows states to make decisions that would otherwise be made at the federal level. Choice (B) is incorrect as it does not deal with a transfer of power. Choices (C) and (D) are incorrect because they deal with states attempting to act in conflict with federal law. Choice (E) is incorrect as the federal government is imposing a requirement upon the state by means of its Article I spending power.

content: An example of a categorical grant would be

answers.A: <label>A. money loaned by the federal government to cities to fund school maintenance</label>
answers.B: <label>B. money given by the federal government to states without conditions</label>
answers.C: <label>C. money loaned by the federal government to a private company to prevent it from failing</label>
answers.D: <label>D. money given by the federal government to states to fund Head Start early education programs</label>
answers.E: <label>E. tax deductions given by the federal government to private citizens who buy fuel-efficient automobiles</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Categorical grants are grants given by the federal government that can be spent for specific purposes only. Choices (A) and (C) are incorrect because they describe loans instead of grants. Choice (B) is incorrect because it describes block grants. Choice (E) is incorrect because a tax deduction is not a grant.

content: The Voting Rights Act of 1965 has had which of the following effects?

answers.A: <label>A. States have been prohibited from establishing voter identification requirements.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Voters must now pass literacy tests before voting.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Voting participation for racial minority voters has increased.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The voting age was lowered from 21 to 18.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The Voting Rights Act removed restrictions that had prevented access to voting for many African Americans and other racial minorities. Choice (A) is incorrect as many states still have identification requirements. Choice (B) is incorrect as the Voting Rights Act actually prohibited literacy tests. Choice (D) is incorrect as the voting age was changed by the Twenty-sixth Amendment. Choice (E) is incorrect as Plessy v. Ferguson was overturned by Brown v. Board of Education.

content: Which of the following has been true of the Republican Party since the 1980s?

answers.A: <label>A. It has become aligned with civil libertarians.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It has come to be dominated by labor unions.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It has become more antagonistic to business interests.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Its membership has come to include environmental activists.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. It has become more influenced by evangelical Christians.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E Since the 1980s, evangelical Christians have exerted more and more influence upon the positions of the Republican Party. Choice (A) is incorrect as civil libertarians are not necessarily associated with the Republicans more than Democrats. Choices (B) and (D) are incorrect as labor unions and environmental activists are more associated with the Democratic Party. Choice (C) is incorrect as the Republican Party is generally considered more sympathetic to business interests.

content: Legislative oversight occurs when

answers.A: <label>A. congressional committees investigate and evaluate the performance of executive agencies and departments</label>
answers.B: <label>B. a court is unwilling to break with precedent to overturn legislative acts</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the Supreme Court declares laws or executive actions unconstitutional</label>
answers.D: <label>D. an amendment to a bill is proposed that softens more objectionable elements of the bill</label>
answers.E: <label>E. a bill passes both the Senate and the House of Representatives with at least a two-thirds majority</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A One of Congress's most important tasks, legislative oversight is used as a way of checking the power of the executive branch by having congressional committees investigate and evaluate the performance of executive agencies and departments. Choice (B) is incorrect as it describes the process of judicial restraint. Choice (C) is incorrect as it outlines the process of judicial review. Choice (D) is incorrect as it describes the function of a saving amendment. Choice (E) is incorrect because it doesn't relate the legislative branch to the executive branch in any way.

content: The table above supports which of the following statements about independent voters during presidential elections?

answers.A: <label>A. Independent voters are more likely to support the incumbent when the incumbent is a Democrat.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Until 2000, the independent vote generally aligned with the popular vote.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The unpredictability of the independent voters is why politicians do not try to attract independent voters.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Republicans have won a plurality of independent votes whenever there was a viable third-party candidate.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The Republican Party would earn more votes if there were not independent voters.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B The data in the tables show that the winner of the popular vote won a plurality (more than any other candidate) among independent voters from 1980 to 1996: the Republican candidates won the popular vote and a plurality of independent voters in 1980, 1984, and 1988; the Democratic candidate won the popular vote and a plurality of independent voters in 1992 and 1996. Then in 2000, correlation ends. The Democratic candidates won the popular vote in 2000, 2008, and 2012; however, a plurality of independent voters supported the Republican candidates in 2000 and 2012. In 2004, the Republican candidate won the popular vote in 2004, but a plurality of independents supported the Democratic candidate.
