Choice (A) is incorrect because incumbents ran in six of these nine elections: Democrats were incumbents in 1980, 1996, and 2012, but a plurality of independents supported them only in 1996; Republicans were incumbents in 1984, 1992, 2004, but a plurality of independents supported them only in 1984. Choice (D) is incorrect because third-party candidates won more than 5% of the popular vote in 1980, 1992, and 1996, and the Democratic candidates won a plurality of independent votes in two of those elections: 1992 and 1996. Choices (C) and (E) are incorrect because there are no data in the table to support them.

content: The origination clause of the Constitution states that

answers.A: <label>A. the Bill of Rights must not be infringed upon by any state legislature</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Congress and the president must jointly create the annual federal budget</label>
answers.C: <label>C. revenue bills must be initiated in the House of Representatives</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the Supreme Court has original jurisdiction over all constitutional matters</label>
answers.E: <label>E. international treaties are to be written by the president</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The origination clause is found in Article I, Section 7 of the Constitution and states that all bills for raising revenue shall originate in the House of Representatives. Choice (A) can be eliminated because it refers to the incorporation doctrine. The president sets a budget request as required by the Budget and Accounting Act of 1921, and Congress then passes appropriations bills for the spending of money in the approved budget; therefore, eliminate (B). Article II, Section 2 gives the Supreme Court original jurisdiction over cases affecting ambassadors, other public ministers and consuls, and those in which a state shall be party; therefore, you may eliminate (D). Choice (E) is incorrect because the treaty clause in Article II, Section 2 grants the president the power to make treaties.

content: How many votes in the Senate must a presidential nominee to the Supreme Court receive in order to be confirmed?

answers.A: <label>A. Forty percent</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Fifty-one percent</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Fifty-five percent</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Sixty percent</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Seventy-five percent</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B A nominee must be confirmed by a simple majority (51%) in order to be confirmed. Forty percent is insufficient to confirm a nominee, so eliminate (A). Choices (C) and (E) are incorrect because they are more than what is necessary to confirm a nominee. Choice (D) is incorrect because it describes the super majority (three-fifths) that must be obtained in order to end a filibuster.

content: Federal judges are subject to which of the following disciplinary actions?

answers.A: <label>A. Impeachment, conviction, and removal from office by Congress</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Removal from office by the appointing president</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Removal from office by the president-elect</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Recall elections by citizens residing in the district over which the judge has jurisdiction</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Establishment of an arbitrary term limit</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A Article II, Section 4 of the Constitution states that federal judges can be removed from office on impeachment for, and conviction of, treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors. Judges cannot be removed by presidents, are neither elected nor recalled by citizens, and aren't subject to imposition of an arbitrary term limit. Accordingly, eliminate all choices except (A).

content: Which of the following statements about interest groups is accurate?

answers.A: <label>A. They don't use campaign funding as a tactic to win favor with legislators.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. They are more successful when their members all belong to the same political party.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. They rarely cover issues that appeal to residents of more than one state.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. They focus most of their lobbying efforts on state legislators.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. They generally are not focused on appealing to a broad group of people.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E Interest groups are organizations of people who share a common interest and want to promote that interest among government officials. Their cause is generally very narrow in nature, although people across many states could share that common interest, so select (E) and eliminate (C). Many large, highly successful interest groups have many members from different political affiliations and lobby federal lawmakers as much as or more than state lawmakers; therefore, you may eliminate (B) and (D). Finally, funding for contributions, advertisements, research, etc., is an important part of becoming a successful interest group, so eliminate (A).

content: Which of the following statements is true regarding delegates to presidential nomination conventions?

answers.A: <label>A. Delegates are generally more likely to register as third party voters at some point.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The majority of the general population is more educated than the delegates.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Delegates typically have little interest in politics.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Typically, the general population is less ideological than the delegates.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Usually, the general population is wealthier than the delegates.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Delegates to presidential nomination conventions are more ideological than the general population; therefore, (D) is the best. Eliminate (A), (B), (C), and (E) because they all state the opposite of what is true.

content: What power was granted to the states by the Articles of Confederation but not by the Constitution?

answers.A: <label>A. Coining money</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Authorizing constitutional amendments</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Having representation in Congress</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Appealing to the president to adjudicate disputes</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Levying taxes</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A Although the Articles of Confederation gave both the federal government and the states the power to coin money, Article I, Section 8 of the Constitution reserves that power for the federal government alone. Choice (B) is incorrect because the Articles of Confederation and the Constitution each gave the states the power of amendment. States still have representation in Congress, although in different numbers than outlined in the Articles of Confederation, so eliminate (C). The president has never been an adjudicator of disputes among states. Congress had that role under the Articles of Confederation and the Supreme Court has it now; therefore, you may eliminate (D). Finally, states have the power to levy taxes under both the Articles of Confederation and the Constitution, so eliminate (E).

content: Which of the following categories of spending are paid without an appropriations bill?

answers.A: <label>A. Department of Education special acts and authorizations</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Justice department budgets</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Federal budget entitlements</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Department of Defense funding</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Housing and Urban development assistance</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Federal budget entitlements are automatically paid to any qualified person. Congress does not need to pass an appropriations bill as it does for spending by all other agencies or programs listed. After the annual budget is set, appropriations committees approve bills to actually spend the money outlined in the budget. Entitlements, such as Medicare or Social Security, are not part of this extra approval process.

content: According to Brown v. Board of Education (1954), which of the following amendments was violated by the "separate but equal" doctrine that had been established in Plessy v. Ferguson (1896)?

answers.A: <label>A. First Amendment</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Sixth Amendment</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Ninth Amendment</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Thirteenth Amendment</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Fourteenth Amendment</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E The Fourteenth Amendment includes the equal protection clause, which states that no person within a single jurisdiction shall be denied equal protection of the laws in that jurisdiction. Brown v. Board of Education found that separate educational facilities were inherently unequal. None of the other amendments contain the equal protection clause, so all other choices can be eliminated.

content: Which of the following best predicts how someone will vote in an election?

answers.A: <label>A. The voter's gender</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The voter's political party affiliation</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The voter's socioeconomic status</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The voter's religion</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Where the voter lives</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B A voter's political party affiliation is the best predictor of which candidate an individual will vote for. Some correlation can be found between a voter's choice and his or her gender, socioeconomic status, religion, and geography, but far stronger correlations can be found for Democrats voting for Democratic candidates and Republicans voting for Republican candidates.

content: All of the following can be inferred from the table above EXCEPT:

answers.A: <label>A. Men who have attained a vocational degree are more likely to identify as Republicans than are those with only a high school diploma.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Men who have attained a doctoral degree are more likely to identify as Democrats than are those with only a college degree.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Women who have completed grade school and men who have attained a high school diploma are equally likely to identify as Republicans.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Men who have attained a Master's degree are less likely to identify as Republicans than they are to identify as Democrats.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Women who have attained a vocational degree are more likely to identify as Republicans than are men who have attained a vocational degree.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Choice (B) is a false statement: 64% of men with a college degree identify as Democrats, while only 34% of men with a doctoral degree do. Therefore, men with a doctoral degree are less likely to identify as Democrats, making (B) the credited response to this EXCEPT question. The other choices can be eliminated because they are true statements. Choice (A) is a true statement: 24% of men with a vocational degree identify as Republican, compared with 13% of men with a high school diploma. Choice (C) is a true statement: 13% of women who completed grade school identify as Republican, just as 13% of men with high school degrees do. Choice (D) is a true statement: 49% of men with a Master's degree identify as Republican, compared with 51% who identify as Democrats. Choice (E) is a true statement: 28% of women with vocational degrees identify as Republican, compared with 24% of men with vocational degrees.

content: Which of the following would occur if Congress were to pass legislation and declare a recess, and the president took no action on the bill within ten days of its passage?

answers.A: <label>A. A line-item veto</label>
answers.B: <label>B. A pocket veto</label>
answers.C: <label>C. An adjournment</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Senatorial courtesy</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B The question accurately defines a pocket veto. A line-item veto occurs when the president vetoes only certain parts of a bill before signing it, so eliminate (A). (In 1998, the Supreme Court ruled that the presidential line-item veto is unconstitutional.) Adjournment is the term for taking a recess, so eliminate (C). A writ of certiorari is issued when the Supreme Court agrees to hear a case; eliminate (D). Senatorial courtesy occurs when the president consults a senator on nominations to be made for positions within that senator's state; eliminate (E).

content: Which of the following is not a special position held by a member of Congress?

answers.B: <label>B. Speaker of the House</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Congressional Management Foundation Chair</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Minority Whip</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Democratic Caucus Chairman</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The Congressional Management Foundation is a nonpartisan, nonprofit organization that works with members of Congress, but is not part of Congress and not run by members of Congress. The president pro tempore is the most senior member of the Senate and the speaker of the House is elected by the majority in the House of Representatives; therefore, eliminate (A) and (B). Both the House and the Senate have a minority whip and a Democratic (and Republican) Caucus Chairman, so eliminate (D) and (E).

content: Interest groups are barred from taking part in which of the following activities?

answers.A: <label>A. Sending lawmakers to educational seminars</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Giving tangible gifts to lawmakers</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Providing research to government officials</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Staging protests and boycotts</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Filing lawsuits in federal courts</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Lawmakers and other government officials are prohibited from accepting outright gifts from lobbyists and others who might have a political agenda. Sometimes educational trips may be construed as gifts, but that line is not black and white, so (A) is incorrect. Choices (C), (D), and (E) all describe activities that comprise a large portion of what interest groups have done in the past and do now, in addition to lobbying. Accordingly, they can all be eliminated.

content: A provision in the Constitution that has been used to expand federal power over the states is

answers.A: <label>A. the police power</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the reserved power clause</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment</label>
answers.D: <label>D. establishment of republican governments by the states</label>
answers.E: <label>E. separation of powers</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Identification and analysis

Choice A refers to a reserved power of the states. Choice B refers to the Tenth Amendment and gives states powers such as education, health, and safety. Choice C, the correct answer, established that the states could not make laws that violate the rights of individuals living in those states. It also incorporated the Bill of Rights into the states. Choice D establishes state governments. Choice E refers to checks and balances.

content: Which of the following statements best describes the consequences of elite class theory?

answers.A: <label>A. It encourages the formation of third political parties.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Competing special interests can unduly influence the legislative process.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A centrist philosophy would emerge resulting in gridlock.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The elite in society would play a dominant role in the political process.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The elite would clash with the middle class resulting in class warfare.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Definitional

Choice D, the correct answer, is the definition of elite class theory. Choice A is a consequence of factions. Choice B is the definition of hyperpluralism. Choice C refers to pluralism and then gives an incorrect consequence of it. Choice E may take place, but is not necessarily a consequence of the elite playing a dominant role in the political process.

content: The exclusionary rule established by the Supreme Court supported the position that

answers.A: <label>A. policemen must knock before they enter a house with a search warrant</label>
answers.B: <label>B. stop and frisk actions by police could be used only if there was probable cause</label>
answers.C: <label>C. witnesses to a crime may testify for a trial on videotape rather than in person</label>
answers.D: <label>D. evidence obtained that goes beyond the stated purpose of a search warrant may not be used in court</label>
answers.E: <label>E. a suspect may withhold information from the police when a lawyer is not present during interrogation</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Definitional

Choice D, the correct answer, is the definition of exclusionary rule. Choices A and B echo Supreme Court rulings. Choice C is factually correct, but has nothing to do with the exclusionary rule, and choice E is an incorrect statement as a result of the Miranda ruling.

content: Which of the following describes a consequence of the 2010 Citizens United v FEC Supreme Court ruling that dealt with campaign finance laws?

answers.A: <label>A. Corporate soft money donations to political parties is banned.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Corporate hard money donations to political candidates is banned.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Corporations do not have to disclose political donations.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Corporation funding of independent political advertisements is protected by the First Amendment.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Unions were allowed to collect dues from their members for the purpose of political action.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Identification and analysis

Choice D correctly identifies the finding of the U.S. Supreme Court in the Citizens United v FEC (2010) case. Corporations prior to this decision were prohibited from using money to make independent political advertisements. Choices A and B are incorrect because corporations are allowed to give soft money to political parties and hard money through their political action committees to candidates. Choice E is incorrect because the Citizens United case did not hand down an opinion regarding unions' ability to collect dues from their members for the purpose of political action, which they are permitted to do.

content: A major area that is affected by congressional oversight hearings is the

answers.A: <label>A. structure of congressional committees</label>
answers.B: <label>B. ability of the president to recommend legislation to Congress</label>
answers.C: <label>C. reduction of the number of cases heard by the Supreme Court</label>
answers.D: <label>D. creation of new special interest groups</label>
answers.E: <label>E. review of the budgets of independent regulatory agencies</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Type of Question: Cause-and-effect relationships

Choice E, the correct answer, is one function of congressional oversight. Another one is to review aspects of laws passed by Congress related to specific governmental agencies or departments. Choice A is wrong because the majority party has the power to review the structure of congressional committees. Choice B is incorrect because the president can recommend legislation independently of congressional oversight. Choices C and D are incorrect statements related to the question raised.

content: The primary function of a lobbyist is to

answers.A: <label>A. find political candidates for special interest groups</label>
answers.B: <label>B. provide information to members of Congress that is favorable to a position taken by a special interest group</label>
answers.C: <label>C. poll the public to help determine a position that a special interest group should take</label>
answers.D: <label>D. raise money for political action committees</label>
answers.E: <label>E. increase the awareness of special interest groups to the electorate</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Definitional

Choice B is the correct answer. Special interest groups hire lobbyists for the purpose of influencing legislation favorable to that group. For instance, the National Rifle Association (NRA) will hire lobbyists to provide information to congressmen that will encourage them to vote against gun control legislation. Choice A is incorrect because political parties, not lobbyists, find candidates to run for office. Choice C is incorrect because special interest groups hire pollsters to determine public opinion. Choice D is incorrect because special interest groups contribute money to political action committees or have those of their own. Choice E is incorrect because lobbyists work behind the scenes and do not attempt to influence the electorate at large.

content: In viewing the relationship between the president and Congress in the area of foreign policy, which action on the part of Congress attempted to reduce presidential authority?

answers.A: <label>A. Congressional Impoundment Act</label>
answers.B: <label>B. War Powers Act</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Gulf of Tonkin Resolution</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Approval of the SALT agreement</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Approval of NAFTA</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Cause-and-effect relationships

Choice B, the correct answer, was a direct result of the president's escalation of the Vietnam War. Choice C was the action by Congress that gave President Johnson the green light to send more troops to Vietnam. Choice A refers to a budgetary action and domestic policy and does decrease presidential authority in that area. Choice D refers to Strategic Arms Limitation Talks, and choice E refers to the North American Free Trade Agreement, both treaties the Senate had to approve.

content: One way Congress can respond to a Supreme Court ruling that declares a law unconstitutional is to

answers.A: <label>A. appoint new justices</label>
answers.B: <label>B. draft a referendum that the voters would approve</label>
answers.C: <label>C. pass new legislation that addresses the issues raised by the Court</label>
answers.D: <label>D. pass a law limiting the terms of the justices</label>
answers.E: <label>E. reargue the case in a state court</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Cause-and-effect relationships

Choice C, the correct answer, is the only manner, other than a constitutional amendment, Congress can act on a ruling by the Supreme Court that declares a law unconstitutional. Choice A is wrong because the Senate approves new justices only when there is an opening on the Court. Choice B is an incorrect statement. Choice D requires a constitutional amendment. Choice E is an incorrect statement.

content: In attempting to gain public support for his agenda, the president uses all of the following techniques EXCEPT

answers.A: <label>A. using the bully pulpit</label>
answers.B: <label>B. giving the media a photo op</label>
answers.C: <label>C. providing sound bites</label>
answers.D: <label>D. holding a press conference</label>
answers.E: <label>E. holding a private meeting with the joint chiefs of staff</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Type of Question: Negative

Choice E is the only incorrect choice because a meeting of the joint chiefs of staff, the heads of the military, is usually behind closed doors and would have a negligible impact on influencing public support compared to the other choices.

content: A Supreme Court that creates precedent is described as one that relies on

answers.A: <label>A. unanimous court decisions</label>
answers.B: <label>B. judicial federalism</label>
answers.C: <label>C. judicial restraint</label>
answers.D: <label>D. judicial activism</label>
answers.E: <label>E. stare decisis</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Definitional

Choice D, the correct answer, requires that you understand the definition of judicial activism. The other choices are incorrect because by definition they refer to aspects of the Supreme Court that do not support what the question is asking. (Refer to glossary for definitions of each of the terms.)

content:
The powers not delegated to the United States by the Constitution, nor prohibited by it to the states, are reserved to the states respectively, or the people.

After the 1994 midterm election, which of the following laws was passed by the Republican Congress to achieve the objective of this amendment?

answers.A: <label>A. Block grants for welfare</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Funded mandates</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Judicial authority to appoint federal judges</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Power to reject regulatory agency directives</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The go-ahead to make individual treaties with foreign countries</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Type of Question: Stimulus-based short quotation

In both questions you must recognize that the quote is from the Tenth Amendment to the Constitutionâ€”commonly referred to as the reserved power clause. The clause defines federalism and explains where states get their powers. Once you have determined this, you can see that in question 11, choice A would be the correct choice because block grants give funds for the states to spend without federal strings attached. In Question 12, choice C, the correct answer, relates to the principle of federalism, the division of powers between the federal government and state governments.

content:
The powers not delegated to the United States by the Constitution, nor prohibited by it to the states, are reserved to the states respectively, or the people.

Which principle of government is derived from this amendment?

answers.A: <label>A. Separation of powers</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Checks and balances</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Federalism</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Pluralism</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Republicanism</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Stimulus-based short quotation

In both questions you must recognize that the quote is from the Tenth Amendment to the Constitutionâ€”commonly referred to as the reserved power clause. The clause defines federalism and explains where states get their powers. Once you have determined this, you can see that in question 11, choice A would be the correct choice because block grants give funds for the states to spend without federal strings attached. In Question 12, choice C, the correct answer, relates to the principle of federalism, the division of powers between the federal government and state governments.

content: Whips have which of the following functions?

answers.A: <label>A. They act as direct liaisons to the White House.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. They work closely with the minority party in the name of bipartisanship.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. They make appointments to the various House and Senate committees.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. They are responsible for keeping party members in line when a vote occurs.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. They preside over the House when the speaker is absent.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Definitional

Choice D, the correct answer, is one of the jobs whips have. Choices A, B, C, and E are incorrect statements. A whip may sometimes preside over a House session, but it is not a function of the job.

content: Which of the following is a major cause of the inability of Congress to pass legislation?

answers.A: <label>A. The number of bills proposed by the president</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Lobbyists influencing Congress</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Divided party control of the Congress</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The increased number of southern Republicans elected to Congress</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The change in the party identification of voters</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Cause-and-effect relationships

Choice C, the correct answer, is a primary reason that Congress does not pass legislation. Even though lobbyists may influence legislation (choice B) in a negative way, they are not singularly responsible for gridlock. The other choices are incorrect in relation to the question.

content: Sunshine laws were passed in order to give

answers.A: <label>A. Congress greater flexibility in determining meeting times</label>
answers.B: <label>B. C-SPAN the ability to televise congressional sessions</label>
answers.C: <label>C. citizens the ability to get information from law enforcement agencies</label>
answers.D: <label>D. citizens the ability to attend meetings that previously were held in secret session</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the press the right to get information from citizens</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Definitional

Choice D, the correct answer, is an application of the definition of sunshine laws. These laws were passed to stop the practice of legislative bodies meeting in secret executive sessions late at night. Along with the Freedom of Information Act, both laws gave citizens more rights in obtaining information from the government.

content: Which of the following is a characteristic of the electoral college?

answers.A: <label>A. It mandates presidential electors to vote for the candidate they are pledged to.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It establishes a power base for third-party candidates.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It has resulted in frequent occasions when a president wins the electoral vote but not the popular vote.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It became part of the Constitution to give more power to the voters.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. It gives the House of Representatives the power to determine who will be president if no candidate gets a majority of the electoral votes.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Type of Question: Identification and analysis

Choice E, the correct answer, gives the circumstances when the House of Representatives is mandated by the Constitution to select a president if a majority is not reached in the electoral college. Choice A is incorrect because presidential electors are only morally obligated to vote for the candidate the elector supported. Choices B, C, and D are incorrect statements about the nature of the electoral college.

content: Standing House committees such as the Ways and Means Committee are important because they

answers.A: <label>A. do not engage in partisan behavior</label>
answers.B: <label>B. mark up bills before they go to the entire House for debate</label>
answers.C: <label>C. can act independently from established House rules</label>
answers.D: <label>D. receive conference committee reports</label>
answers.E: <label>E. are equally divided in membership between Democrats and Republicans</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Definitional

Choice B, the correct answer, explains a function of a standing committee in the House of Representatives. The question is made even easier because it gives an example of a standing committee. Choices A and C are easy to eliminate as incorrect answers. Choice D may be true in rare instances, but it does not describe the primary importance of standing committees. Choice E is incorrect because standing committees are divided proportionally between Democrats and Republicans based on the majority/minority split in the House.

content: The Constitution provides that one-third of the Senate's membership is up for election every two years so that

answers.A: <label>A. House members may decide whether to run for the Senate</label>
answers.B: <label>B. committee assignments can be alternated between Democrats and Republicans</label>
answers.C: <label>C. voters have less of a chance to change control of the Senate from one party to another</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the entire House and entire Senate are not elected in the same year</label>
answers.E: <label>E. congressional apportionment can alter the size of House districts</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Cause-and-effect relationships

Choice D, the correct answer, is the most obvious reason that the entire Senate is not elected in six-year cycles. A direct result could be a dramatic upheaval of both houses under certain circumstances. Choices A, B, and C are incorrect statements based on fact or circumstance. Choice E is incorrect because apportionment does not relate to the Senate.

content: Which of the following groups voted most heavily Republican during the first decade of the twenty-first century?

answers.A: <label>A. Jews</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Evangelical Christians</label>
answers.C: <label>C. African-Americans</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Asian-Americans</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Labor union members</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Chronological

Choice B, the correct answer, is an important Republican constituency. The other choices are all traditional Democratic constituents.

content: Proponents of the Second Amendment were most upset when Congress passed

answers.A: <label>A. the Civil Rights Act of 1990</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1992</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the Unfunded Mandates Act of 1994</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the Line Item Veto Act of 1994</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the Brady Bill of 1992</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Type of Question: Cause-and-effect relationships

Choice E, the correct answer, is the only law that deals with the right to bear arms. The Brady Bill mandated a waiting period before an individual could purchase a gun. The NRA and other gun proponents were against the bill.

content: Procedural due process can best be found in

answers.A: <label>A. the First Amendment</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the Second Amendment</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the Fifth Amendment</label>
answers.D: <label>D. plea bargaining agreements</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the use of cameras in the courtroom</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Definitional

Choice C, the correct answer, is a constitutional example of procedural due process. The Fifth Amendment provides a road map for due process, including the right to life, liberty, and property. Plea bargaining, choice D, is incorrect because it is not a guaranteed right. The other choices do not have direct procedural guarantees even though through application or court challenge due process questions may arise.

content:
Question below is based on the following headline.

Green Party Candidate Ralph Nader Runs for President

Some people say we should have a third major political party in the country in addition to the Democrats and Republicans.

Which of the following reflects the best explanation for the headline?

answers.A: <label>A. The Democratic and Republican parties have outlasted their effectiveness.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The media's coverage of the parties has soured the voters.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Voters don't seem to detect major differences between the Democrats and Republicans.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Third political parties will have a better chance to elect their candidates.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Voter registration has been on the decline.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Stimulus-based short narrative passage

Choice C, the correct answer, reflects voter discontent with the major political parties and the reason why Ralph Nader decided to run for president in 2000. Choice A is incorrect because there is still a viable two-party system. Choice B may be true but does not directly relate to the poll results. Choice D is an inaccurate conclusion, and choice E is wrong as a result of the Motor Voter Act.

content: What is the result of a continuing resolution agreed upon by both houses of Congress?

answers.A: <label>A. It authorizes the president to borrow money in advance of an approved budget.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It allows a president to send troops abroad on a temporary basis.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It prevents the shutdown of any governmental operation if a new budget is not enacted.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It directs the Congress to meet until a budget is voted on.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. It creates a new legislative agenda.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Definitional

Choice C, the correct answer, is the basic result of what happens when a continuing resolution is adopted. Choice A represents an illegal action on the part of the president. Choices B, D, and E are factually incorrect.

content: The trend of states joining in regional presidential primaries suggests that the states want to

answers.A: <label>A. lessen the cost of the presidential campaigns</label>
answers.B: <label>B. have greater influence in the outcome of the nominating process</label>
answers.C: <label>C. lessen the importance of the New Hampshire primary</label>
answers.D: <label>D. decrease the electorate's influence on the outcome</label>
answers.E: <label>E. diminish the coverage by the media</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Sequencing a series of events

Choice B, the correct answer, reflects the impact of regional primaries such as Super Tuesday. A new regional primary started in 1994, when New England states joined together in what became known as Junior Tuesday, in order to have more of an impact on the process.

content: Which of the following reflects how the news media covers campaigns?

answers.A: <label>A. The media covers the candidates' positions in an in-depth manner.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The media is obligated to give equal coverage to all candidates running for office.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The media's main objective is to change public opinion through its coverage.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The media's coverage is characterized by candidates' sound bites and photo ops.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The media has shied away from looking at the personal lives of the candidates running for office.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Generalization

Choice D, the correct answer, requires that you understand the definitions of sound bites and photo ops. Choices A, B, and E are factually incorrect. And choice C is deceptive because, although public opinion may change through the media's coverage, that answer does not reflect the purpose of the news media's coverage of campaigns.

content: In choosing members of the cabinet, the president usually seeks out people who

answers.A: <label>A. exclusively come from his own political party</label>
answers.B: <label>B. are primarily from the business community</label>
answers.C: <label>C. will remain loyal to the president</label>
answers.D: <label>D. are current government officials</label>
answers.E: <label>E. are former government officials</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Generalization

Choice C, the correct answer, has become the main criterion related to how and why cabinet appointments are made. Choice A is incorrect because of the use of the word exclusively. Choices B and E are incorrect because, although the statements have a degree of factual accuracy, they do not reflect the main criterion. Choice D is factually incorrect because most cabinet members come from the upper levels of the socioeconomic life.

content: Which of the following is true about senatorial courtesy?

answers.A: <label>A. Senators have final say regarding presidential judicial appointments.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Senators of the state from which the candidate comes are consulted by the president prior to the candidate's appointment as a federal judge.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Senators rely on the expertise of their fellow senators before approving judicial appointments.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Senators consult with the American Bar Association before voting on judicial appointments.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Senators poll their constituents before deciding on whether to accept a presidential appointment.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Definitional

Choice B, the correct answer, is the primary result of senatorial courtesy. Even though choices A, C, D, and E are factually correct, they do not relate to the concept of senatorial courtesy.

content: All of the following are considered delegated constitutional jobs of the president EXCEPT

answers.A: <label>A. commander in chief of the armed forces</label>
answers.B: <label>B. chief of state</label>
answers.C: <label>C. making appointments of ambassadors</label>
answers.D: <label>D. head of their political party</label>
answers.E: <label>E. signing treaties with foreign countries</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Negative

Choice D is the incorrect answer because it is an assumed duty that is not part of the written Constitution. Choices A, B, C, and E are all constitutionally delegated powers or jobs of the president.

content:
Question below is based on this graph:

The graph supports which of the following conclusions?

answers.A: <label>A. The poverty rate has increased from 1965 to 2011.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The number of people in poverty has increased from 1965 to 2011.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. There is no correlation between the percentage of people in poverty and the poverty rate.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. When the poverty rate increases, the percentage of people in poverty decreases.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The poverty rate and percentage of people in poverty increase immediately following a recession.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Type of Question: Stimulus-based

Choice E is the correct answer because, in evaluating this graph, you should be able to see an increase in the poverty rate and the number of people in poverty after recessions. Choices Aâ€“D are incorrect interpretations of the graph.

content: The Founding Fathers relied on which principle developed by Enlightenment thinkers?

answers.A: <label>A. Habeas corpus</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Guarantees of life, liberty, and property</label>
answers.C: <label>C. One man, one vote</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The right to bear arms</label>
answers.E: <label>E. A single-house legislature</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Sequencing a series of events

Choice B, the correct answer, comes directly from John Locke's writings and was changed in the Declaration of Independence to "life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness." The other choices are all part of our constitutional foundations but do not derive from the Enlightenment thinkers.

content: Which of the following conclusions did Madison reach in Federalist No. 39 regarding the issue of state sovereignty in the Federal system?

answers.A: <label>A. The government should be a confederacy of sovereign states.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The federal government should rely on the wisdom of the states more than the states should depend on the federal government.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The states should not be able to be taxed by the federal government.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A government should be developed where states retain important governing abilities but are subordinate to the federal government in other areas.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The states should have delegated powers reserved to them.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Sequencing a series of events/generalization

Choice D, the correct answer, is a basic principle of the Federalist Papers. Choices A, B, and C reflect Anti-Federalist thinking. Choice E is factually incorrect.

content: Which of the following is an example of the Supreme Court accepting a case based on original jurisdiction?

answers.A: <label>A. An appeal by a state regarding the decision of a lower court to overturn the state's restrictive abortion law</label>
answers.B: <label>B. A habeas corpus petition from a convict who is on death row</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A suit on the part of a citizen who believes his First Amendment rights are being violated</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A dispute between environmentalists and land developers regarding the constitutionality of the Endangered Species Act</label>
answers.E: <label>E. A dispute between New York and New Jersey over the plans of New York to build a hotel on Ellis Island</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Type of Question: Definitional

Choice E, the correct answer, is an example of how original jurisdiction, which is defined constitutionally, works. Choices Aâ€“D are all examples of appellate jurisdiction.

content: A major difference between the Iowa caucus and the New Hampshire primary is

answers.A: <label>A. greater turnout of voters in the Iowa caucus</label>
answers.B: <label>B. more loyal party regulars vote in New Hampshire</label>
answers.C: <label>C. exit polls are more accurate in caucus votes</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the fact that candidates must spend more money on caucus votes</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the fact that New Hampshire voters use a secret ballot to vote</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Type of Question: Definitional/sequencing a series of events

Choice E is the correct answer because the New Hampshire primary uses a secret ballot while the Iowa caucus is an open vote.

content: Which of the following was a major reason the Supreme Court ruled that state-approved term limits for Congress were unconstitutional?

answers.A: <label>A. State laws restricting terms varied from state to state.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The age, residency, and citizenship requirements in the Constitution could be altered only by a constitutional amendment.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Congress could pass their own laws changing term limits.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Most people in the country voiced strong opposition to state-imposed term limit requirements.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. If states passed term limit laws for congressmen, it would also enable them to pass term limit laws for other elected officials.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Cause-and-effect relationships

Choice B, the correct answer, comes straight from the Supreme Court ruling Thorton v Arkansas decided in 1995. Choice A, although true, was not a primary reason for the decision. Choice C is incorrect because the decision made it clear that the only way to accomplish term limits would be through a constitutional amendment. Choice D is factually incorrect, and choice E is a legal action states can act upon.

content: Which of the following is an example of political realignment?

answers.A: <label>A. Social conservatives voting for John McCain in 2008</label>
answers.B: <label>B. African-Americans voting for Barack Obama in 2008</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A greater percentage of Hispanics voting for Barack Obama than George W. Bush</label>
answers.D: <label>D. More independents voting for Barack Obama than John McCain</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Republican Party self-identification declining during the 2000s</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Hypothesis

Choice C, the correct answer, is a good example of realignment, the movement of voters from one political party to another, resulting in a major shift in succeeding elections. In this case, there was a major movement of Hispanic voters away from the Republican Party. Choices A and B are incorrect because social conservatives have voted for Republicans, and African-Americans have voted for Democrats in past presidential elections. Choice D and Choice E, though factually correct, do not define realignment.

content: Which of the following statements is true about the nature of modern party organizations?

answers.A: <label>A. Local politics generates a grassroots support by party regulars.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The control of the party machinery is greatest at the national level.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The party's national committee has the major fundraising responsibility for local candidates.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. They are run by party bosses in a democratic manner.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The party's chairman is selected by its congressional membership.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Type of Question: Generalization/definitional

Choice A, the correct answer, is a political axiom. Choices B, C, D, and E are factually incorrect. Control of party machinery is greatest at the local level. Major fundraising for local candidates is done by the local candidates and on the grassroots level. Party bosses play much less of a role in party organizations than in the days of Boss Tweed, and even those local parties dominated by a party boss are not run in a democratic manner. And the party's chair is selected by the National Committee.

content:
The following excerpt is from a Supreme Court decision:
On the other hand, the allowance of the privilege to withhold evidence that is demonstrably relevant in a criminal trial would cut deeply into the guarantee of due process of law and gravely impair the basic function of the courts. A presidentâ€™s acknowledged need for confidentiality in the communication of his office is general in nature. . . .

Which event took place as a result of this ruling?

answers.A: <label>A. The impeachment of Richard Nixon by the House of Representatives</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The immediate resignation of Richard Nixon as president</label>
answers.C: <label>C. An order requiring Nixon to turn over private documents</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The release of the Watergate tapes to the Senate Watergate Committee</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The erasure of 18 minutes of a critical tape by Nixon's secretary</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Stimulus-based

The quote comes from the Supreme Court case Nixon v United States, also known as the Watergate tapes case. In Question 37, you first had to identify the passage as a Watergate-related quote. Then you had to sequence the event and know that the result of the ruling was that Nixon had to turn over the Watergate tapes (choice D). In Question 38 you had to know the definition of executive privilege and apply the case to the principle of separation of powers (choice C).

answers.D: <label>D. Judicial review</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Federalism</label>

(C) Type of Question: Stimulus-based

The quote comes from the Supreme Court case Nixon v United States, also known as the Watergate tapes case. In Question 37, you first had to identify the passage as a Watergate-related quote. Then you had to sequence the event and know that the result of the ruling was that Nixon had to turn over the Watergate tapes (choice D). In Question 38 you had to know the definition of executive privilege and apply the case to the principle of separation of powers (choice C).

content: The major impact third political parties have on presidential elections has been to

answers.A: <label>A. recruit leaders from the Democrats and Republicans to run for president</label>
answers.B: <label>B. draw enough votes from the major partiesto throw the election into the House of Representatives</label>
answers.C: <label>C. generate increased party identification among the electorate</label>
answers.D: <label>D. develop issues that are later adopted by the major political parties</label>
answers.E: <label>E. encourage a larger voter turnout</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Generalization

Choice D, the correct answer, is derived from the fact that throughout political history many third-party platforms are eventually incorporated into the platforms of the major parties. Examples are the populist reforms and the issue of deficit spending raised by Ross Perot in 1992. The other choices are not factually correct.

content: A special interest group would probably have the greatest success dealing with a legislator regarding public policy issues that

answers.A: <label>A. were favored by the public as reflected by polls</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the president also supported</label>
answers.C: <label>C. were controversial in nature</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the legislator needed specific information about, which the group could provide</label>
answers.E: <label>E. had previously been voted on by Congress but defeated</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Sequencing a series of events

Choice D, the correct answer, is true because the actions of lobbyists are measured by whether the lobbyist can convince the legislator to vote for a particular bill. Besides using other means, when a lobbyist is armed with facts and figures, legislators are more likely to respond to the position taken by the lobbyist. Choices A, B, C, and E are all possible but do not relate directly to the issue the question is raising.

content: Which of the following statements best describes congressional incumbency?

answers.A: <label>A. Incumbents are usually able to win reelection.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Incumbents have had fundraising limits imposed on them by the Federal Election Commission.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Incumbents have been able to raise less money than their opponents.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Incumbents are able to use franking privileges to their advantage.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Incumbents look to have numerous debates with their opponents.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Type of Question: Cause-and-effect relationships

Choice A, the correct answer, reflects the importance of incumbency. During national presidential elections, most incumbents have an advantage going into the election. Choice B is factually correct. Choice D, although true, does not get to the heart of the issue of incumbencyâ€”the ability to win reelection. Choice E is a false statement.

content: Compared with marble cake federalism, Reagan's new federalism aimed to

answers.A: <label>A. increase the size of the federal government</label>
answers.B: <label>B. reduce the number of block grants given to the states</label>
answers.C: <label>C. downsize the federal government and turn more authority over to the states</label>
answers.D: <label>D. increase the amount of federal taxes to reduce the deficit</label>
answers.E: <label>E. reduce the size of the Defense Department and give the savings back to the states</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Definitional

Choice C, the correct answer, requires a working knowledge of the characteristics of both marble cake federalism and Reagan's new federalism. Choices A, B, and E are factually incorrect. Choice D, although factually correct, does not reflect a practice of Reagan's policies.

content: Which of the following has the power to increase the size of the Supreme Court?

answers.A: <label>A. The voters</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The president</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Congress</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A constitutional amendment</label>
answers.E: <label>E. A vote by the Senate Judiciary Committee</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Sequencing a series of events

Choice C, the correct answer, is the prescribed constitutional way the size of the Court can be changed. Historically, when Franklin Roosevelt was unhappy with the decisions made by the Court, he attempted to "pack the court" and Congress rejected the proposal. Even though a constitutional amendment could be an alternative, it is not the answer because it has never been proposed.

content: Which statement is true about the War Powers Act?

answers.A: <label>A. It overturned the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It gave Congress the power to appoint the head of the joint chiefs of staff.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It gave the president the authority to declare war.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It established procedures when United States troops were under the command of the UN during peacekeeping missions.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. It directed the president to be accountable to the Congress if he sent troops to foreign countries.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Type of Question: Generalization

Choice E, the correct answer, is a component of the War Powers Act. Choices A, B, C, and D are factually incorrect.

content: The guiding principle that governs legislative apportionment is

answers.A: <label>A. political gerrymandering</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the establishment of majority-minority districts</label>
answers.C: <label>C. one man, one vote</label>
answers.D: <label>D. judicial authority to create congressional districts</label>
answers.E: <label>E. districts determined by the governors of each state</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Identification and analysis

Choice C, the correct answer, derives from the Supreme Court ruling Baker v Carr and mandates state legislatures to take into account the make-up and size of congressional districts when redistricting based on population changes. Although political gerrymandering (choice A) or majority-minority districts may be the result, they are not the guiding principles in creating legislative apportionment. Choices D and E are factually incorrect.

content: All of the following demographic criteria have had an impact on voting EXCEPT

answers.A: <label>A. the number of young people registered</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the socioeconomic makeup of the electorate</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the shift of the population to sunbelt states</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the ethnic make-up of the electorate</label>
answers.E: <label>E. an increase in illegal aliens</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Type of Question: Negative

Choice E, the correct answer, though impacting on an election issue, does not affect voting because illegal aliens cannot vote. Choice D is a different issue since ethnic make-up refers to heritage.

content: What conclusion can you reach from the fact that informal congressional caucus groups such as the black caucus and caucus for women's issues have been formed?

answers.A: <label>A. Caucus groups have had little impact on the legislative process.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Democratic caucus groups were more powerful than Republican groups.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. There is an indirect relationship between these groups and special interest groups.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Caucus groups were organized to better serve voter constituents.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Republican groups were more numerous than Democratic groups.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Cause-and-effect relationships

Choice D, the correct answer, reflects the fact that most congressional caucuses have as their purpose a constituent base. Choices A, C, and E are factually incorrect. Choice B is incorrect because there is little relationship between power and the existence of a caucus group.

content: Which of the following represents the attitudes of citizens with respect to the issue of separation of church and state?

answers.A: <label>A. A majority of the population is against a constitutional amendment authorizing silent prayer in the schools.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Conservatives feel that more people should attend churches and synagogues on a more regular basis.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A majority of the population understands the establishment clause but feels students should be able to pray in school.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Citizens in a pluralist society reject the need to recognize the rights of minority religious groups.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Generalization

Choice D, the correct answer, is based on numerous poll results. Choices A, B, and E are incorrect factually. Choice C is factually accurate but has nothing to do with the issue of separation of church and state.

content: The commerce clause of the Constitution has been viewed as a way for

answers.A: <label>A. Congress to exercise greater authority over state matters</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the president to exercise greater authority to commit troops abroad</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the states to exercise their reserved powers</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the Senate to increase its authority to advise and consent the president's appointments</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Congress to exercise greater authority over the Supreme Court</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Type of Question: Identification and analysis

Choice A, the correct answer, requires you to know that the commerce clause has been used to pass legislation such as the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Even though choices B, C, and D can take place, they have nothing to do with the commerce clause. Choice E is incorrect because congressional authority relates to the size of the Court.

content: Since the 2000s the manner in which legislation passed each house of Congress suggests that

answers.A: <label>A. bipartisanship has been the rule of thumb</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Congress has passed a greater number of bills than in previous decades</label>
answers.C: <label>C. there has been an increasing tendency for the president to veto legislation</label>
answers.D: <label>D. even though the House may pass its legislative agenda, it is often slowed down by the Senate</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Senate-House conference committees have exercised greater influence than congressional leaders in the formulation of legislation</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Hypothetical

Choice D, the correct answer, is true especially if you consider what happened in the first year the Republicans gained control of Congress in 1994. Although the House passed almost every component of the Republican Contract with America, the Senate took much longer to pass the bills it received from the House. Choice A is incorrect because traditionally there has been bickering between the parties. Choices B, C, and E are incorrect factually.

content: All of the following reflect devolution of federal power EXCEPT

answers.A: <label>A. the approval of block grants to the states</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the limitations placed on the federal government to pass on unfunded mandates to the states</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the Supreme Court decisions that allow death row inmates to file petitions for review in federal court</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the executive orders resulting in the downsizing of the bureaucracy</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the congressional legislation resulting in the elimination of regulations established by regulatory agencies</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Negative

Choice C, the correct answer, has nothing to do with the aim of giving back power to the states. The other choices all have components that reflect the states gaining authority and the federal government giving up its control over the states.

content: Since 1960, which of the following is the most significant factor in determining which candidate receives the party's nomination for president?

answers.A: <label>A. The economic condition facing the country</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The belief that programs favored by the candidate would benefit the country</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The ability of the candidate to win a majority of the delegates</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The support given to the candidate by party leaders</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The polls indicating that the candidate has name recognition</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Solution to a problem

Choice C, the correct answer, is the practical reason why a candidate receives the nomination. Winning a majority of the delegates is crucial to receiving the party's nomination. Although choices A, B, D, and E are all factors, if the candidate does not win primaries, those issues all become irrelevant.

content: All of the following are reasons for lower voter turnout in congressional elections compared to presidential elections EXCEPT

answers.A: <label>A. Political advertisements use more smear tactics in presidential elections.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Voters are more aware of national issues than local issues.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. There is more media coverage of presidential elections.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Voters believe that presidential elections have a greater impact on the country's future.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Candidates spend more money on presidential elections.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Type of Question: Negative

Choice A, the correct answer, does not take into account that even in congressional elections candidates use smear tactics. The other choices are all valid reasons why there is lower voter turnout in off-year elections.

content: The Speaker of the House of Representatives has the primary role of

answers.A: <label>A. breaking tie votes in the House</label>
answers.B: <label>B. presiding over the House during routine business</label>
answers.C: <label>C. setting the legislative agenda for the House</label>
answers.D: <label>D. settling disputes in his own party</label>
answers.E: <label>E. acting as a liaison with the opposition party</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Identification and analysis

Choice C, the correct answer, is a major function of the speaker. Even though the speaker has other roles described (choices A, B, D, and E), the primary role is to establish a legislative agenda. A good example of this responsibility was when Newt Gingrich pushed through the House the Republican Contract in 1994.

content: All of the following choices are accurate statements about the nature of bureaucracies EXCEPT

answers.A: <label>A. There are built-in review processes for appeal of agency decisions.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. There are bureaucratic agencies that oversee other agencies.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The size and scope of the federal bureaucracy increased in the 1990s.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. There are political checks on agencies.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Legislative power can restrict agency appropriations.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Negative

Choice C, the correct answer, is not true because of President Clinton's efforts to downsize the federal government through his REGO (reinventing government) programs. The other choices are all correct.

content: Which statement is most true of the media's coverage of presidential campaigns?

answers.A: <label>A. Presidential endorsements by newspapers change the minds of many voters.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Sunday talk shows pay for their guests to appear.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. There is an increased interest in covering the national conventions gavel to gavel by the major networks.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Networks like C-SPAN and CNN have played an increasingly important role in reporting the issues of the campaign.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The fairness doctrine has lessened the accusation that there is bias in the media toward one candidate.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Generalization

Choice D, the correct answer, is a relatively new characteristic of the importance of the media in covering the political scene. Choices A, C, and E are factually inaccurate. Choice B is an exaggeration.

content: Which of the following statements describes voting trends in recent presidential elections?

answers.A: <label>A. The gender gap has not been a factor.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The youth vote is declining.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The religious right is becoming less of a factor.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. More people are enrolling as Independents.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. White Americans vote Democratic.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Identification and analysis

Choice D correctly identifies the recent voting trend regarding party identification. Since 2008, more people are enrolling as Independents rather than Democrats or Republicans. This is called dealignment. Choice A is incorrect because in the last three presidential elections women have voted in higher numbers for the Democratic presidential candidate than men voting for either the Republican or Democratic presidential candidate. Choice B is incorrect because in the 2008 presidential election the youth vote increased for President Obama. Choice C is incorrect because the religious right vote has been a major factor in elections, especially in the 2004 election. Choice E is incorrect because white Americans tend to vote Republican in presidential elections.

content: Which of the following statements is a major reason for the increased use of public opinion polls by the media?

answers.A: <label>A. The government assesses the validity of the polls.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Candidate-sponsored polls compete for the public's attention.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A smaller random sample can now be used to get accurate results.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Polls are aimed exclusively at minority groups.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Elected officials pay attention to poll results.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Type of Question: Cause-and-effect relationships

Choice E, the correct answer, is an obvious reason and may cause some confusion because it answers the question so simplistically. Choices A, B, C, and D are factually incorrect.

content: The Federal Reserve Board has grown in importance because it

answers.A: <label>A. influences the trade policy of the United States</label>
answers.B: <label>B. has printed more money in order to reduce the deficit</label>
answers.C: <label>C. attempts to control inflation by raising or lowering interest rates</label>
answers.D: <label>D. can shut down trading on the stock market when the market drops below a certain point</label>
answers.E: <label>E. can create new branches of the National Bank</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Identification/definitional

Choice C, the correct answer, is a major function of the Federal Reserve Board and was used frequently in the 1990s in an attempt to head off a period of inflation. Choices A, B, D, and E are factually incorrect.

content: All of the following are characteristics of the media-driven presidential campaign EXCEPT

answers.A: <label>A. 30-second political ads shown on prime-time television shows</label>
answers.B: <label>B. political debates that include minor party candidates</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the use of Twitter and Facebook by the campaigns</label>
answers.D: <label>D. sophisticated polling done by paid consultants</label>
answers.E: <label>E. candidates appearing on Sunday talk shows</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Negative

Choice B, the correct answer, does not accurately describe the media-driven presidential campaign. Even though a political debate is a characteristic of a media-driven presidential campaign, the inclusion of minor party candidates has not occurred since the 1992 presidential debate. The other choices are all characteristics of the media-driven presidential campaign.

content: Which of the following statements is true?

answers.A: <label>A. People have a high degree of trust in their politicians and elected officials.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Divided government has been endorsed by the electorate in numerous presidential elections.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Democrats have regained status as the majority party in the South.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Realignment has created a viable third party.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. People identify themselves more as liberals than conservatives.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Identification and analysis

Choice B, the correct answer, refers to the fact that since 1968 there has been a consistent pattern reflected in the election of a president from one party and the election of a majority of members of the opposite party to Congress. Choice A is the opposite of what people believe. Choices, C, D, and E are factually incorrect.

content: Which of the following principles of government was articulated in the Federalist Papers?

answers.A: <label>A. Checks and balances</label>
answers.B: <label>B. A weak judicial branch</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A weak executive branch</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A strong House and a weak Senate</label>
answers.E: <label>E. A unitary form of government</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Type of Question: Identification and analysis

Choice A, the correct answer, is a central concept of the Federalist papers. The Federalists adopted Montesquieu's principle of checks and balances as the foundation of the separation of powers in the federal government. Choices B and C were weaknesses in the Articles of Confederation. Choice D was never discussed, and Choice E deals with a different form of government.

content: An example of political socialization includes which of the following statements?

answers.A: <label>A. Parents who vote Democratic influencing their children to vote Democratic</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Children being taught about politics in school</label>
answers.C: <label>C. College graduates deciding to attend law school in order to run for office</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Political parties influencing voters through political ads</label>
answers.E: <label>E. A newspaper running an editorial that suggests that a politician should resign</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Type of Question: Definitional

Choice A is the correct answer because, by definition, political socialization is the process whereby people obtain their political values. These values, such as party identification, views on abortion, and attitudes toward affirmative action, can come from a variety of sourcesâ€”primarily from parents, but also schools and churches. Choices B, C, D, and E are incorrect because they do not fit within this definition.

content: Executive privilege has

answers.A: <label>A. protected the president from standing trial while in office</label>
answers.B: <label>B. protected the first lady from handing over personal materials to special prosecutors</label>
answers.C: <label>C. resulted in Supreme Court decisions ordering the president to give sensitive materials to investigators</label>
answers.D: <label>D. created the need for new laws defining what executive privilege means</label>
answers.E: <label>E. rallied public opinion to support the president using this power</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Cause-and-effect

Choice C, the correct answer, applies the definition of executive privilege to a specific situation. The Supreme Court ruled in the United States v Nixon and in a case where Hillary Rodham Clinton tried to use executive privilege in order to withhold Whitewater documents that in both cases the materials had to be handed over. Choices A and B are factually incorrect. Choices D and E were never part of the controversy.

content: Which of the following reforms has been recommended to change the electoral college?

answers.A: <label>A. Close polls throughout the country the same time on election day.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Ban exit polling by the networks.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Eliminate the winner-take-all provision of the system.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Move up the date that electors vote.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Expand the concept of choosing electors to congressional races.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Solution to a problem

Choice C, the correct answer, deals with the part of the electoral college system that awards a candidate the total electoral votes of a state regardless of the margin of victory. There have been suggestions to reform the system by creating a proportional allocation of electoral votes. Choices A and B are reforms suggested dealing with the coverage of national elections by the networks. Choices D and E have never been suggested.

content: Supreme Court cases mainly derive from

answers.A: <label>A. plea bargains that fail</label>
answers.B: <label>B. congressional legislation that is vetoed</label>
answers.C: <label>C. state legislation that goes unchallenged</label>
answers.D: <label>D. original jurisdiction cases</label>
answers.E: <label>E. appellate jurisdiction cases</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Type of Question: Identification and analysis

Choice E, the correct answer, is the most common manner in which cases get to the Supreme Court. In order to answer the question correctly, you must know the definitions and application of original jurisdiction and appellate jurisdiction. The other choices are incorrect.

content:
Question below is based on this table:

CONGRESSIONAL BILLS VETOED: 1961-2010

Which of the following conclusions about presidential vetoes is supported by the table?

explanation:
Correct Answer: D
