(D) Type of Question: Stimulus-based

The table identifies the nature and number of presidential vetoes used by presidents, beginning with Kennedy and ending with Clinton. The table also defines the type of veto each president used; regular, which can be voted on by Congress, or pocket, which a president makes when Congress has completed its session or is in recess for ten days. Choice D is the correct answer because, clearly, Ford had more vetoes rejected by Congress than the other president listed. Choice A is wrong because more vetoes have been sustained than overridden. Choice B is incorrect because Congress does not vote on pocket vetoes. Choice C is incorrect because even though Reagan had the highest number of vetoes sustained, on a percentage basis, Bill Clinton was more successful. Choice E is wrong because Clinton never used a pocket veto.

content: The provisions of the Fifth Amendment have all of the following components EXCEPT

answers.A: <label>A. prohibition of double jeopardy</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the right to a speedy trial</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the protection against self-incrimination</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the right of eminent domain</label>
answers.E: <label>E. protection of life, liberty, and property</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Negative

Choice B, the correct answer, is the only answer that refers to a right not found in the Fifth Amendment. It is a Seventh Amendment right. The other choices are all part of the Fifth Amendment.

content: Which of the following ideas advocated by Republicans during the 1994 congressional elections best describes the concept of devolution?

answers.A: <label>A. They encouraged a return of power to the state governments.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. They promoted a strong executive branch.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. They called for an evolutionary approach to checks and balances.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. They advocated a better relationship between the voter and elected representatives.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. They insisted on passage of a balanced budget amendment.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Type of Question: Identification and analysis

Choice A, the correct answer, requires that you know the definition of devolution and then be able to apply it to an actual event. In this case, the Republicans wanted more power to be turned over to the states. Choice B is the opposite of devolution. Choices C and D have nothing to do with devolution, and Choice E, though having consequences for the states, does not answer the question as directly as Choice A.

content: Which of the following House committees has the most influence in determining the fate of legislation?

answers.A: <label>A. Agricultural Committee</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Rules Committee</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Post Office Committee</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Education Committee</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Foreign Affairs Committee</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Identification and analysis

Choice B, the correct answer, is one of the most influential House committees. The other committees may be important in certain situations, but the question asked you to identify specifically a committee that can influence legislation. The Rules Committee determines which bills reach the floor.

content: Which of the following is considered to be the highest leadership position in the Senate?

answers.A: <label>A. Minority Whip</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Majority Whip</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Minority Leader</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Majority Leader</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Identification and analysis

Choice D, the correct answer, includes those positions in the Senate that are leadership in nature even if it is a minority position (minority leader).

content: Elite class theory differs from pluralism in that groups from the elite believe that

answers.A: <label>A. consensus is essential to political compromise</label>
answers.B: <label>B. representation of many interest groups foster good government</label>
answers.C: <label>C. they are best suited to run government based on their economic status</label>
answers.D: <label>D. sharing wealth and power are foundations of representative government</label>
answers.E: <label>E. gaining access to elected representatives can best be achieved through special interests</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Comparing and contrasting concepts

Choice C, the correct answer, is a good definition and application of the elite class theory. Choice A is a good application of pluralism. Choice B is an application of hyperpluralism. Choices D and E may have some truth in their applications, but do not answer the question.

content: Libel and slander most closely come into conflict with the constitutional guarantee of

answers.A: <label>A. due process</label>
answers.B: <label>B. free speech</label>
answers.C: <label>C. equal protection under the law</label>
answers.D: <label>D. a fair trial</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the right to an attorney</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Sequencing a series of ideas

Choice B, the correct answer, is an application of the definition of libel and slander. If you know those definitions, then you will be able to connect them with an inherent conflict of the free speech provision of the First Amendment. Choice A may apply if a trial occurs over a libel or slander suit. Choice C is a general constitutional guarantee. Choices D and E are components needed in any trial.

content: In the Gibbons v Ogden case, the Supreme Court decided for the first time that

answers.A: <label>A. judicial review was a power of the court</label>
answers.B: <label>B. state contracts took precedence over federal law</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Congress had the exclusive right to regulate interstate commerce</label>
answers.D: <label>D. intrastate commerce was a legitimate federal function</label>
answers.E: <label>E. states could not tax the federal government</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Chronological

Choice C, the correct answer, is the central result of one of the landmark cases the Marshall Court ruled on. The question is difficult because Choices A and E were results of other landmark Marshall casesâ€”Marbury v Madison and McCulloch v Maryland. Choices B and D are false statements.

content: A constituent approach to representation reflects a

answers.A: <label>A. congressman who consistently votes his conscience</label>
answers.B: <label>B. legislator who usually follows the party line</label>
answers.C: <label>C. lawmaker who introduces a bill that increases defense spending</label>
answers.D: <label>D. desire on the part of an elected official to represent the view of those who voted for him</label>
answers.E: <label>E. consistent approach by the representative who challenges the president's programs</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Definitional

Choice D, the correct answer, defines the notion behind the idea of a congressman following a constituent's view when voting on legislation. In order to answer the question, you must know the definition of constituent, and you should be able to recognize the fact that there are other legitimate approaches a representative can take (Choices A, B, and E) that do not answer the question.

content: What is a major difference between the manner in which both houses of Congress operate?

answers.A: <label>A. The House allows unlimited debate on bills, whereas the Senate has strict time limitations.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The Senate permits more amendments to bills than does the House.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The rules of both houses are the same.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Committee chairman terms are limited in the Senate, but not in the House.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The Senate Committees always have equal numbers of Democrats and Republicans serving on them.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Comparing and contrasting ideas

Choice B, the correct answer, is the only answer that establishes a major difference between the House and Senate. Choices A, C, and E are obviously incorrect. Choice D is tricky because the House has term limits for committee chairmen.

content: The media play what kind of role related to public policy?

answers.A: <label>A. It raises money to support candidates running for office.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It has the major function of linking the electorate to the formal institutions of government.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It investigates the personal ethics of elected officials.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It competes for the attention of the electorate.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. It influences politicians by offering them lower advertising rates.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Cause-and-effect relationship

Choice B, the correct answer, is a definition of the media as a linkage institution to government. Choice C may be a function of the media, but it does not apply to public policy. Choice D may be true, but it also does not have anything to do with what the question is asking.

content: What advantage did the line item veto have over a regular veto? The line item veto allowed the president to

answers.A: <label>A. strike any provision of the 13 major appropriation bills</label>
answers.B: <label>B. eliminate riders attached to spending bills</label>
answers.C: <label>C. line out appropriation bills started in the Senate</label>
answers.D: <label>D. veto legislation designated as essential</label>
answers.E: <label>E. ignore a continuing resolution</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Type of Question: Identification and analysis

Choice A, the correct answer, was the only provision of the line item veto that applied to legislation before it was declared unconstitutional. The line item veto permitted the president to exercise veto power on any part of the 13 appropriation bills that fund the government and make up the discretionary spending portion of the federal budget. Choice B is wrong because it only refers to amendments attached to appropriation bills. Choice C is incorrect because it only refers to action taken in the Senate. Choice D is wrong because there are many bills that can be characterized as essential. Choice E is incorrect because the president can veto a continuing resolution.

content: Which step in the development of public policy occurs first?

answers.A: <label>A. Enactment of the policy</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Formation of policy alternatives</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Evaluation of the policy</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Recognition of the problem</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Revision of the policy</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Sequencing a series of events

Choice D, the correct answer, is the first step in the development of public policy. There is a logic behind this procedure, because one would want to identify a problem before enacting, forming, evaluating, or revising the policy.

content: Which of the following is a consequence of recent Supreme Court decisions regarding campaign finance reform?

answers.A: <label>A. An increase in political ad spending by independent groups and corporations</label>
answers.B: <label>B. A ban on soft money donations</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A ban on hard money donations</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Presidential candidates accepting matching funds</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Public financing of congressional campaigns</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Type of Question: Cause-and-effect

Choice A is the correct answer because a consequence of the Citizens United case is it allowed unlimited campaign donations to groups that were independent from any party or campaign. Choice B is incorrect because soft money donations were the type of donations allowed in the decision. Choice C is factually incorrect. Choice D is incorrect because in both the 2008 and 2012 presidential campaigns candidates stopped accepting matching funds. Choice E is incorrect because there is no public financing of congressional campaigns.

content: The aim of the exclusionary rule as defined in the Mapp v Ohio Supreme Court case is to

answers.A: <label>A. encourage police to knock before entering a suspected crime scene</label>
answers.B: <label>B. prevent law enforcement officials from stopping and frisking suspects</label>
answers.C: <label>C. deny the media access to places where police are conducting an investigation</label>
answers.D: <label>D. force police to get search warrants for evidence in plain view</label>
answers.E: <label>E. not allow illegally obtained evidence to be admitted into a court proceeding</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Type of Question: Identification and analysis

Choice E, the correct answer, reflects the definition and application of the exclusionary rule. Choice A refers to the no-knock ruling. Choice B refers to the stop and frisk principle. Choice C can be true in certain situations but has nothing to do with the exclusionary rule. Choice D is a false statement, and in fact police do not need warrants to get evidence in plain view.

content: The main criticism levied against the Articles of Confederation was that it

answers.A: <label>A. gave too much power to the central government</label>
answers.B: <label>B. failed to give the national government the authority to lay and collect taxes</label>
answers.C: <label>C. did not allow the federal government to govern new territories</label>
answers.D: <label>D. created a powerful judicial branch</label>
answers.E: <label>E. had a term limit provision for the president</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Chronological

Choice B, the correct answer, reflects the major criticism and weakness of the Articles of Confederation. The reason why the Articles were so ineffective, besides giving too much authority to the states, was that the new central government could not pay off Revolutionary War debts by collecting taxes. The other choices are all incorrect because they do not apply to the Articles.

content: As a result of the Motor Voter Law, there was

answers.A: <label>A. a decrease in registration because states challenged the law's constitutionality</label>
answers.B: <label>B. an increase in registration, but a decrease in turnout</label>
answers.C: <label>C. a decrease in registration and a decrease in turnout</label>
answers.D: <label>D. an increase in registration and an increase in turnout</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the greatest increase in registration of senior citizens</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Cause-and-effect

Choice B, the correct answer, requires that you understand the nature and provisions of the Motor Voter Law passed by Congress in 1993. If you knew that the law's intent was to make it easier to register, then you could eliminate Choices A and C. Choice D is partially correct, but it is wrong because there was a decrease in actual turnout. Choice E is wrong because senior citizens were already registered and did not have to take advantage of the new law.

content: Which of the following statements about presidential appointments is true?

answers.A: <label>A. All presidential appointments must be confirmed by a majority of the Senate.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Presidential staff appointments must be confirmed by the Senate.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Presidential appointments are reviewed by the House of Representatives before going to the Senate.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Presidential appointments are first sent to a Senate committee before the full Senate votes.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. State judges are confirmed by the Senate.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Identification and Analysis

Choice D is the correct answer because after a president makes an appointment, the Senate according to the Constitution has the power to check the appointment through its power to "consent" to that appointment. Once an appointment is announced, the appropriate Senate committee holds hearings and hears testimony from the appointee. For instance, a Supreme Court nominee appears before the Senate Judiciary Committee. Once the testimony is completed, the committee votes to send the nominee's name to the full Senate where a majority vote is needed to confirm the appointee. Choices A and B are incorrect because presidential staff appointments such as chief of staff and press secretary do not need Senate confirmation. Choice C is incorrect because the House of Representatives does not play a role in this process. Choice E is incorrect because state judges are confirmed by state legislatures or voted on by the people from that state.

content: The Supreme Court has the constitutional authority to check Congress by

answers.A: <label>A. vetoing legislation signed by the president</label>
answers.B: <label>B. settling disputes among states</label>
answers.C: <label>C. applying original jurisdiction to cases brought before them on appeal</label>
answers.D: <label>D. declaring parts of legislation unconstitutional</label>
answers.E: <label>E. assigning the Chief Justice to preside over the impeachment trial of the president</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Solution to a problem

Choice D, the correct answer, is the primary manner in which the Supreme Court applies judicial review to congressional actions. Choice A is not a power of the Court. Choices B, C, and E are all powers of the Supreme Court, but they do not have anything to do with its ability to check congressional power.

content: An alternate manner in which a president can implement policy without congressional approval is by

answers.A: <label>A. appointing a member of the opposing political party to the cabinet</label>
answers.B: <label>B. issuing an executive order</label>
answers.C: <label>C. sending controversial legislation to the electorate for a referendum</label>
answers.D: <label>D. making a speech in front of a group that opposes him</label>
answers.E: <label>E. holding a press conference</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Identification and analysis

Choice B is the correct answer because an executive order defines the manner in which a president can create public policy without signing legislation. Choices A, D, and E are all legitimate tools a president can use, but they do not necessarily result in public policy. Choice C is not a power of the president.

content: The trend of affirmative action programs in the 2000s was to

answers.A: <label>A. require a quota system for college admissions</label>
answers.B: <label>B. eliminate requirements for federally funded affirmative action programs</label>
answers.C: <label>C. take race as a factor only in the private sector</label>

answers.E: <label>E. face challenges on the legality of existing laws</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Type of Question: Generalization

Choice E, the correct answer, comes directly from a series of court cases challenging existing affirmative action programs. Choice A is factually incorrect. Choice B would be true if it suggested a reduction of federal programs, rather than a complete elimination. Choices C and D are factually incorrect.

content: The "fighting words" doctrine outlined in Supreme Court decisions deals with

answers.A: <label>A. freedom of the press</label>
answers.B: <label>B. separation of church and state</label>
answers.C: <label>C. freedom of speech</label>
answers.D: <label>D. freedom of assembly</label>
answers.E: <label>E. freedom to petition</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Definitional

Choice C, the correct answer, is the only area in the Bill of Rights where the "fighting words" doctrine applies. It originally came from the Supreme Court case Chaplinsky v New Hampshire, and it was one of the few decisions that placed limitations on freedom of speech.

content: A major characteristic of independent regulatory agencies is that they are

answers.A: <label>A. quasi-legislative and quasi-judicial in function</label>
answers.B: <label>B. highly influenced by special interest groups</label>
answers.C: <label>C. sensitive to the needs of the electorate</label>
answers.D: <label>D. decreasing in size, scope, and influence</label>
answers.E: <label>E. minimally influential in determining public policy</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Type of Question: Generalization

Choice A, the correct answer, is the only answer that gives a major characteristic of many bureaucratic agencies such as the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), the Food and Drug Administration, and Federal Trade Commission (FTC). They are called quasi-legislative and quasi-judicial because they can issue regulations and then act as judges to see that the regulations are being followed.

content: Which of the following is characteristic of the nominating process for president in the 2008 and 2012 elections?

answers.A: <label>A. There were more caucuses than primaries.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. There was a higher voter turnout in the primaries than in the general election.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Women determined the outcome of the nomination for the Democratic Party.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. There was an incumbent running in both parties.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. There was an increased number of front-loaded primaries.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Type of Question: Sequencing a series of events

Choice E is the correct answer because both the Democratic and Republican parties had what are called front-loaded primaries, the scheduling of early presidential primaries, in 2008 and 2012. Choice A is incorrect because there are more primaries than caucuses. Choice B is incorrect because there is a higher voter turnout in the general election than in the primaries. Choice C is incorrect because women were only one voting group that helped determine the nominee. Choice D is incorrect because only in 2004 was an incumbent, George W. Bush, running.

content: A trend toward dealignment occurred in the 2000s because

answers.A: <label>A. voters had strong party identification</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the Motor Voter Law has increased registration for the Democrats and Republicans</label>
answers.C: <label>C. there was a general mistrust of elected officials</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the Republicans gained control of Congress in 1994</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the Freedom of Information act revealed campaign irregularities by the major parties</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Definitional/cause-and-effect

Choice C, the correct answer, requires that you understand the definition of dealignment. Once you recognize that the term means a moving away from both major political parties, the question becomes relatively easy. Choice A is the opposite meaning. Choice B may be true but does not answer the question. Choices D and E may be factually correct, but they do not provide the correct answer to the question posed.

content: A presidential power that has been challenged by Congress since 1980 is the power to

answers.A: <label>A. commit troops to foreign countries</label>
answers.B: <label>B. give the State of the Union address</label>
answers.C: <label>C. appoint cabinet members</label>
answers.D: <label>D. sign treaties</label>
answers.E: <label>E. receive ambassadors</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Type of Question: Identification

Choice A, the correct answer, is the one area in which the Congress and the president have disagreed. After the Vietnam War, Congress became very hesitant anytime the president committed American troops to a foreign nation. Situations like Haiti and Bosnia are recent examples. The other choices all contain presidential powers that have not been challenged to any great extent by Congress.

content: A major difference between a freshman member and a five-term member of the House of Representatives is that the

answers.A: <label>A. freshman was allowed to get committee chairmanship</label>
answers.B: <label>B. five-term representative could not run for reelection because of term limits</label>
answers.C: <label>C. freshman representative could not offer amendments to proposed bills</label>
answers.D: <label>D. five-term representative had fewer opportunities to receive PAC money</label>
answers.E: <label>E. freshman representative had strong convictions and was less likely to compromise</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Type of Question: Comparing and contrasting ideas

Choice E, the correct answer, is a characteristic of a newly elected ideological representative. You only have to go back to the freshman class of 1994 to see how they came into Congress ready to change the rules of the game. They succeeded to a certain extent. However, they also learned that the art of compromise was essential to the implementation of public policy. The other choices are all false statements.

content: The concept of one man, one vote as outlined in the Baker v Carr Supreme Court decision applies to elections for

answers.A: <label>A. U. S. senator</label>
answers.B: <label>B. president</label>
answers.C: <label>C. federal judges</label>
answers.D: <label>D. state legislatures</label>
answers.E: <label>E. governors</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Definitional

Choice D, the correct answer, is the only answer that applies the one man, one vote ruling to an election that guarantees equal representation. The original case, in fact, dealt with a state legislature in Tennessee that had major voting representation inequalities. The other choices all deal with elected offices that do not require equal representation. There are two senators in each state. Every citizen within a state has equal weight in voting for a president or governor, and people do not vote for federal judges.

content: The original intent of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution as interpreted by the Supreme Court was to

answers.A: <label>A. force the states to follow the Bill of Rights</label>
answers.B: <label>B. provide equal protection under the law for freed slaves</label>
answers.C: <label>C. expand voting for women</label>
answers.D: <label>D. give states the right to pass laws that guaranteed separate but equal status to their citizens</label>
answers.E: <label>E. enable Congress to pass affirmative action legislation</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Chronological

Choice B, the correct answer, is derived from the fact that the Fourteenth Amendment was introduced and ratified after the Civil War to deal with the injustices that the freed slaves had to face. The amendment was later used to incorporate the Bill of Rights into state action (Choice A). Choice C was accomplished through another constitutional amendment. Choice D was the manner in which the Supreme Court interpreted the equal protection clause in the Plessy v Ferguson case. Choice E is factually correct, but not the original intent of the amendment.

content: Historically, the approval rating of the president usually

answers.A: <label>A. remains around 50 percent during his entire term</label>
answers.B: <label>B. fluctuates depending on his response to national and international problems</label>
answers.C: <label>C. is lowest during times of war</label>
answers.D: <label>D. is highest toward the end of his presidency</label>
answers.E: <label>E. depends on the kind of media coverage he gets</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Generalization

Choice B, the correct answer, is true because public opinion is quite fickle and usually responds to very visible national and international problems. Choices A and C are factually incorrect. Choices D and E may have some elements of truth, but they do not provide a complete answer to the question asked.

content: All of the following steps are characteristic of the lawmaking process EXCEPT

answers.A: <label>A. Revenue bills must start in the Senate.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Conference committees resolve differences between bills.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Filibusters in the Senate are used to stop bills from coming to a vote.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Each House has standing committees that mark up legislation.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. A roll call vote indicates the positions taken by congressmen.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Type of Question: Negative

Choice A, the incorrect statement, reflects the fact that revenue bills must start in the House. The other choices all reflect important characteristics of the lawmaking process.

content: The use of racial quotas was made illegal in the United States as a direct result of the

answers.C: <label>C. Proposition 209-The California Civil Rights Initiative</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Civil Rights Act of 1964</label>
answers.E: <label>E. affirmative action programs created by individual states</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Type of Question: Cause-and-effect

Choice A is the correct answer because the Bakke decision allowed states to take race into consideration when developing affirmative action programs. However, the Court also ruled that a quota system violated the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. Choice B is wrong because the Brown decision only dealt with the issue of school integration and was silent about quotas. Choice C is incorrect because Proposition 209 eliminated all government-sponsored affirmative action programs in California. Choice D is incorrect because the Civil Rights Act of 1964 banned discrimination in public accommodations. Choice E is an accurate statement of fact but does not answer the question.

content: A primary election in which voters from one political party can cross over to express their choice for a candidate from another party is called

answers.A: <label>A. a closed primary</label>
answers.B: <label>B. an open caucus</label>
answers.C: <label>C. a nonbinding primary</label>
answers.D: <label>D. an open primary</label>
answers.E: <label>E. a dual primary</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Sequencing an event

Choice D, the correct answer, is the prescribed manner in which an open primary is held. You must know the definitions of the different kinds of primaries to be able to answer this question. Closed primary is limited by party affiliation. Nonbinding primary does not lock delegates to the winner. Dual primary is one in which a presidential preference and a separate slate is voted on. An open caucus does not exist.

content: All of the following is true about the 2010 census EXCEPT

answers.A: <label>A. Minorities, especially Hispanics, make up a growing share of the U.S. population and are the largest ethnic group.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The fastest-growing states are in the North and Rustbelt.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Southern and western states gained seats in the U.S. House of Representatives, while Northeastern and Midwestern states lost seats.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The fastest rates of decline tend to be in the Northeast and Midwest.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Most U.S. population growth during the past century has taken place in suburbs, rather than central cities.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Negative

Choice B, the correct answer, is false because the fastest-growing states are in the West and South. Choices A, C, D, and E are all results from the 2010 census.

content: Congressional oversight committees have the main purpose of

answers.A: <label>A. reviewing governmental operations</label>
answers.B: <label>B. drafting appropriation bills</label>
answers.C: <label>C. holding impeachment hearings</label>
answers.D: <label>D. establishing time limits for debates</label>
answers.E: <label>E. writing constitutional amendments</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Type of Question: Identification

Choice A, the correct answer, is the major function of congressional oversight committees. Once the oversight function is completed, appropriate legislation may be drafted to deal with the problem that was investigated. Or a criminal proceeding may result if evidence is brought out in the hearings. Two examples of oversight hearings are the campaign finance irregularities and the Whitewater hearings. The other choices, though functions of congressional committees, do not apply directly to oversight.

content: A criticism of the U.S. census is that it

answers.A: <label>A. favors large cities over suburban areas</label>
answers.B: <label>B. costs the taxpayer too much money</label>
answers.C: <label>C. is held too frequently</label>
answers.D: <label>D. is biased toward the party who controls Congress</label>
answers.E: <label>E. does not take into account the homeless</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Type of Question: Cause-and-effect

Choice E, the correct answer, is an aspect of the census that has only become a problem because the homeless do not reside in a specific residence. It is important, especially to the large urban areas, because it could easily impact on the number of representatives from a state that has a large homeless population. The other choices are factually incorrect.

content:
Question below is based on this graph:

According to the graph, which statement is true about voter turnout in presidential elections?

answers.A: <label>A. Turnout is greatest when the country is at peace.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Turnout is lowest in elections where there is a landslide.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Turnout is determined by the number of candidates running for president.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Turnout is lower after presidential scandals.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Turnout is increased when a president wins a second term.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Stimulus-based graph

The graph shows the percent of eligible voters who actually voted in presidential elections from 1968 through 2012. To answer the question, you must know some presidential history. Choice D is the correct answer. Voter turnout decreased in the elections following the Watergate scandal in 1974 and President Clinton's impeachment in 1999. Choice A is incorrect because the graph indicates that turnout was greatest when the country was at warâ€”look at the rates during the Vietnam War. Choice B is incorrect because turnout was higher in 1968 and 1980, election years where there were "landslide" victories. Choice E is wrong because turnout decreased in the years when Reagan and Clinton were reelected to second terms.

content: The president and Congress have all of the following powers in dealing with proposed legislation EXCEPT

answers.A: <label>A. The president may exercise a line item veto on appropriation bills.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The House and Senate may not send different versions of the same bill to the president for consideration.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The president has the authority to hold on to legislation after Congress adjourns without signing it.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The president may issue a veto after receiving legislation passed by both houses of Congress.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Congress may override a presidential veto by a two-thirds vote of each house.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Type of Question: Negative

Choices B, C, D, and E are factually correct and illustrate the powers that the president and Congress have in dealing with legislation. Choice A, the line item veto, is the correct answer because it was ruled unconstitutional by the Supreme Court and, therefore, is no longer an option available to the president or Congress.

content: Campaign finance reform advocacy groups such as Common Cause favor

answers.A: <label>A. a ban on soft money</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the elimination of any free television time for candidates</label>
answers.C: <label>C. an increase in the amount of money that labor unions can give to both parties</label>
answers.D: <label>D. special interest groups financing congressional campaigns</label>
answers.E: <label>E. greater use of personal funds by presidential candidates</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Type of Question: Identification

Choice A, the correct answer, requires that you know that advocacy groups such as Common Cause believe that soft money (the money that is unregulated and can go to political parties in large sums) should be banned. The other choices are incorrect because they are not areas that advocacy groups believe would reform campaign finances.

content: Supreme Court decisions in the 2000s related to the separation of church and state reflect the Court's approval of

answers.A: <label>A. greater government support for the accommodation of religion in public schools</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the use of school vouchers for tax deductions</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the limited right to have silent prayer in public schools</label>
answers.D: <label>D. a complete ban on religious symbols in schools</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the right to have clergy speak at school graduation</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Type of Question: Cause-and-effect

Choice A, the correct answer, is true because the Court has drawn a fine line between accommodation and practice of religion, especially in public schools. The other choices all reflect areas the Supreme Court has declared illegal.

content: When apportionment becomes a political tool, it is called

answers.A: <label>A. census taking</label>
answers.B: <label>B. gerrymandering</label>
answers.C: <label>C. equal representation under the law</label>
answers.D: <label>D. single district representation</label>
answers.E: <label>E. multidistrict representation</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Hypothetical

Choice B, the correct answer, requires that you know the definition of gerrymandering (the redrawing of legislative districts after a census based on purely political factors). Though Choices C and D are characteristics of congressional districts, they do not answer the question.

content: What kind of political action committee would most likely support Democratic candidates?

answers.A: <label>A. Tobacco corporations</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Labor unions</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Gun advocacy groups</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Business corporations</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The Chamber of Commerce</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Identification

Choice B, the correct answer, is a classic supporter of the Democratic Party. In fact, labor unions are the target of both Republicans and some advocacy groups because of the manner in which the unions are able to funnel contributions to the Democratic Party. The other choices reflect PACs that traditionally support the Republican Party.

content: All of the following powers are granted to Congress by the Constitution EXCEPT the power to

answers.A: <label>A. collect taxes</label>
answers.B: <label>B. declare war</label>
answers.C: <label>C. appoint judges</label>
answers.D: <label>D. regulate interstate commerce</label>
answers.E: <label>E. create inferior courts</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Negative

Choice C, the correct answer, may provide some difficulty because the Senate must approve the appointment of federal judges. The other choices are specific delegated powers of Congress.

content: Which of the following provisions of the Republican Contract with America had the goal of reforming the Congress?

answers.A: <label>A. The balanced budget amendment to the Constitution</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The Welfare Reform Act</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Term limit amendment to the Constitution</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Regulatory reform</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Legal reform</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Identification

Choice C, the correct answer, is a provision of the Contract with America that would have limited the terms of Representatives and Senators, if enacted. It was proposed as a constitutional amendment and defeated twice by the House. The other choices, though all provisions of the Contract, did not impact on the Congress itself.

content: Which of the following is a provision of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Act?

answers.A: <label>A. A time line of procedural steps the Congress had to take to pass the budget</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Authority given to the Congressional Budget Office to delete items from the proposed budget</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A balanced budget by the year 2002</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The power given to Congress to stop mandatory spending after the budget is signed into law</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The ability of the president to have a line item veto</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Type of Question: Identification

Choice A, the correct answer, is a characteristic of the act and sets in motion the manner in which the budget cycle moves in Congress. It was passed during the Nixon administration in response to Nixon's impounding funds that were budgeted. The other choices, though all aspects of budget development, are not characteristic of the Impoundment Act.

content: Which of the following events occurs first during the impeachment of a president?

answers.A: <label>A. A media frenzy forces the House to vote to impeach the president</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The House Judiciary Committee votes on articles of impeachment</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A special prosecutor issues a report to Congress</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The Senate Judiciary Committee votes on articles of impeachment</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The Supreme Court rules on the guilt or innocence of the president</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Sequencing a series of events

Choice B is the correct answer because the Constitution requires the House of Representatives to initiate impeachment charges against the president. In order for the initiation of charges to occur, the House Judiciary Committee must first vote on articles of impeachment. If you only think back to the Clinton impeachment, you may get confused and select another choice based on the events surrounding that episode, such as the media frenzy or the use of a special prosecutor's report. Although those events were associated with the impeachment of Bill Clinton, they are not part of the formal impeachment process.

content: Southern states that created "majority-minority" congressional districts did so because they were

answers.A: <label>A. directed to do so by the Supreme Court</label>
answers.B: <label>B. attempting to abide by the provisions of the Voting Rights Act of 1965</label>
answers.C: <label>C. hopeful that African-Americans would vote Republican</label>
answers.D: <label>D. confident that white candidates would be given an advantage over African-Americans</label>
answers.E: <label>E. responding to an executive order of the president</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Definitional

Choice B, the correct answer, illustrates how states had to abide by the provisions of congressional law to create equality in the voting process. In order to answer the question correctly, you have to understand the nature of majority-minority districts and the historical background. It is a difficult question because the Supreme Court declared many of these districts unconstitutional.

content: Liberal activists would probably support which of the following rulings made by the Supreme Court?

answers.A: <label>A. An abortion case that ruled there should be a 24-hour waiting period before a woman could get an abortion</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A death penalty habeas corpus appeal to the federal courts that was turned down</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A free speech case where a provision of a congressional act restricting access to obscene sites on the Internet was declared unconstitutional</label>
answers.E: <label>E. A free press case giving school officials greater latitude in censoring school newspapers</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Hypothetical

Choice D, the correct answer, is an application of the definition of judicial activism (those court decisions that overturn precedent or existing law). The choices are all based on actual decisions. Choices A, B, C, and D are all cases that are judicial restraint in nature.

content: A strong federal system of government has which of the following components?

answers.A: <label>A. A central government dominated by the states</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Different levels of government unified by a central government</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Three branches of government each having separate powers</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A parliament with a prime minister as head of the government</label>
answers.E: <label>E. A loosely bound union of states</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Type of Question: Identification/definitional

Choice B, the correct answer, is a major characteristic of a federal form of government. Choices A and E are more typical of a confederation. Choice C can be a part of a federal system but only if there are state governments that are part of the system. Choice D is a parliamentary form of government.

content: According to the Twenty-Fifth Amendment to the Constitution, what happens if a president is disabled when serving in office?

answers.A: <label>A. The House and Senate must vote to allow the vice president to assume power.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The first lady is given temporary power to govern.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The Supreme Court decides when the vice president can take over the office.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. After the cabinet makes a declaration of the president's incapacity to govern, the vice president becomes president.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. There is a special election held to determine who will be the next president.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Type of Question: Identification

Choice D, the correct answer, is the only choice that is a provision of the constitutional amendment that outlines what happens when a president is disabled. The other choices are all factually incorrect.

content: The Supreme Court has determined that racial gerrymandering is unconstitutional because it

answers.A: <label>A. violates the reserve power clause of the Constitution</label>
answers.B: <label>B. deprives elected representatives of their property right</label>
answers.C: <label>C. ignores the one man, one vote principle of a previous Supreme Court ruling</label>
answers.D: <label>D. violates the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment</label>
answers.E: <label>E. extends affirmative action to a point that goes beyond the intent of the Voting Rights Act of 1965</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Type of Question: Sequencing a series of events

Choice E, the correct answer, requires that you know the definition of racial gerrymandering and the historical reasons why it existed. Choice D would be correct if the Court ruled that these districts were constitutional. The other choices are factually incorrect.

content: What constitutional principle allows a president to send combat troops to a foreign country?

answers.A: <label>A. A delegated power to declare war</label>
answers.B: <label>B. An enumerated power to fund the troops</label>
answers.C: <label>C. An implied power as Commander in Chief</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A delegated power as Chief of State</label>
answers.E: <label>E. A delegated power to sign treaties</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Type of Question: Identification

Choice C, the correct answer, reflects the fact that the president's stated power as Commander in Chief must be expanded into an implied power when the president sends troops into combat in a foreign country without Congress declaring war. Choices A and B are incorrect because Congress has the power to declare war and appropriate funds to support troops. Choice D is incorrect because even though the president is considered Chief of State, it is more of a ceremonial role. Choice E is incorrect because, though the president has the power to sign treaties, treaties must be approved by the Senate.

content: American civil liberties were granted by the

answers.A: <label>A. Bill of Rights</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Articles of Confederation</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Declaration of Independence</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Judiciary Article of the United States Constitution</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. The Bill of Rights established basic rights, including freedom of speech, petition, assembly, religion, and the press; the right to bear arms; freedom from unreasonable search and seizure; the right to a speedy and public jury trial; and freedom from cruel and unusual punishment. The Articles of Confederation (B) did not enumerate civil liberties. Although the Declaration of Independence (C) was a statement of the ideals of the new United States, it did not have the force of law and, therefore, did not establish civil liberties. The Judiciary Article (D) grants only the right of trial by jury in federal cases. Marbury v. Madison (E) established the principle of judicial review.

content: The only president to resign from office was

answers.A: <label>A. Calvin Coolidge</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Spiro Agnew</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Lyndon Johnson</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Richard Nixon</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Zachary Taylor</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D. Richard Nixon resigned from office in 1974 as a result of the Watergate scandal. He is the only president to resign thus far. Calvin Coolidge (A) and Lyndon Johnson (C) completed their terms of office. Zachary Taylor (E) died while in office. Spiro Agnew (B) did resign from office, but he was a vice president, not a president.

content:
Impeachment cases must be tried in the

I. Senate only

II. House only

III. Senate and House

IV. Senate and House with the Supreme Court presiding

answers.A: <label>A. IV</label>
answers.B: <label>B. I</label>
answers.C: <label>C. I and II</label>
answers.D: <label>D. II</label>
answers.E: <label>E. III</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. According to the Constitution, the House of Representatives brings charges of impeachment, whereas the Senate tries, or sits in judgment of, impeachment cases.

content: An example of a government corporation would be

answers.A: <label>A. the U.S. Treasury Department</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the U.S. Postal Service</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the U.S. armed forces</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the Internal Revenue Service</label>
answers.E: <label>E. any independent regulatory agency found within the U.S. government</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. The U.S. Postal Service is a government corporation. The U.S. Treasury (A) is a department of the federal government. The armed forces (C) are part of the Defense Department, and the IRS (D) is an independent agency. Independent regulatory agencies (E) are part of the executive branch.

content: Primary elections are held to

answers.A: <label>A. narrow down the field of candidates within a political party</label>
answers.B: <label>B. expand the field of candidates within a political party</label>
answers.C: <label>C. give the voters more choice in the general election</label>
answers.D: <label>D. allow state legislatures the opportunity to determine political districts</label>
answers.E: <label>E. increase participation of third-party candidates</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. Primary elections are "first elections," held to nominate candidates from within a political party. Primary elections narrow the field of party candidates to one (B), giving voters the choice of only one candidate per party in the general election (C). State legislatures do not use primary results to determine political districts (D). Primary elections are among the factors that limit the influence and participation of third-party candidates.

content: The primary purpose of major U.S. political parties is to control government by

answers.A: <label>A. affecting public policy</label>
answers.B: <label>B. defining party principles</label>
answers.C: <label>C. winning elections through peaceful legal actions</label>
answers.D: <label>D. pushing legislation through Congress</label>
answers.E: <label>E. promoting an individual political cause</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. The primary goal of political parties is to seek to control government through the winning of elections. Choice (D) reflects only one aspect of the role of political parties at the national level. The goals of affecting public policy (A), defining party principles (B), and promoting an individual political cause (E) are secondary goals for major U.S. political parties, which are election oriented.

content: The independent regulatory commission responsible for the supervision of the nation's banking system and regulation of the money supply is the

answers.A: <label>A. Federal Trade Commission</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Securities and Exchange Commission</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Consumer Product Safety Commission</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Department of the Treasury</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Federal Reserve System</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E. The Federal Reserve System was created in 1913 to supervise the nation's banking system and to regulate the money supply. The Federal Trade Commission (A) regulates fraudulent trade practices. The Securities and Exchange Commission (B) supervises the exchange of securities to protect investors. The Department of the Treasury (D) is a department, not an independent regulatory commission, of the federal government that collects revenue and administers federal finances. The Consumer Product Safety Commission (C) is an independent regulatory agency that protects the public from faulty consumer products.

content: Senatorial elections

answers.A: <label>A. occur within single-member districts</label>
answers.B: <label>B. attract less media attention than elections of representatives</label>
answers.C: <label>C. promote frequent personal contact with senatorial constituencies</label>
answers.D: <label>D. provide for a continuous body in the Senate</label>
answers.E: <label>E. result in less diverse constituencies than those of representatives</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D. Although senators are elected for six-year terms, senatorial elections are staggered so that only one-third of the Senate is elected every two years. Senators are elected in statewide, at-large elections (A), resulting in a larger and, therefore, more diverse, constituency (E). The prestige of the Senate leads to more media interest (B). Because senators are elected from the entire state, their constituencies are generally more diverse than those of representatives.

content: The Founding Fathers envisioned a president who would fulfill all of the following roles EXCEPT

answers.A: <label>A. a shaper of public opinion</label>
answers.B: <label>B. a check on bills enacted into law</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the head of state</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the commander of the armed forces</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the executor of bills passed by Congress</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. The world of the late 18th century was so limited, and the nature of the U.S. presidency so newly defined, that the founding fathers could not anticipate the extent to which future presidents would use their power to shape public opinion. The Constitution provides for the presidential role as a check on bills enacted into law through the power of the vote (B) and as administrator, or executor, of bills passed by Congress (E). Article II grants the president the command of the armed forces (D). As both the chief executive and the ceremonial head of the United States, the president is head of state (C).

content: Before the Supreme Court hears the oral arguments of a case presented for its review, each side must present written documents supporting that side's legal viewpoint. These written documents are known as

answers.A: <label>A. legal documents</label>
answers.B: <label>B. briefs</label>
answers.C: <label>C. viewpoints of the court</label>
answers.D: <label>D. a prospectus</label>
answers.E: <label>E. a writ</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. Briefs are written documents given to the court to present each side's views on the case. Briefs do not present the viewpoint of the court (C). A legal document (A) states a contractual relationship or grants a right. A prospectus (D) is a document that describes major features of a proposed project, whereas a writ (E) is a legal order requiring a person to do or refrain from a specific act.

content: Which of the following best describes a filibuster?

answers.A: <label>A. A filibuster is an oratorical tactic that can only be used in the Senate.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. A filibuster is an oratorical tactic that can only be used in the House.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It is used in both houses to stop or slow down action on legislation.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It can easily be avoided or stopped.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. It is used quite often by the members of Congress and is usually very successful.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. A filibuster is a stalling tactic used only in the Senate (C, E), where debate is not limited. The House of Representatives limits debate under the authority of the Rules Committee (B). It is difficult to avoid or stop a filibuster because senators are hesitant to place limits on one another (D).

content: Interest groups are most often associated with

answers.A: <label>A. matters of economic interest</label>
answers.B: <label>B. matters of political interest</label>
answers.C: <label>C. military issues</label>
answers.D: <label>D. methods of increasing voter participation</label>
answers.E: <label>E. matters of social interest and value</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. Although interest groups may focus on the subjects mentioned in choices (B) to (E), the largest number of interest groups are based on economic issues.

content: In the United States, the average person's political participation is limited to

answers.A: <label>A. voting in local elections</label>
answers.B: <label>B. a basic understanding of government</label>
answers.C: <label>C. voting in presidential elections</label>
answers.D: <label>D. ignoring government altogether</label>
answers.E: <label>E. working for a political party at some level of government</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. Voting in presidential elections is the method of participation used by the largest number of Americans. Most Americans do not vote in local elections (A) or work for a political party (E). Choice (B) refers to knowledge rather than participation, while choice (D) involves a lack of political participation.

content: The membership of the House of Representatives

answers.A: <label>A. is dependent on the national census</label>
answers.B: <label>B. is a continuous body</label>
answers.C: <label>C. is permanently restricted to 435 members</label>
answers.D: <label>D. is elected in 50 statewide at-large elections</label>
answers.E: <label>E. is apportioned according to the provisions of the New Jersey Plan</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. The number of representatives apportioned to each state depends on the findings of the most recent census. The members of the House of Representatives are elected every two years, preventing a continuous body as in the Senate (B). Congress may vote to alter the "permanent" size of the House (C). Only those states whose population is small enough to allow for only one representative elect representatives in at-large elections; most states elect representatives from single-member districts (D). The Virginia Plan provided for the apportionment of representatives according to population (E).

content: Which of the following is a major defect of the electoral college?

answers.A: <label>A. The Senate, not the people, decides elections for president.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Electors are not legally pledged to their candidate.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Electors are directed by the Constitution as to how to cast their ballot.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The candidate winning the popular vote always wins.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Federal law apportions an equal number of electors to each state.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. Electors are not legally pledged to vote for their candidate and may vote for any candidate (C). If no candidate wins a majority of electoral votes, it is the House, not the Senate, that decides the election (A). The candidate winning the popular vote sometimes loses the election, as in the election of 2000 (D). Each state is apportioned electors according to its number of representatives plus senators (E).

content: In Lemon v. Kurtzman, the court established the Lemon Test. According to this test, which of the following would apply?

answers.A: <label>A. Prayer in public schools is unconstitutional.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Prayer in public schools is constitutional.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Religious freedom is guaranteed by the constitution.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Education laws do not apply to religious freedom.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. State aid must be of a secular purpose if it is to be applied to a church school.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E. The Lemon Test created standards for the establishment clause of the First Amendment, under which state aid given to a church school must be for a secular purpose. Choices (A), (B), (C), and (D) are not included in this court decision.

content: Which of the following is true about the voting process in America?

answers.A: <label>A. The federal government regulates voter registration in all states.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. State governments regulate voter registration within their respective state.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. All individuals over the age of 18 are required to register to vote.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Anyone may vote regardless of registration status.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Local governments are responsible for voter registration laws.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. Voter registration is regulated by state governments (A, E). Registration to vote is not required of anyone in the United States (C); most states, however, require registration in order to vote (D).

content: In order to ratify the Constitution of the United States

answers.A: <label>A. 9 of the 13 states had to approve the document</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the people had to approve the Constitution by popular vote</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the document had to have unanimous approval by all of the states</label>
answers.D: <label>D. a two-thirds vote by both houses of the new government was necessary</label>
answers.E: <label>E. a three-fourths vote of all state legislatures had to approve the document</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. According to Article VII of the Constitution, ratification would occur with the approval of 9 of the 13 states.

content: Which of the following is NOT true about the Senate?

answers.A: <label>A. The most influential member is the Senate majority leader.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Revenue bills cannot be introduced in the Senate.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The Senate works with the president when treaties are involved.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The Senate's larger number makes it more powerful.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The Senate contains 100 members.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D. The Senate (E) has a smaller number of members (100) than the House of Representatives (435). The most influential member is the Senate majority leader, who often also serves as the spokesman for the majority party in the Senate (A). Revenue bills may be introduced only in the House (B). The Senate has the authority to ratify or reject a treaty made by the president (C).

content: The purpose of the Twenty-Second Amendment, passed in 1951, was to

answers.A: <label>A. limit presidential terms of office</label>
answers.B: <label>B. allow the president to choose a vice presidential running mate</label>
answers.C: <label>C. provide more checks and balances on the executive office</label>
answers.D: <label>D. allow voters in the District of Columbia to vote</label>
answers.E: <label>E. allow for presidential impeachment</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. The Twenty-Second Amendment limits the president to two elected terms and not more than ten years in office. The Twenty-Third Amendment allows voters in the District of Columbia to vote in presidential elections (D). No amendments address checks and balances (C), presidential impeachment (E), or the selection of vice-presidential running mates (B).

content: Which of the following presidents appointed the first woman to the Supreme Court of the United States?

answers.A: <label>A. Jimmy Carter</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Bill Clinton</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Ronald Reagan</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Franklin Roosevelt</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Gerald Ford</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. Sandra Day O'Connor, the first woman appointed to the Supreme Court, was appointed by Ronald Reagan in 1981.

content:
Which of the following is a specific power of the House of Representatives?

I. impeachment of the president

II. election of the president when the electoral college fails

III. initiation of revenue bills

answers.A: <label>A. I only</label>
answers.B: <label>B. II only</label>
answers.C: <label>C. III only</label>
answers.D: <label>D. I, II, and III</label>
answers.E: <label>E. I and II</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D. The House of Representatives has the sole power to bring charges of impeachment, elect the president if there is not a majority in the electoral college, and initiate revenue bills.

content: Members of the federal executive bureaucracy tend to represent the interests of

answers.A: <label>A. the president</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the departments in which they work</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the special interests to which they belong</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the political party to which they belong</label>
answers.E: <label>E. themselves</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. A bureaucracy is an organization composed of several levels of authority. It often uses specialization to carry out the tasks of its departments and agencies. Members of the federal bureaucracy tend to represent the departments in which they work rather than the president (A), specialinterest groups (C), political parties (D), or themselves (E).

content: In the United States, the powers of government are divided between a national government, state governments, and several regional and local governments. This system is called

answers.A: <label>A. delegated government</label>
answers.B: <label>B. federalism</label>
answers.C: <label>C. democracy</label>
answers.D: <label>D. republican government</label>
answers.E: <label>E. checks and balances</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. U.S. federalism is the division of governmental powers between national, state, and several regional and local governments. Delegated government (A) receives its powers through a constitution. Democracy (C) is rule by the people. A republican government (D) is one in which the people are ruled by elected representatives. Checks and balances (E) are the limits placed by one branch of the federal government over another.

content: A private organization that attempts to get government officials to respond to its philosophy and way of thinking on particular issues is called a(n)

answers.A: <label>A. pressure group</label>
answers.B: <label>B. political pressure group</label>
answers.C: <label>C. interest group</label>
answers.D: <label>D. political power group</label>
answers.E: <label>E. lobbyist</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. Interest groups are private groups that attempt to pressure government officials to respond to their issue or philosophy. Choices (A), (B), and (D) do not specifically define an interest group. A lobbyist (E) is a representative of a special interest group.

content: The political belief that the president is the steward of the people and should continually act in the best interests of the people is known as the stewardship theory. Which president first promoted this theory?

answers.A: <label>A. Theodore Roosevelt</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Thomas Jefferson</label>
answers.C: <label>C. George Washington</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Franklin Roosevelt</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Woodrow Wilson</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. The progressive president Theodore Roosevelt first promoted the stewardship theory, a concept descriptive of the modern presidency. He articulated this philosophy in his 1913 autobiography.

content: States, which require the winning candidates of each party to have an absolute majority in a primary election, may also require the holding of a(n)

answers.A: <label>A. open primary</label>
answers.B: <label>B. closed primary</label>
answers.C: <label>C. runoff primary</label>
answers.D: <label>D. nonpartisan primary</label>
answers.E: <label>E. direct primary</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. When no candidate receives an absolute majority in a primary, states may require a runoff election between the top candidates. An open primary (A) is one in which any qualified voter may participate. A closed primary (B) is one in which participants must be declared party members. A nonpartisan primary (D) is one in which the candidates do not run on party labels. A direct primary (E) is an election in which voters vote directly for their party's candidates for office.

content: In the United States, the Congress has created two types of federal courts. These courts are

answers.A: <label>A. special and legislative courts</label>
answers.B: <label>B. district and constitutional courts</label>
answers.C: <label>C. constitutional and appellate courts</label>
answers.D: <label>D. constitutional and legislative courts</label>
answers.E: <label>E. district and appellate courts</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D. Constitutional courts are the federal courts created by Congress under Article III of the Constitution. Legislative courts are special courts that hear cases arising from the powers given to Congress under Article I (A). District courts, a type of constitutional court, serve as federal trial courts (B, E). Appellate courts (C), which decide appeals from district courts, are constitutional courts.

content: What right is protected by the Second Amendment of the United States Constitution?

answers.A: <label>A. quarter troops</label>
answers.B: <label>B. bear arms and maintain a militia</label>
answers.C: <label>C. serve in a militia</label>
answers.D: <label>D. petition the federal government</label>
answers.E: <label>E. express and exhibit free speech</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. The Second Amendment provides the right to bear arms. Quartering troops is addressed in the Third Amendment (A). The First Amendment deals with free speech (E) and petitioning the government (D). No amendment addresses the issue of serving in a militia (C).

content: Which of the following is a true statement about political parties in the United States?

answers.A: <label>A. Political parties are addressed in the constitution.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Membership is voluntary and represents a good cross section of the country's population.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Membership is voluntary, but only a small portion of the voting public belongs.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Party membership is strengthening.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Political parties are becoming less diverse in their membership.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. Membership in U.S. political parties is voluntary and represents voters from a variety of geographical regions, ethnic and racial groups, income and educational levels, religions, and ideologies. Political parties are not mentioned in the Constitution, and George Washington was elected to the presidency without membership in a party (A). A large portion of the voting public claims party membership (C). More and more U.S. voters are classifying themselves as independents (D), while members of political parties represent more diverse ideologies (E).

content: An incumbent is a

answers.A: <label>A. first-time office holder</label>
answers.B: <label>B. candidate running for office</label>
answers.C: <label>C. current office holder</label>
answers.D: <label>D. most recently defeated candidate</label>
answers.E: <label>E. candidate with the most votes</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. Incumbents are current office holders.

content: In developing the United States Constitution, which of the following plans called for a strong national government with three separate branches?

answers.A: <label>A. the Virginia Plan</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the New Jersey Plan</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the Connecticut Plan</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the Philadelphia Plan</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the Hamilton Plan</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. The Virginia Plan provided for a strong central government with three branches. The New Jersey Plan (B) called for a weak national government with three separate branches. The Connecticut Compromise (not a proposed plan) created a strong national government with three separate branches (C). There was no Philadelphia Plan (D), and the Hamilton Plan (E) favored a monarch.

content: An interest group, a bureaucratic government agency, and a committee of Congress working together would be an example of

answers.A: <label>A. an iron triangle</label>
answers.B: <label>B. a government corporation</label>
answers.C: <label>C. an issue network</label>
answers.D: <label>D. an independent government agency</label>
answers.E: <label>E. an independent regulatory agency</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. An iron triangle is an alliance that develops between bureaucratic agencies, interest groups, and congressional committees or subcommittees in pursuit of a common goal. A government corporation is created by Congress to carry out businesslike activities (B). An issue network (C) is a group of individuals in Washington who regularly discuss and advocate public policies. An independent executive agency (D) is similar to a department but has no cabinet status. An independent regulatory agency (E) is one that is created to regulate or police.

content: The purpose of a poll watcher is to

answers.A: <label>A. direct the voter to the proper polling station</label>
answers.B: <label>B. help the election judge count the votes</label>
answers.C: <label>C. determine exit poll results</label>
answers.D: <label>D. ensure the election process at the poll is fair and honest</label>
answers.E: <label>E. ensure that enough ballots are on hand to meet the needs of voter turnout</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D. A poll watcher is a representative of a political party or candidate who ensures that the election process is fair and honest. Election judges and other election officials direct voters (A), help count votes (B), and ensure that enough ballots are on hand (E). Political pollsters determine exit poll results (C).

content: The president's cabinet is designed to

answers.A: <label>A. issue executive orders</label>
answers.B: <label>B. negotiate executive agreements</label>
answers.C: <label>C. run the executive branch of the government</label>
answers.D: <label>D. set the president's agenda before the Congress</label>
answers.E: <label>E. both advise the president and administer a department of government</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E. The president's cabinet advises the president; each secretary administers a department of the government. Only the president has the power to issue executive orders (A), negotiate executive agreements (B), run the executivebranch (C), and set his agenda before the Congress (D).

content: Which of the following terms best describes the legislative tactic of acquiring funds or projects for a Congressman's home district?

answers.A: <label>A. logrolling</label>
answers.B: <label>B. pork barrel legislation</label>
answers.C: <label>C. gerrymandering</label>
answers.D: <label>D. congressional campaigning</label>
answers.E: <label>E. lobbying</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. Pork barrel legislation is the term for a member of Congress acquiring funds or projects for his or her home district. Logrolling (A) is an attempt by members of Congress to gain the support of other members for their support of the congressperson's legislation. Gerrymandering (C) involves drawing congressional districts to favor one political party or group over another. Congressional campaigning (D) is the act of running for Congress. Lobbying (E) is the attempt of interest groups to support or reject legislation.

content: What is the total current membership of the electoral college?

answers.A: <label>A. 435</label>
answers.B: <label>B. 535</label>
answers.C: <label>C. 538</label>
answers.D: <label>D. 438</label>
answers.E: <label>E. 270</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. The electoral college is composed of 538 members, with each state having the same number of electors as the sum of its representatives and senators. The Twenty-Third Amendment provides that Washington, D.C., shall have the same number of electors as the smallest stateâ€”three.
