content: How many courts of appeals are there in the federal court system?

answers.A: <label>A. 1</label>
answers.B: <label>B. 90</label>
answers.C: <label>C. 6</label>
answers.D: <label>D. 3</label>
answers.E: <label>E. 12</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E. There are 12 courts of appeals in the federal court system.

content: Adding amendments to the United States Constitution is a two-step process that includes

answers.A: <label>A. proposal by the United States House of Representatives and ratification by the Senate</label>
answers.B: <label>B. proposal by the United States Senate and ratification by the House of Representatives</label>
answers.C: <label>C. proposal and ratification by both houses of Congress</label>
answers.D: <label>D. proposal by the United States Congress and ratification by the states</label>
answers.E: <label>E. proposal by the executive branch and ratification by the legislative branch</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D. Amending the Constitution requires Congress to propose amendments by a two-thirds vote in both houses. The proposed amendment must then be ratified by the state legislatures of three-fourths of the states or by conventions held in three-fourths of the states. Another method of amendment allows Congress to call a national convention when requested by three-fourths of the state legislatures. This convention then initiates the process by proposing the amendment. To date a national convention has not been called to propose an amendment.

content: Each state in the House of Representatives is allowed a certain number of representatives. That number is determined by:

answers.A: <label>A. the population of each state</label>
answers.B: <label>B. constitutional amendment</label>
answers.C: <label>C. presidential mandate</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the number of electors each state has in the electoral college</label>
answers.E: <label>E. a number called for in the Constitution of each state</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. The Constitution requires that a state's representation in the House of Representatives be based on the population of the state.

content: In the case of a tie vote in the electoral college during the selection of the president, who is charged with electing the president?

answers.A: <label>A. Senate</label>
answers.B: <label>B. House of Representatives</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Supreme Court</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Senate and Supreme Court</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Supreme Court and House of Representatives</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. According to the Constitution, if the electoral college fails to choose a president, the House of Representatives is charged with choosing the president.

content: Which of the following is an executive power of the Senate?

answers.A: <label>A. reviewing presidential vetoes</label>
answers.B: <label>B. trying impeachment cases</label>
answers.C: <label>C. keeping a check on the House of Representatives</label>
answers.D: <label>D. proposing constitutional amendments</label>
answers.E: <label>E. approving appointments and treaties</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E. Approving appointments and treaties are executive powers of the Senate because they are used in conjunction with a power of the president. Reviewing presidential vetoes (A) and proposing constitutional amendments (D) are two of the Senate's legislative powers. Trying impeachment cases (B) is a nonlegislative power of the Senate. The Senate does not check the power of the House of Representatives (C).

content: Which of the following Supreme Court cases established the principle of judicial review in the American court system?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. Marbury v. Madison (1803) established the principle of judicial review. McCulloch v. Maryland (1819) upheld the power of the national government by denying the right of a state to tax the Bank of the United States (A). Gibbons v. Ogden (1824) upheld the power of the national government over interstate commerce (B). Mapp v. Ohio (1961) extended the Fourth Amendment's protection against unreasonable searches and seizures to the states as well as to the national government (D). Miranda v. Arizona (1966) held that the Fifth Amendment requires that a person arrested for a crime must be advised of his or her right to remain silent and to have an attorney present (E).

content: Which of the following best describes a public interest group?

answers.A: <label>A. A public interest group seeks to benefit its self-interest.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. A public interest group seeks to benefit the nation as a whole rather than its self-interest.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A public interest group seeks to destroy government bureaucracy.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A public interest group seeks to provide information to certain groups within the Congress.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. A public interest group seeks to win the support of the president.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. A public interest group, such as Common Cause or Mothers Against Drunk Driving, seeks to benefit the nation as a whole. Public interest groups are concerned with issues such as the environment, consumer protection, crime, and civil rights.

content: While the president has the power to make appointments, he or she also has the power to remove some appointed officials from office. Where in the United States Constitution is this power located?

answers.A: <label>A. Article I</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Article II</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Article III</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Article IV</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Article V</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. Article II of the Constitution addresses the powers of the president.

content: What is the minimum age requirement for a member of the House of Representatives?

answers.A: <label>A. 25</label>
answers.B: <label>B. 30</label>
answers.C: <label>C. 35</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The same age requirement as for the president</label>
answers.E: <label>E. There is no minimum age requirement</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. The minimum age for a member of the House of Representatives is 25.

content: Which court was considered to be the most liberal court of the 20th century?

answers.A: <label>A. Warren Court</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Burger Court</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Marshall Court</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Taney Court</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Taft Court</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. Because of its decisions that expanded the rights of criminal defendants, the Supreme Court under Chief Justice Earl Warren is often considered the most liberal court of the 20th century. While the Burger court (B) was responsible for liberal decisions in Roe v. Wade and U.S. v. Nixon, it is generally considered a more conservative court for its narrowing of the rights of defendants. The Taft Court (E) was a conservative court. The Marshall (C) and Taney (D) courts were 19th-century courts.

content: The civil service system in the United States was created by

answers.A: <label>A. the Constitution</label>
answers.B: <label>B. executive order</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the Pendleton Act</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the Hatch Act</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the Civil Service Act of 1850</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. The Pendleton Act (1883) created the U.S. civil service system.

content: A primary election open only to the known voters of a political party would best be described as a(n)

answers.A: <label>A. open primary</label>
answers.B: <label>B. indirect primary</label>
answers.C: <label>C. blanket primary</label>
answers.D: <label>D. wide-open primary</label>
answers.E: <label>E. closed primary</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E. A primary election would best be described as a closed primary if only the known members of a political party were able to participate. In an open primary (A), voters may choose candidates of either party, whether they belong to that party or not. In a blanket primary (C), voters may choose the candidates of either party, voting fora Republican for one office and a Democrat for another. The wide-open primary (D) is another term for the blanket primary. "Indirect" is not a term used to describe primaries (B).

content: How many judges currently serve on the Supreme Court?

answers.A: <label>A. six</label>
answers.B: <label>B. nine</label>
answers.C: <label>C. four</label>
answers.D: <label>D. ten</label>
answers.E: <label>E. five</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. There are currently nine justices on the Supreme Courtâ€”a chief justice and eight associate justices.

content: Which of the following is NOT true of the seniority rule?

answers.A: <label>A. The seniority rule ignores ability.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The seniority rule discourages hard work.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The seniority rule is not as important today as in the past.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The seniority rule is significant in the selection of committee chairpersons.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The seniority rule allows the most qualified individual to be selected for the job.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E. The seniority rule is the custom that the chair of a congressional committee is awarded to the member of the majority party with the longest participation on the committee. The use of the seniority rule does not require the selection of the most qualified individual to be chosen as a committee chairperson.

content: Which of the following is NOT an accurate description of the president's ability to deal with the Congress?

answers.A: <label>A. In dealing with Congress, the president works under a system of checks and balances.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The president must work with political party influences in Congress.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The president is able to enact legislation that he or she deems necessary.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The president may veto acts of Congress.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The president must work with Congress on issues important to both branches of the government.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. The president is only able to suggest legislation. Congress must pass bills enacting legislation.

content: If a special session of Congress is necessary after Congress has adjourned, who has the power to call Congress back into session?

answers.B: <label>B. the president</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the vice president by virtue of position in the Senate</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the members of Congress</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the members of the House and Senate Special Session Committee</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. Only the president may call special sessions of Congress.

content: When a case is appealed to the Supreme Court of the United States on the request of a lower court that is not sure on the point of law, the lower court must present a(n)

answers.A: <label>A. certificate</label>
answers.B: <label>B. appeal</label>
answers.C: <label>C. writ of assistance</label>
answers.E: <label>E. brief solicitation</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. Appealing a case to the Supreme Court because a lower court is unsure on a point of law requires the presentation of a certificate. An appeal (B) is a case brought to a higher court from a lower court. A writ of assistance (C) was a document that allowed British officers to search a premise. A writ of certiorari (D) is a document from a superior court demanding the record of a case from an inferior court. A brief solicitation (E) is a request for a written argument presented to a court.

content: Which U.S. president held the most press conferences?

answers.A: <label>A. Richard Nixon</label>
answers.B: <label>B. George Bush</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Jimmy Carter</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Franklin Roosevelt</label>
answers.E: <label>E. John Kennedy</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D. Franklin Delano Roosevelt held the most press conferences, partly because of his long tenure in office and the national emergencies of the times.

content: The size of the House of Representatives is determined by

answers.A: <label>A. the president</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Congress</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the Constitution</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the population of the states</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the Supreme Court</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. Congress determines the size of the House of Representatives through the passage of legislation. The Reapportionment Act of 1929 established the current size at 435 members. Although each state's membership in the House is determined by population, changes in population distribution are resolved by reapportionment, thus maintaining the current size of the House at 435 members.

content: Bicameralism is

answers.A: <label>A. a legislative body dominated by two major political parties</label>
answers.B: <label>B. a legislative body composed of one house</label>
answers.C: <label>C. a legislative body composed of two houses</label>
answers.D: <label>D. a legislative body that shares power with a judiciary</label>
answers.E: <label>E. a legislative body that shares power with an executive</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. Bicameralism describes a legislative body composed of two houses, such as the United States Congress.

content: "A President's power originates in his ability to persuade others." This statement can best be attributed to which of the following individuals?

answers.A: <label>A. James David Barber</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Bill Clinton</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Richard Neustadt</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Richard Nixon</label>
answers.E: <label>E. John Locke</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. The quotation is attributed to Richard Neustadt.

content: The political party system in the United States is based on the principle of a(n)

answers.A: <label>A. multi-party system</label>
answers.B: <label>B. single-member district system</label>
answers.C: <label>C. moderate-liberal system</label>
answers.D: <label>D. independent system</label>
answers.E: <label>E. two-party system</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E. The United States operates under a two-party system, with only two major parties having a reasonable chance of winning elections. A single-member district (B) is an electoral district from which voters choose one person for each elected office.

content: The Supreme Court of the United States has both original and appellate jurisdiction. The court usually hears cases on appeal and decides only a few cases each year. Who decides which cases the court will hear?

answers.A: <label>A. the chief justice of the Supreme Court</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the members of the Supreme Court as a group</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the attorney general of the United States</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the solicitor general of the United States</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the chief associate judge of the Supreme Court</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. The justices of the Supreme Court, using the rule of four, decide which cases they will consider. According to the rule of four, four of the nine justices must agree to hear the case.

content: In the Supreme Court case of Mapp v. Ohio, the Court ruled that

answers.A: <label>A. police acting in good faith, with a legal warrant, may present evidence in court</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment applies to illegal searches</label>
answers.C: <label>C. searches of criminal suspects are constitutional</label>
answers.D: <label>D. evidence may be used in court if the evidence would have been inevitably discovered</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the exclusionary rule does not apply to cases tried in state courts</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. The case of Mapp v. Ohio is among several cases that established the exclusionary rule of evidence (evidence seized in an illegal search may not be used in a court of law). Mapp v. Ohio also applied the exclusionary rule to state courts (E). Choice (A) refers to United States v. Leon. In Wolf v. Colorado, the Court applied protections against unreasonable search and seizure to the states under the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment (B). Also, in Terry v. Ohio the Court ruled that searches of criminal suspects are constitutional (B). The Court established the inevitable discovery rule in Nix v. Williams (D).

content: If the United States government were to be sued, to which court(s) would those seeking damages take their case to be heard?

answers.A: <label>A. U.S. District Courts</label>
answers.B: <label>B. U.S. Supreme Court</label>
answers.C: <label>C. U.S. Courts of Appeals</label>
answers.D: <label>D. U.S. Tax Court</label>
answers.E: <label>E. U.S. Court of Claims</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E. Cases against the U.S. government are heard in the U.S. Court of Claims. The U.S. District Courts (A) have original jurisdiction and serve as trial courts at the federal level. The Supreme Court (B) is the final authority dealing with all questions arising from the Constitution, federal laws, and treaties. The U.S. Courts of Appeals (C) decide appeals from U.S. district courts and review decisions of federal administrative agencies. The U.S. Tax Court (D) is a special court within the federal judicial system.

content:
What method of floor vote is used in the passage of a bill in both houses of Congress?

I. voice vote

II. standing vote

III. roll-call vote

IV. teller vote

V. electronic vote

answers.A: <label>A. I only</label>
answers.B: <label>B. II only</label>
answers.C: <label>C. III only</label>
answers.D: <label>D. I, II, III</label>
answers.E: <label>E. IV and V only</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D. Voting on legislation in both houses of Congress may be by voice, standing, or roll-call vote. The House of Representatives also uses teller and electronic voting; the Senate does not.

content: A constitutional duty of the vice president is to

answers.A: <label>A. work with the Supreme Court on constitutional issues</label>
answers.B: <label>B. preside over the Senate and break tie votes</label>
answers.C: <label>C. balance the ticket</label>
answers.D: <label>D. preside over the House of Representatives and break tie votes</label>
answers.E: <label>E. issue directives, on the president's order, to the political parties</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. According to the Constitution, the duty of the vice president is to preside over the Senate and vote only in the case of a tie (D). The vice president does not work with the Supreme Court (A), nor does he or she issue directives to the political parties (E). The president often chooses the vice presidential running mate to balance the ticket. Balancing the ticket, however, is not a constitutional role of the vice president (C).

content: The United States Constitution has been amended

answers.A: <label>A. 27 times</label>
answers.B: <label>B. 26 times</label>
answers.C: <label>C. 17 times</label>
answers.D: <label>D. originally only 10 times including the Bill of Rights</label>
answers.E: <label>E. 28 times</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. There are 27 formal amendments to the U.S. Constitution.

content: The first woman appointed to the Supreme Court of the United States was

answers.A: <label>A. Sandra Day O'Connor</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Ruth Bader Ginsburg</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Barbara Jordan</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Jeannette Rankin</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Geraldine Ferraro</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. Sandra Day O'Connor was appointed in 1981 by President Ronald Reagan as the first woman on the Supreme Court. Ruth Bader Ginsburg (B) is the Court's second woman Supreme Court justice. Barbara Jordan (C) was a member of the U.S. House of Representatives from Texas. Jeannette Rankin (D) was the first woman elected to the U.S. Congress. Geraldine Ferraro (E) is a former member of the U.S. House of Representatives and the first woman to run for vice president from a major political party.

content:
Which of the following is a function that political parties are expected to perform?

I. nominate candidates for office

II. politically educate the electorate

III. create a sense of centralized responsibility

IV. maintain the separation of powers in government

answers.A: <label>A. I and III only</label>
answers.B: <label>B. I, II, III, and IV</label>
answers.C: <label>C. III and IV only</label>
answers.D: <label>D. I, II, and III only</label>
answers.E: <label>E. I only</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D. Political parties nominate candidates for office, politically educate the electorate, and help create a sense of centralized responsibility. The U.S. Constitution provided for the separation of powers before the entrance of parties onto the U.S. political scene.

content: Regulating securities, financial markets, and investment companies, and prohibiting fraud and dishonest investment practices would be the major functions of which of the following independent regulatory agencies?

answers.A: <label>A. the Federal Reserve</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Federal Trade Commission</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Commodity Futures Trading Commission</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Securities and Exchange Commission</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Consumer Product Safety Commission</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D. The Securities and Exchange Commission was created as an independent regulatory agency to regulate securities, financial markets, and investment companies, and to prohibit fraud and dishonest investment practices. The Federal Reserve (A) regulates the lending practices of banks and the nation's money supply. The Federal Trade Commission (B) regulates misleading and false trade practices. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission (C) is an independent agency that monitors the trading of futures contracts. The Consumer Product Safety Commission (E) is an independent regulatory agency that regulates the sale and manufacture of consumer products.

content: Which of the following would be a true statement if a presidential election had to be decided by the House of Representatives?

answers.A: <label>A. Each member of the House is allowed one vote.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Each state's delegation casts one vote.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Only the speaker votes.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The House votes as a single unit.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The House Rules Committee makes the decision.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. If the House of Representatives were to act upon the failure of the electoral college to elect a president, each state delegation would receive one vote. A majority of 26 votes would be necessary for a candidate to win election.

content: Which of the following is most accurate regarding interest groups?

answers.A: <label>A. Interest groups always provide accurate and concise information.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Some interest groups have influence that is not proportional to their size.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Interest groups attempt to control government.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Interest groups are well financed.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Interest groups undermine the goals of the American political system.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. Some interest groups have influence that is not proportional to the group's number of members. Some interest groups are small in membership and exert considerable influence, while other groups with large memberships may exert very little influence. Interest groups sometimes distort facts to sway the public toward their cause (A). They seek to influence the policies of government, while political parties attempt to control government (C). Interest groups vary in their degree of financial support (D). They provide channels for political participation that enable citizens to work together to achieve a common goal (E).

content: The Necessary and Proper Clause found in Article I, Section 8 of the United States Constitution is also known as the

answers.A: <label>A. elastic clause</label>
answers.B: <label>B. expressed clause</label>
answers.C: <label>C. implied clause</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the general practice clause of Congress</label>
answers.E: <label>E. congressional clause</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. The Necessary and Proper Clause is often termed the "elastic clause" because it stretches the powers of Congress.

content: Which of the following is a qualification required in order to be president of the United States?

answers.A: <label>A. naturalized citizen</label>
answers.B: <label>B. 30 years of age</label>
answers.C: <label>C. natural-born citizen</label>
answers.D: <label>D. previous experience in government</label>
answers.E: <label>E. resident of the United States for at least nine years</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. In order to be eligible to be elected president of the United States, a candidate must be a natural-born citizen. Other qualifications include being at least 35 years of age and having lived in the United States for at least 14 years.

content: Which of the following is the best definition of political socialization?

answers.A: <label>A. individuals playing different political roles in society</label>
answers.B: <label>B. individuals with diverse beliefs about public policy</label>
answers.C: <label>C. individuals with diverse sets of values and beliefs about public policy</label>
answers.D: <label>D. individuals acquiring their differing beliefs and political orientation</label>
answers.E: <label>E. individuals defining their political society in relation to their form of government</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D. Political socialization involves personal acquisition of differing beliefs and political ideology.

content: Which of the following is a right that would not be guaranteed to a noncitizen?

answers.A: <label>A. freedom of speech</label>
answers.B: <label>B. freedom of religion</label>
answers.C: <label>C. freedom of press</label>
answers.D: <label>D. right to an attorney</label>
answers.E: <label>E. freedom to move about the country</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E. Noncitizens are not guaranteed the freedom to move about the country, while citizens of the United States have this right under the Privileges and Immunities Clause of Article IV of the Constitution. The freedoms of speech (A), religion (B), and the press (C) are guaranteed to all persons by the First Amendment. The right to an attorney (D) is granted to accused persons through Supreme Court decisions in Powell v. Alabama, Betts v. Brady, Escobedo v. Illinois, and Gideon v. Wainwright.

content: In order for a case to be heard in the Supreme Court of the United States, a consensus must be reached among the justices. This agreement is known as:

answers.B: <label>B. a precedent</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the rule of four</label>
answers.E: <label>E. a certificate</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D. In order for cases to be heard by the Supreme Court, the "rule of four" requires that at least four of the justices agree to place the case on the Court's docket. A writ of certiorari (A) is an order issued by the Supreme Court directing a lower court to send up a record of a case for review. A precedent (B) is an example set by a court decision for future court cases. An amicus curiae (C) is a "friend of the court" brief. A certificate (E) is a query from a lower court to the Supreme Court regarding a rule of law or a procedure.

content: Which of the following would be a true statement regarding judicial review and the power of the court to declare an act of government unconstitutional?

answers.A: <label>A. Only federal courts hold this power.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. All federal courts and most state courts hold this power.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. All federal courts and all state courts hold this power.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Most federal courts and most state courts hold this power.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Only the Supreme Court of the United States holds this power.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. All federal and most state courts have the power of judicial review. Municipal courts are one type of court that does not have the power of judicial review.

content: The executive department charged with the administration of the largest entitlement program in the United States is

answers.A: <label>A. Health and Human Services</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Homeland Security</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Veterans Affairs</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Labor</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Education</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. The Department of Health and Human Services administers the Social Security program, which is the most extensive entitlement program in the United States. Homeland Security (B) prevents terrorist attacks in the United States. It includes the Coast Guard, Secret Service, Border Patrol, Immigration and Visa Services, and FEMA. The Department of Veterans Affairs (C) promotes the welfare of veterans of the armed forces. The Department of Labor (D) enforces federal labor laws and administers unemployment programs. The Department of Education (E) administers federal aid programs to schools.

content: Presidential impeachment

answers.A: <label>A. requires a majority vote of the Senate for conviction</label>
answers.B: <label>B. exemplifies the concept of checks and balances</label>
answers.C: <label>C. is the removal of a president from office</label>
answers.D: <label>D. is presided over by the vice president</label>
answers.E: <label>E. allows the Senate to bring charges against the president</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. In the impeachment process the House checks the power of the executive branch by bringing charges of impeachment against the president (E). The chief justice of the Supreme Court sits as the presiding judge in the impeachment trial, thus checking the power of the legislative branch over the executive branch (D). A two-thirds vote of the Senate is required for conviction (A). Impeachment is the act of bringing charges against the president; it may or may not result in conviction and the subsequent removal of the president from office (C).

content: A group of individuals seeking to control government by winning an election and placing a candidate in office would best be described as a(n)

answers.A: <label>A. caucus</label>
answers.B: <label>B. political party</label>
answers.C: <label>C. interest group</label>
answers.D: <label>D. political action committee</label>
answers.E: <label>E. constituency</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. In the United States, a political party is a group of individuals that seeks to control government by winning elections. A caucus (A) is a state meeting to select delegates who, in turn, nominate candidates to political offices. An interest group (C) has no legal status in the election process. Political action committees (D) are the political arms of interest groups. A constituency (E) is the group of people in a state or district that a member of Congress represents.

content: In order to get elected to the Congress, the most significant advantage is

answers.A: <label>A. incumbency</label>
answers.B: <label>B. an endorsement by a major business or community leader</label>
answers.C: <label>C. financial support</label>
answers.D: <label>D. knowledge of the workings of government</label>
answers.E: <label>E. military service</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. Although choices (B), (C), (D), and (E) may contribute to the success of a congressional candidate, the most significant advantage is incumbency. Name recognition, claiming credit for projects, providing casework for constituents, greater media exposure, and fundraising abilities are all advantages of incumbents during an election.

content: Constitutional amendments may be ratified by

answers.A: <label>A. state conventions called by Congress</label>
answers.B: <label>B. a national convention</label>
answers.C: <label>C. a two-thirds vote of each house of the Congress</label>
answers.D: <label>D. legislatures of three-fourths of the states</label>
answers.E: <label>E. legislatures of two-thirds of the states</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D. One method of ratification of constitutional amendments is by the state legislatures in three-fourths of the states (E). A second method of ratification is by special conventions held in three-fourths of the states. These conventions are called by the states, not by Congress (A). Amendments may be proposed by a national convention (B) or by a two-thirds vote of both houses of Congress (C).

content: Justices of the Supreme Court and the lower federal courts serve for a period of

answers.A: <label>A. 25 years</label>
answers.B: <label>B. time determined by the president</label>
answers.C: <label>C. life, during good behavior</label>
answers.D: <label>D. time determined by Congress</label>
answers.E: <label>E. 4 years</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. Federal judges, including Supreme Court justices, serve for a period of life, during good behavior. They may be removed from office only through the impeachment process.

content: James Madison applied the term "faction" to

answers.A: <label>A. political parties and interest groups</label>
answers.B: <label>B. negative members of Congress</label>
answers.C: <label>C. splinter groups of the executive</label>
answers.D: <label>D. political parties</label>
answers.E: <label>E. states not willing to be a part of the federal union</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. In Federalist #10, James Madison referred to factions, meaning political parties and interest groups.

content: The general beliefs that the American public has about politics and policy issues can best be defined as

answers.A: <label>A. political socialization</label>
answers.B: <label>B. public policy</label>
answers.C: <label>C. policy formulation</label>
answers.D: <label>D. political ideology</label>
answers.E: <label>E. public opinion</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E. Public opinion is the belief that the general public has about politics and public policy issues. Political socialization (A) is the complex process by which people get their sense of political identity, beliefs, and values. Public policy (B) is the exercise of governmental power in doing those things necessary to maintain legitimate authority and control over society. Policy formulation (C) is the crafting of a policy to resolve public problems. Political ideology (D) is a consistent set of beliefs about politics and public policy that sets the framework for evaluating government and public policy.

content: Which of the following is NOT a check on the power of the executive branch?

answers.A: <label>A. executive agreements</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the power of the purse</label>
answers.C: <label>C. judicial review of executive actions</label>
answers.D: <label>D. public opinion</label>
answers.E: <label>E. approval powers over appointments</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. Executive agreements are pacts made between the president and other heads of state. Unlike treaties, executive agreements do not require Senate approval. The power of the purse (B) is the fact that agency budgets must be authorized and appropriated by Congress. Judicial review of executive actions (C) is the power to declare executive actions unconstitutional. Public opinion may act as a check on presidential actions (D). Presidential appointments must be approved by a two-thirds vote of the Senate (E).

content: After a proposed bill has had its first reading, what is generally the next step that a bill might encounter?

answers.A: <label>A. The proposed bill is reviewed by an investigating committee.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The proposed bill is sent to the president.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The proposed bill is sent to a standing committee.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The proposed bill is vetoed by the president.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The proposed bill is voted on by the entire Congress.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. After a bill is introduced, which is considered the first reading, it is then sent to the appropriate standing committee for review. The correct order for the remaining choices is A (if further information on the bill is necessary), E, B, and D.

content: Which of the following is true of the constitutional provision regarding the electoral college?

answers.A: <label>A. Each presidential electoral casts two ballots.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. State legislatures with the help of the electoral college choose the president.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Electoral ballots are cast along political party lines.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Electors are bound by federal law to vote for their party's candidate.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Electors are bound by state law to vote for their party's candidate.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. According to the Twelfth Amendment, each elector casts two ballots, one for president and another for vice president. State legislatures do not have a role in the choice of the president (B). Although not a constitutional provision, electoral votes are cast according to the state popular vote (C). Although electors are not bound by federal law to vote for their party's candidate (D), the laws of a few states bind electors to vote according to the popular vote (E).

content: Which of the following is NOT a correct statement regarding interest groups?

answers.A: <label>A. Interest groups sometimes form coalitions to strengthen their influence.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Federal law requires political action committees to donate to several candidates.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Interest groups seek to improve their image by appealing to the public.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Interest groups concentrate on influencing Congress without involving the courts.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. In recent years lobbying has become increasingly more regulated.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D. Interest groups often take an issue to court if they are unsuccessful in gaining the support of Congress. The remaining answer choices are true regarding interest groups.

content: Sometimes litigants that are not part of the formal proceeding of Supreme Court oral arguments wish to have their points of view presented. They may file what is known as a(n)

answers.B: <label>B. certificate</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D. Amicus curiae briefs are filed by "friends of the court," interested parties who have no standing in the case but who wish to provide information and opinions to the court for consideration. A per curiam decision (A) is one delivered by the court as a whole. A certificate (B) is a method of bringing a case before the Supreme Court. A writ of certiorari (C) is an order by a higher court directing a lower court to provide the record in a case for review. Stare decisis (E) is the doctrine that a trial court is bound by the decisions of appellate courts.

content: Which of the following is NOT a basic principle of government found in the Constitution?

answers.A: <label>A. popular sovereignty</label>
answers.B: <label>B. conservatism</label>
answers.C: <label>C. limited government</label>
answers.D: <label>D. judicial review</label>
answers.E: <label>E. federalism</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. Conservatism, or the belief that big government infringes on personal liberties, is not a principle found in the Constitution. Popular sovereignty (A) is the concept that government exists with the consent of the governed. Limited government (C) is the principle that governmental power is restricted. Judicial review (D), one aspect of the principle of checks and balances, is the power of courts to determine the constitutionality of legislative and executive actions. Federalism (E) is the division of powers between a national government and several regional governments.

content: Which of the following would best describe gerrymandering?

answers.A: <label>A. a group of Congress members teaming together in order to get legislation passed</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the breakdown of a political party within the Congress</label>
answers.C: <label>C. dividing the states into regional electoral districts</label>
answers.D: <label>D. dividing states along party lines in order to determine party strategy</label>
answers.E: <label>E. drawing electoral districts within a state in order to favor a political party or candidate</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E. The drawing of electoral districts within a state in order to favor one political party or candidate is known as gerrymandering. The other answer choices do not describe gerrymandering.

content: The political theory proposed by John Locke, calling for a nation to be developed as a voluntary agreement between citizens and government, is known as the

answers.A: <label>A. divine right theory</label>
answers.B: <label>B. hyperpluralist theory</label>
answers.C: <label>C. social contract theory</label>
answers.D: <label>D. state theory</label>
answers.E: <label>E. elite theory</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. The social contract theory, based on the writings of John Locke and supported by Thomas Jefferson in the Declaration of Independence, calls for a voluntary agreement between citizens and government. The divine right theory (A) was the traditional European belief that monarchs derived their power to govern from God. Hyperpluralism (B) views democracy as a system of many groups pulling government in many directions at the same time. The elite theory (E) holds that governmental power is in the hands of a small powerful elite. There is no state theory (D).

content: The power of the Supreme Court to determine the constitutionality of a law passed by Congress is called

answers.A: <label>A. judicial review</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Supreme Court review</label>
answers.C: <label>C. constitutional review</label>
answers.D: <label>D. congressional review</label>
answers.E: <label>E. special review</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. Judicial review allows a court to act on the constitutionality of a law passed by Congress. The Supreme Court established this principle in Marbury v. Madison (1803).

content: Independent agencies that are usually beyond the reach of presidential control are called

answers.A: <label>A. independent regulatory commissions</label>
answers.B: <label>B. executive agencies</label>
answers.C: <label>C. independent executive agencies</label>
answers.D: <label>D. government corporations</label>
answers.E: <label>E. independent government agencies</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. Independent regulatory commissions are created to act independently of presidential control.

content: Which of the following is NOT an expressed presidential power found in the United States Constitution?

answers.A: <label>A. making appointments</label>
answers.B: <label>B. commander of the military</label>
answers.C: <label>C. treaty making</label>
answers.D: <label>D. budget management</label>
answers.E: <label>E. granting pardons</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D. The Constitution does not delegate management of the federal budget to the president. The Constitution does grant the president the powers of making appointments (A) and treaties (C), both with the consent of the Senate. The president is the commander-in-chief of the armed forces (B). The Constitution also gives the president the power to grant pardons (E).

content: Which of the following stages generally occurs earliest in the presidential election contest?

answers.A: <label>A. national party conventions</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the popular election</label>
answers.C: <label>C. state primaries and caucuses</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the electoral college election</label>
answers.E: <label>E. choosing a running mate</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. State primaries and caucuses generally occur earliest in the presidential election contest. The next stage is usually the national party convention (A) and selection of the running mate (E). The next stage is the popular election (B) followed by the electoral college election (D).

content:
Which of the following are types of opinions that may be submitted by the justices when the Supreme Court reaches a decision in a case?

I. majority opinion

II. concurring opinion

III. dissenting opinion

IV. concluding opinion

answers.A: <label>A. I only</label>
answers.B: <label>B. I, II, and III only</label>
answers.C: <label>C. II and IV only</label>
answers.D: <label>D. II and III only</label>
answers.E: <label>E. I, II, III, and IV</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. The majority opinion is submitted by those justices who agree with the Court's majority decision. A concurring opinion is submitted by a justice or justices who agree with the majority decision but have different reasons for doing so. A dissenting opinion is submitted by a justice or justices who disagree with the majority opinion. All three may be submitted to explain the decisions of the Court.

content: The most effective tool of any interest group wishing to influence the workings of government is

answers.A: <label>A. the political party</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the American voter</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the lobbyist</label>
answers.D: <label>D. propaganda</label>
answers.E: <label>E. grassroots organizations</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. Lobbyists serve interest groups by trying to bring influence on the workings of government.

content: All of the following are strategies typically used by successful interest groups EXCEPT

answers.A: <label>A. engaging in acts of civil disobedience and violence</label>
answers.B: <label>B. litigation</label>
answers.C: <label>C. creating coalitions with other interest groups</label>
answers.D: <label>D. contributing to political candidates through political action committees</label>
answers.E: <label>E. bringing grassroots pressures on legislators</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. Successful interest groups usually employ tactics and strategies other than civil disobedience or violence. The remaining answer choices are methods frequently used by interest groups.

content: Poll taxes were fees paid by individuals in order to vote. Which amendment in the United States Constitution outlaws this practice?

answers.A: <label>A. Twentieth Amendment</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Eighteenth Amendment</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Twenty-First Amendment</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Twenty-Fifth Amendment</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Twenty-Fourth Amendment</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E. The Twenty-Fourth Amendment abolished the poll tax. The Twentieth Amendment (A) set the dates of the terms of the president and vice president and of the sessions of Congress. The Eighteenth Amendment (B) established prohibition, while the Twenty-First Amendment (C) repealed prohibition. The Twenty-Fifth Amendment (D) dealt with presidential succession.

content: Which of the following is NOT a role of the members of Congress?

answers.A: <label>A. constituent servant</label>
answers.B: <label>B. gatekeeper</label>
answers.C: <label>C. policymaker</label>
answers.D: <label>D. delegate</label>
answers.E: <label>E. trustee</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. Gatekeepers are media executives, news editors, and prominent reporters who decide what news to present and how it will be presented. The remaining answer choices represent roles of the members of Congress. A constituent servant (A) is a representative who is interested in assisting constituents with problems. As a policymaker (C), a member of Congress makes public policy through the passage of legislation. A delegate (D) is a representative whose vote is based on the wishes of constituents. A trustee (E) is a representative who, after listening to constituents, votes based on his or her own opinions.

content: Amnesty would fall under which power of the president?

answers.A: <label>A. ordinance power</label>
answers.B: <label>B. executive power</label>
answers.C: <label>C. judicial power</label>
answers.D: <label>D. immigration power</label>
answers.E: <label>E. naturalization power</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. One of the judicial powers of the president is the power to grant amnesty, the offer of a pardon to a group of people who have committed offenses against the government. President Gerald Ford granted amnesty to men who left the United States during the Vietnam Conflict to avoid the draft.

content: In the United States government the creation of every bureaucratic agency may be traced back to

answers.A: <label>A. Congress</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the president</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the Constitution</label>
answers.D: <label>D. state governments</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the Articles of Confederation</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. The Constitution gives Congress the power to establish agencies of the federal bureaucracy.

content: What is the correct term for an organizational department of the government that has been created by the Congress but is still not located within the jurisdiction of one of the cabinet departments?

answers.A: <label>A. legislative agency</label>
answers.B: <label>B. congressional agency</label>
answers.C: <label>C. independent agency</label>
answers.D: <label>D. government agency</label>
answers.E: <label>E. executive agency</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. An independent agency is an agency of the executive branch that does not fall within the jurisdiction of a cabinet-level department. Examples include the Equal Opportunity Employment Commission and the Environmental Protection Agency.

content: During the 1930s, President Franklin Roosevelt attempted to increase the size of the Supreme Court by an unusual scheme. If he had been successful, six new positions would have been added. What was this scheme called?

answers.C: <label>C. court packing</label>
answers.D: <label>D. partisan control</label>
answers.E: <label>E. constitutional court controlling</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. "Court packing" is the term used to describe President Franklin Roosevelt's plan to increase the size of the Supreme Court by allowing the appointment of justices who were more likely to support Roosevelt's New Deal legislation. The plan was never implemented.

content: Which of the following best describes the speaker of the House?

answers.A: <label>A. presiding officer of the House</label>
answers.B: <label>B. shares power with the president pro tem</label>
answers.C: <label>C. appointed by the president</label>
answers.D: <label>D. appointed by members of his political party within the House</label>
answers.E: <label>E. controls Congress with the help of the president</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. The Speaker of the House is the presiding officer of the House of Representatives. The Speaker does not share power with the president pro tempore of the Senate (B). The Speaker is elected by the members of the majority party in the House (C, D). The majority leader and the majority whip, not the president, assist the Speaker (E).

content: Which of the following is NOT a function of an interest group?

answers.A: <label>A. creates interest in public affairs</label>
answers.B: <label>B. provides for a system of checks and balances on government officials</label>
answers.C: <label>C. stimulates political participation by the people</label>
answers.D: <label>D. provides information to government officials</label>
answers.E: <label>E. provides an avenue for political parties to obtain the vote and confidence of the people</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E. Interest groups do not provide ways for political parties to obtain votes. Interest groups do create interest in public affairs (A), stimulate political participation by the people (C), provide information to the government on issues they represent (D), and help provide for the system of checks and balance through their monitoring functions (B).

content: Which amendment of the United States Constitution altered the manner of voting in the electoral college?

answers.A: <label>A. Twenty-Second Amendment</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Twenty-Fifth Amendment</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Twelfth Amendment</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Twentieth Amendment</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Twenty-Sixth Amendment</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. The Twelfth Amendment provides for electors to choose the president and vice president by casting separate ballots for each office. Before the ratification of this amendment, each elector would cast two ballots. The candidate with the largest number of electoral votes became president, while the candidate receiving the second highest number of votes became vice president. The Twelfth Amendment was added in 1804 after the election of 1800 failed to produce a winner in the electoral college. Thomas Jefferson became president in 1801 after a long battle in the House of Representatives.

content: Which of the following is NOT mentioned in the United States Constitution?

answers.A: <label>A. political parties</label>
answers.B: <label>B. taxation</label>
answers.C: <label>C. impeachment</label>
answers.D: <label>D. treason</label>
answers.E: <label>E. ex post facto laws</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. Since political parties did not begin to form until George Washington's second administration, the Constitution does not refer to political parties.

content: The primary purpose of a conference committee is to

answers.A: <label>A. provide an investigative step in the passage of a bill</label>
answers.B: <label>B. provide the president with an update on vetoed bills</label>
answers.C: <label>C. compromise proposed bills between the two houses of the Congress</label>
answers.D: <label>D. review revenue bills</label>
answers.E: <label>E. determine if proposed bills are worthy of continuing the legislative process</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. Conference committees are created to iron out the differences in the House and Senate versions of a bill. Their goal is to create a compromise bill that, once passed by the House and Senate, can be sent to the president for signature or veto.

content: Which of the following is considered to be the main trial court within the federal court system?

answers.A: <label>A. the Supreme Court</label>
answers.B: <label>B. a district court</label>
answers.C: <label>C. an appellate court</label>
answers.D: <label>D. a federal circuit court</label>
answers.E: <label>E. a court of appeals</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. District courts serve as the trial courts within the federal court system. The remaining answer choices do not refer to trial courts.

content: Which of the following best describes the action taken by the Congress when the president vetoes a bill?

answers.A: <label>A. The bill is tabled.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The bill is sent to a conference committee.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The Speaker of the House is sent to discuss the bill with the president.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The bill may become a law if both houses override the presidential veto by a two-thirds vote.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The bill may become a law if both houses override the presidential veto by a simple majority in each house.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D. When the president vetoes a bill it is sent back to Congress, where it may become law if it is overridden by a two-thirds vote of both houses.

content: Which of the following is a false statement about the United States Constitution?

answers.A: <label>A. It is the guideline for fundamental law in the United States.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It provides for a system of checks and balances among the branches of government.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It limits the individual liberties of the American people.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It provides for the protection of individual freedoms.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. It provides for the separation of power among the three branches of government.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. The Constitution does not limit the individual liberties of the American people. The Constitution, including the Bill of Rights, guarantees numerous rights to the people.

content:
Which of the following is a characteristic of cooperative federalism?

I. block grants

II. revenue sharing

III. federal grants-in-aid

IV. devolution

answers.A: <label>A. I, II, and IV only</label>
answers.B: <label>B. I, II, and III only</label>
answers.C: <label>C. II, III, and IV only</label>
answers.D: <label>D. I only</label>
answers.E: <label>E. II only</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. Block grants, revenue sharing, and federal grants-in-aid are all characteristic of cooperative federalism. Devolution requires greater state responsibility about how grant money should be spent and is, therefore, a step away from cooperative federalism.

content: In the absence of the vice president, who is the presiding officer in the United States Senate?

answers.A: <label>A. the president of the Senate</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the president pro tem</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the majority leader</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the minority leader</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the speaker</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. If the vice president, who serves as president of the Senate, is not present, the president pro tempore serves in the vice president's absence. The majority party selects the president pro tempore.

content: Where in the Constitution is the establishment of a federal court system found?

answers.A: <label>A. Article I</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Article II</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Articles I and II</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Articles II and IV</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Article III</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E. Article III of the Constitution establishes the federal court system. Article I describes the organization and powers of the legislative branch, while Article II establishes the executive branch. Article IV deals with relations among the states.

content: Which of the Supreme Courts was the most active in the area of increasing the rights of the accused?

answers.A: <label>A. Warren Court</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Rehnquist Court</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Marshall Court</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Nixon Court</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Taft Court</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. The Supreme Court under Chief Justice Earl Warren (1953â€“1969) was the most active in increasing the rights of the accused. (Sample cases include Miranda v. Arizona, 1966; Gideon v. Wainwright, 1963; and Mapp v. Ohio, 1961.)

content: Which of the following is part of the legislative process in the House of Representatives but NOT in the Senate?

answers.A: <label>A. debate on the floor</label>
answers.B: <label>B. a filibuster</label>
answers.C: <label>C. referral to committee</label>
answers.D: <label>D. roll-call vote</label>
answers.E: <label>E. assignment of rules</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E. The assignment of rules occurs in the Rules Committee in the House of Representatives, but no such committee exists in the Senate. Filibusters (B) may occur in the Senate but not in the House of Representatives. Floor debate (A), referral to committee (C), and the roll-call vote (D) occur in both the House of Representatives and the Senate.

content: If a state is using a party-column ballot, what type of voting strategy is a voter more likely to use?

answers.A: <label>A. split-ticket voting</label>
answers.B: <label>B. party-line voting</label>
answers.C: <label>C. nonpartisan voting</label>
answers.D: <label>D. straight-ticket voting</label>
answers.E: <label>E. partisan voting</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D. Since the party-column ballot lists only the party members running for each office on the ballot, the party-column ballot attracts voters to the ease of straight-ticket voting.

content: According to James David Barber, which of the following is not a classification of presidential character?

answers.A: <label>A. positive-assertive</label>
answers.B: <label>B. passive-negative</label>
answers.C: <label>C. active-negative</label>
answers.D: <label>D. passive-positive</label>
answers.E: <label>E. active-positive</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. James David Barber classified types of presidential character as active-positive, active-negative, passive-positive, and passive-negative. Positive-assertive was not a classification used by Barber.

content: The burning of a United States flag would best be described as

answers.A: <label>A. unintended speech</label>
answers.B: <label>B. an obscenity</label>
answers.C: <label>C. a right that would be prohibited by the First Amendment</label>
answers.D: <label>D. symbolic speech</label>
answers.E: <label>E. a criminal activity</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D. In Texas v. Johnson the Supreme Court stated that burning the U.S. flag was a form of symbolic speech protected under the First Amendment.

content: Richard Neustadt, a noted political theorist, has stated that a president's power comes from

answers.A: <label>A. having the president's political party control both houses of the Congress during the presidential term</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the president's ability to persuade others to do what he or she wants</label>
answers.C: <label>C. being outside of politics</label>
answers.D: <label>D. not being sensitive to the political surroundings</label>
answers.E: <label>E. implementing his or her policies over the party's policies</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. Richard Neustadt stated that a president's power comes from the ability to persuade others to do what he or she wants.

content: The first African American to serve on the Supreme Court of the United States was

answers.A: <label>A. Thurgood Marshall</label>
answers.B: <label>B. John Marshall</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Clarence Thomas</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Oliver Wendell Holmes</label>
answers.E: <label>E. William O. Douglas</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. The first African American appointed to the Supreme Court was Thurgood Marshall, appointed by Lyndon Johnson. John Marshall (B) was the first Chief Justice of the Supreme Court. Oliver Wendell Holmes (D) and William O. Douglas (E) were Supreme Court justices. Clarence Thomas (C) currently serves as a justice on the Supreme Court.

content: How often are members of the House of Representatives elected?

answers.A: <label>A. every six years</label>
answers.B: <label>B. every five years</label>
answers.C: <label>C. every four years</label>
answers.D: <label>D. every three years</label>
answers.E: <label>E. every two years</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E. Members of the House of Representatives are elected every two years.

content: Which of the following was an expansion of suffrage that occurred before the Civil War?

answers.A: <label>A. elimination of gender disqualifications</label>
answers.B: <label>B. elimination of poll taxes</label>
answers.C: <label>C. elimination of religious qualifications</label>
answers.D: <label>D. elimination of race disqualifications</label>
answers.E: <label>E. elimination of literacy tests</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. Religious qualifications for voting were eliminated in the early years of the nineteenth century. Gender disqualifications (A) were eliminated in 1920 with the passage of the Nineteenth Amendment. Poll taxes in federal elections (B) were eliminated in 1964 with the passage of the Twenty-Fourth Amendment. Race disqualifications (D) were eliminated in 1870 with the passage of the Fifteenth Amendment. Literary tests (E) were eliminated in the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

content: If the president must nominate a new vice president due to the office being vacated, the nomination must be approved and confirmed by

answers.A: <label>A. the Senate</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the House of Representatives</label>
answers.C: <label>C. both houses of Congress</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the Supreme Court</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the Senate and the Supreme Court</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. If the president nominates a vice president because of a vacancy in the office, the Twenty-Fifth Amendment calls for both houses of Congress to approve the nomination.

content: Interest groups are different from political parties because they

answers.A: <label>A. only attempt to influence the president</label>
answers.B: <label>B. do not nominate candidates for office</label>
answers.C: <label>C. are only concerned with the winning of elections</label>
answers.D: <label>D. deal with a wide range of policy issues</label>
answers.E: <label>E. are more concerned with the making of policy than influencing policy</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. Interest groups do not nominate candidates for office. Choices (C), (D), and (E) describe the activities of political parties. Neither interest groups nor political parties attempt to influence only the president (A).

content: In the United States Constitution, where is the congressional power of taxation found?

answers.A: <label>A. Article III</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Article II</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Article I</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Article VI</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Article IV</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. Article I, which establishes the legislative branch, gives Congress the power to tax. Article II (B) establishes the executive branch, while Article III (A) establishes the judicial branch. Article IV (E) deals with relationships among the states, while Article VI (D) establishes the supremacy of the Constitution.

content: When Congress passed the Brady Bill, which required a five-day waiting period before the purchase of a handgun, it was following which step of the policymaking process?

answers.A: <label>A. agenda setting</label>
answers.B: <label>B. policy formulation</label>
answers.C: <label>C. policy evaluation</label>
answers.D: <label>D. policy adoption</label>
answers.E: <label>E. policy implementation</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D. Congress was involved in the policy adoption step, in which government adopts a plan of action, including the passage of legislation, to solve a problem. Agenda setting (A) is the recognition of an issue as a problem that must be addressed. Policy formulation (B) involves finding ways to solve the problem. Policy implementation (E) is the execution of the plan of action by the appropriate agencies, while policy evaluation (C) is the analysis of policy and its impact upon the problem.

content: The Full Faith and Credit Clause of the Constitution is the requirement that each state accept the public acts, records, and judicial proceedings of every other state, found in the Constitution in

answers.A: <label>A. Article I</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Article VI</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Article IV</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Article III</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Article II</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. The Full Faith and Credit Clause is found in Article IV of the Constitution, which addresses the relationship among the states.

content: Which amendment of the United States Constitution applies to unreasonable searches and seizure?

answers.A: <label>A. Fourth Amendment</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Tenth Amendment</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Fifth Amendment</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Ninth Amendment</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Second Amendment</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. The Fourth Amendment protects against unreasonable searches and seizures. The Tenth Amendment (B) speaks of the powers reserved to the states or to the people. The Fifth Amendment (C) deals with criminal proceedings and due process. The Ninth Amendment (D) addresses rights retained by the people, while the Second Amendment (E) guarantees the right to bear arms.

content: What is a possible result of an "off-year" election?

answers.A: <label>A. The president may be forced to resign.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The political power of Congress increases.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The power base of Congress may change.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The Constitution may change.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. An entirely new Senate is elected.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. Frequently during off-year elections the party of the president may lose seats in Congress, changing the base of power. Off-year elections do not force the president to resign (A), nor does the political power of Congress increase (B). The Constitution changes only by amendment (D). In any congressional election, only one-third of the Senate is elected (E).

content: Executive agreements

answers.A: <label>A. are nonbinding agreements</label>
answers.B: <label>B. require the approval of both houses of Congress</label>
answers.C: <label>C. do not have the force of law</label>
answers.D: <label>D. must be approved by the Supreme Court</label>
answers.E: <label>E. do not require Senate approval</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E. Executive agreements do not require Senate approval (B). They are pacts between the president and the head of state of a foreign country and are binding on the parties who make the agreement (A). They do not require the consent of the Supreme Court (D), nor do they remove governmental authority from Congress (C).

content: An order from the Supreme Court requesting that a lower court send up its records on a particular case is known as a(n)

answers.A: <label>A. certificate</label>
answers.C: <label>C. appeal</label>
answers.D: <label>D. brief proposal</label>
answers.E: <label>E. writ of power</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. A writ of certiorari (cert) is an order from the Supreme Court requesting that a lower court send up its records on a particular case.

content: Which of the following was NOT an aspect of the political culture of most of the Founding Fathers present at the Constitutional Convention?

answers.A: <label>A. Enlightenment philosophy</label>
answers.B: <label>B. divine right theory</label>
answers.C: <label>C. traditional democratic theory</label>
answers.D: <label>D. natural rights</label>
answers.E: <label>E. limited government</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. Political culture is the set of basic beliefs and values about government that is shared by mostcitizens. The divine right theory was the traditional European belief that monarchs ruled by direct authority from God. By the time in which the Constitution was written, the divine right theory had been challenged by Enlightenment philosophy (A), which included a belief in natural rights (D) ensured by limited government (E). The Founding Fathers embraced traditional democratic theory (C), or the concept that government depends on the consent of the governed.

content:
Which of the following is a proposed plan of reform for the electoral college when electing the president?

I. the district plan

II. the proportional plan

III. direct population election

IV. the national bonus plan

answers.A: <label>A. I only</label>
answers.B: <label>B. II and IV only</label>
answers.C: <label>C. I, II, III, and IV</label>
answers.D: <label>D. III only</label>
answers.E: <label>E. III and IV only</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. Proposed reforms of the electoral college include the district plan, proportional plan, national bonus plan, and direct popular election. In the district plan, two electors would be chosen at large from each state, while the other electors would be chosen within the state's congressional districts. Under the proportional plan, each presidential candidate would receive a share of the electoral vote proportional to the state's popular vote. The national bonus plan keeps the basic structure of the electoral college, but awards an additional 102 electoral votes to the winner of the popular vote. Direct popular election is the concept of abolishing the electoral college.

content: Political action committees are extensions of interest groups that

answers.A: <label>A. raise money for campaigns</label>
answers.B: <label>B. call for the resignation of fraudulent office holders</label>
answers.C: <label>C. encourage massive use of propaganda</label>
answers.D: <label>D. define public opinion</label>
answers.E: <label>E. determine public opinion</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. Political action committees are extensions of interest groups that raise money for political candidates and campaigns.

content: Which of the following is true about most presidential elections in modern history?

answers.A: <label>A. Candidates from all parties usually receive some electoral votes.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. They result in major party realignments.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. They often center around one important issue.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The winner of the popular vote usually wins the majority of the electoral vote.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. They are nonpartisan elections.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D. In most modern presidential elections, the winner of the popular vote also wins the majority of the electoral vote. Usually only candidates of major parties receive electoral votes (A). Most modern elections center around a variety of issues (C), but seldom result in realignment of the major parties (B). Elections involve the active participation of political parties (E).

content: The power of television in U.S. politics was best illustrated in which of the following presidential elections?

answers.A: <label>A. the Bush-Gore election of 2000</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the Truman-Dewey election of 1948</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the Nixon-Kennedy election of 1960</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the Carter-Ford election of 1976</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the Reagan-Carter election of 1980</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. The power of the media, especially television, is best illustrated by the Kennedy-Nixon campaign in 1960, when a presidential debate was televised for the first time. Television coverage of the debates is credited as one of the factors in Kennedy's victory over Nixon. Television continued to play a major role in the coverage of future presidential campaigns (A, D, E). The role of the media in the Truman-Dewey campaign (B) is best noted by faulty polling methods that incorrectly predicted Dewey as the winner of the election.

content: An important result of McCulloch v. Maryland (1819) was to

answers.A: <label>A. establish the supremacy of the federal government over the states</label>
answers.B: <label>B. place limits on the powers of Congress</label>
answers.C: <label>C. establish the doctrine of judicial review</label>
answers.D: <label>D. establish the doctrine of dual federalism</label>
answers.E: <label>E. give greater power to the states</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. An important result of McCulloch v. Maryland (1819) was to establish the supremacy of the federal government over the states (E). McCulloch upheld the implied powers of Congress to create a Bank of the United States (B). Judicial review (C) was established in Marbury v. Madison. Dual federalism (D) views the national and state governments each remaining supreme within their own sphere of influence.

content: Which of the following occurs latest in the passage of a bill in Congress?

answers.A: <label>A. conference committee</label>
answers.B: <label>B. referral to committee</label>
answers.C: <label>C. investigation and hearings</label>
answers.D: <label>D. debate on the floor</label>
answers.E: <label>E. amendment committee</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A. The conference committee occurs latest in this list of steps in the passage of a bill through Congress. Conference committees are organized when the House and the Senate pass a bill in different forms. The steps in the passage of a bill are B, C, E, D, and A.

content: Voters casting their ballots for candidates of a presidential candidate's political party because of the popularity of the presidential candidate is best described as

answers.A: <label>A. same-party voting</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the presidential-coattail effect</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the party-electoral effect</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the electoral effect</label>
answers.E: <label>E. presidential-party voting</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B. The presidential coattail effect refers to the phenomenon whereby voters support members of the president's party running for other offices, because of the president's popularity.

content: Which is true of the Supreme Court of the United States?

answers.A: <label>A. Judges are nominated by the president and confirmed by the House of Representatives.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Judges serve at the will of the president.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Judges are appointed for life and can only be removed by impeachment.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Judges set their own salaries and benefits.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Judges are always from the same political party as the president.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C. Justices to the Supreme Court are appointed for life terms, during good behavior, and can be removed only through impeachment and conviction of the charges against them (B). They are nominated by the president and confirmed by the Senate (A).
